column10:
It took me almost 3 years to finish this game, and after completing it, all I have to say is that it left me speechless. I finally decided to pick it back up again once I found out that they were releasing the Apollo Justice trilogy onto Steam. So I was like, you know what, let me finish what I started. It was kind of a pain to get through JFA, since I stopped playing at the point of one of the most remarkably terrible chapters. I wouldn’t recommend starting Ace Attorney and then just dropping it for a long while because I had to refresh my memory on a lot of previous cases since I had forgotten the main plot points of them (which is not a good idea since the game is very driven by its past cases). The game normally gives a short recap at times, but I’m very detail-oriented, so I wasn't satisfied with how brief it was. I straight up read through several wiki pages just to remember what had happened previously. However, once I got back, I got back to playing NONSTOP. I remembered just how fun and enjoyable all the characters were, and honestly, I loved the challenge of trying to figure out the mysteries behind each case. Although I enjoyed all of the games equally, my favorite one hands down was Trials and Tribulations. And the final achievement that the game gives you for completing the whole trilogy had me bawling. 

My only complaint was that the lawyers did not smooch at the end. I will always have a little soft spot for the gay lawyers (and Gumshoe).

Deserves the high reviews. But it's not for me, I don't think. I felt like the conclusions I was reaching did not line up with the game. Like my brain would tell me "this piece of evidence should be used here". But the logic of the game often didn't line up with my brain logic. Not that the game is wrong, I don't think. It's just that what seemed clear to me often ran contrary to the game. Still, there are so many fun characters and the story (as far as I played) was neat.

Fantastic Trilogy with investing storytelling. Game mechanics for 3D UI aren't completely adapted for PC play, and some will make you want to pull your hair out (like a certain vase, for example) - but it makes up for this with charming character interactions and sweet-cathartic justice.
It's Ace Attorney, popular for a good reason.

This game was, for lack of better words, an amazing experience, and I truly wish I had played it sooner. It's not perfect, far from it actually, but it's how genuine and charming it feels that really does it for me. Some of these characters, such as Edgeworth, Gumshoe or Godot are probably my favorites in any video game, the mechanics here are brilliant and make for a very fun experience, and even though not all cases are hits, I can't say there was any that I didn't at least have fun with. 

I also love how this game is able to balance truly heartbreaking emotional moments with some of the sharpest comedy I've seen in a while. The OST is just excellent (some highlights for me being "True Pain" and "The Bitter Taste of Truth") and absolutely carries this game. 

Overall, despite it's faults, the Ace Attorney trilogy is to me a timeless classic and I finally understand why so many people love these games. A must play if you haven't already.

Great faithful recreation of the classic 3 games, the series at its absolute best, I enjoyed it years ago on a DS emulator, and I still enjoyed (especially my favorite entries) as much as back then. Lots of content for the price.

Ace Attorney is a courtroom drama vn with some detective investigation in between, I don't like VNs that boil down clicking through dialogue and only ever giving a "yes/no" option every now and then to make a save point at, so basically any VN that includes more gameplay has preferential treatment from me. I might have given a positive review to danganronpa games, but the bat***t story and school (eww) settings in some are far worse than the more grounded and charming scenarios of these games. The gap between the two series in my eyes is big, and I prefer PW:AA a lot more.

The visuals are upscaled, traced and smoothened out from the old pixelated releases, they tried to keep them as similar to the original sprites as possible, which while playing it safe, is probably the best choice for such a beloved series. Some of the visuals might look odd in such high resolution, and there is no setting to switch back to old sprites, so it's not perfect exactly, but I have few complaints. I like the charm to the spritework and the 3 games have a very specific artstyle that stands out. It might not be the best looking gameboy game, but for the cartridge limitations etc. it looked good for the time.

Sound is pretty much the same as (I believe) DS ports, the music is higher quality than the gameboy releases, and while sound effects are probably better too, they are VERY crunchy at times. The fact that visuals have been upscaled and recreated, yet the sounds are as compressed as years before does stand out quite a lot, the loops are naturally also still very short, so things like rowdy courtroom crowd looping is very noticable. The music composition though is outstanding, and one of the big reasons people still remember Ace Attorney games.

Gameplay is a bit simple, but still rewarding, investigation sections involve point n click mechanics, looking for items, talking to people, using items on people to progress, and from game 2 onwards - interrogating minigame to discover secrets.
In courtroom you get several part statements from witnesses, press on them for more details, sometimes uncovering additional parts, and selecting correct evidence on correct statement part to object. Sometimes you have a multiple choice question, or you point to specific element on a photo/map to prove your point. Each mistake costs an amount of health, which without using saves can be a bit restrictive with how much text you would need to skip past again. The HP part is not perfect, but it often acts as a decent pressure gauge, as more important points will also penalize more on your bar.
Lastly, the first game had a DLC in its nintendo ds rerelease, it's a longer case and it includes some new things (which stand out by being absent in chronologically next 2 games), some of the evidence can be inspected as 3d objects, there is a little interactive segment to check for fingerprints, and there is even a short 3d video cutscene, that you will pause at correct time to point out a contradiction, something that was only possible on static images in other entries.

Lastly the story, the first game is a classic and works perfectly well as a self contained piece of writing, it was a critique of japanese judical system at a time, and the main characters reflect that, even disregarding that aspect, the narrative is solid and well put together, with only the samurai case feeling as a bit of an intermission. The second game is a bit rough in my eyes, it pushes a theme very strongly in an overt way at the very beginning, just to sit on it and seemingly do nothing until the very end. The starting theme in question is just "what if we did it the other way around", where defense lawyers can be the immoral ones. The second (first real case) is decent and it sets up a lot, while coming from the first game, revealing that a spiritual aspect is no longer implied, kind of disappointed me, it is a set up for better things to come out of it. Third case feels like extreme filler, although I did like the conclusion of it. And lastly the fourth case, which despite the game feeling weak, is one of the best cases in the entire series, the twist might be obvious at that point, but the way it flows is executed really well.
Then the third game, rarely do I see the third installment to be the best, yet this one happened. There are two cases set in the past that add to the main narrative, while the 2 standalone ones feel a LOT better than the circus one in 2, the fact that the game doesn't start with a big dream sequence metaphor helps these 2 cases feel natural, and despite being a bit disconnected from the narrative, they also add to the character development, besides just being good on their own. Then there is a case that closes it all, all 3 games, takes setup from second game and all of the additional context from 3rd, the character development pays off a lot, even pulling on my strings a little, despite me being a cold stupid f***k. Things that seemed like anime nonsense were executed in such a smooth and convincing way that even on second playthrough I felt like I was going through this story the first time. I could easily recommend checking out PW1 on its own, and if its quirks are fun enough to push further, I think it'd be a disservice to stop before reaching the end of PW3.

I don't know what the optimal price would be, I think I paid around 20 bucks, which is quite a bit if you just want to play the first game, but for all 3 classic games I'd say it's worth it and then some.

Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney has earned the title of being "Schrödinger's Game" as the more I played it, the less I became convinced it was an actual game. Somewhere between the "unnecessary feelings" and cross-examining a parrot I accepted the fact that I was just never meant to understand this game. Which is very much like how I still don't understand the concept of Schrödinger's Cat but I still find a way to reference it in every conversation I've had since I've learned of its existence. 10/10 I've made my friend's life a living hell with the constant stream of Whatsapp messages with varying captions of "Are you seeing this?" I hope to see the Investigations and the Layton/AA games on here someday.

This might just be the greatest trilogy of stories I have ever witnessed in my life. Almost every case is written in a way that somehow takes itself seriously yet also throws in the most insane moments of humor without breaking the immersion. I made the mistake of waiting for a sale to play this but honestly, this is worth twice the asking price. 10/10

Fantastic plot with unexpected turnarounds, carefully designed callbacks, and increasing depth. Excellent character building--every character shines in their own ways, and the game presents a good showcase of different perspectives and motives. Highly recommend.

One caveat: please don't take the laws/procedural rules too seriously. For those with a legal background, it may require some effort to overlook some of the (glaring) procedural due process issues and violations of evidentiary rules in the game. Nevertheless, these issues do not lessen the dramatic effect and overall effectiveness of the story.
A masterful narrative.

Having heard references to this game so many times over the years, i decided to see what it had to offer. The answer, sadly, is not much.

The pacing is glacially slow, and the dialogue is not exactly riveting. Furthermore, I had only gotten as far as the 2nd chapter of the first game when I already hit a logic problem; the clear and obvious answer was apparently wrong, and after racking my brain I went online to find the solution, which turned out to make no sense. If you're going to make what amounts to a detective game and you have this issue, you failed.

Overall I think this would actually make for a pretty good childrens game given the easy dialogue and slow pace but that's pretty much the only positive thing I can say about it.

The core element of the Phoenix Wright games is the intricate, often surprising cases you must unravel as the rookie defense attorney, Phoenix Wright. Each case is carefully constructed, introducing memorable characters, unexpected twists, and satisfying 'aha' moments when you piece together the truth.

I particularly enjoyed the final cases in each of the three games. These grand finales tested all the investigative and courtroom skills I'd gained, keeping me glued to my screen. Every time I thought I'd grasped the full picture, a new revelation was thrown in, completely challenging my assumptions.

I highly recommend the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy to fans of mysteries, courtroom dramas, or anyone looking for a unique and entertaining gaming experience.  While the core gameplay can feel slightly repetitive across several cases, the memorable characters, clever puzzles, and mind-blowing twists more than make up for it.

"Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney Trilogy" it's a remaster compilation of the first classic games of this series. "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney (2001)" , "Justice For All (2002)" and "Trials and Tribulations (2004)".
In this trilogy, we'll play as a defense attorney throughout fourteen different cases. As this job demands we would have to examine the crime scene, search for clues, talk to witnesses, defend our clients, have a blind faith in them and finally willing to discover the very truth until the end.
Although this visual novel is not one of my favourites it is indeed  freaking good. All the sections of this game are absolutely incredible. I'll talk in full detail about those:

-The soundtrack is unbelievable. There's not a single bad song on the trilogy soundtrack. Each one is perfectly designed for transmitting the right feeling or sensation at the right time. These might become a little repetitive though.

-The characters are well written. Every single one of them have their own background, their own goal or objective and their own development. I must mention the fact that every character is there for a reason and everyone have something to do with past, current or future cases. Or even they have conections or secrets between themselves that we'd have to uncover.

-I think that the cases themselves are the best and most important section about this visual novel. Every new case that we have to play is better than the last one. Not just better but more mysterious, more entertaining and more unpredictable. Just like the characters, the cases are not random. Most of them are linked to each other and we will realize that sooner or later. Of course, not every case has the same lore or talks about the same murder or situation.
Every case is different than the previous one. And of course, I have to mention that not every case has the same length, some are shorter and some are larger.

-The hours worth of gameplay is something to stand out too. In my experience, it took me 106 hours to complete the fourteen cases. It could sound like it's too many hours but you won't get bored a single minute playing this game, I can assure u that for sure.

I'd like to mention the only negative thing about this visual novel though. That is the lack of a patch about the Spanish translation. I understand that's an issue for the people who speak Spanish but don't speak English. It's kinda sad that they can't have the oportunity to play such a great visual novel just for that.

Anyways I deeply recommend you to buy and play this visual novel, you won't regret it. The people who are into series or movies about crimes, attorneys and law stuff, like I am, they must play this too.

[h1] "You're not the clown. You are the entire circus." [/h1]

You know why I love Ace Attorney? -- Because it takes a mundane, boring-ass job and turns it into this hype dramatic courtroom drama. Lawyers just weren't cool before Phoenix Wright came along!

The first three games of this game are so similar in game-play & story-telling that I can't really pick them apart individually. But I'll say that Trials & Tribulations has the most consistently awesome cases, so I'll pick that one as my favourite of the trio. BUT that is also due to how Justice For All and Ace Attorney were building up to that finale conclusion in Trials & Tribulations. Albeit the case "Rise from the Ashes" is single-handedly the best case in the entire series. It's so fricking good, it's one of the most epic cases to ever possibly exist, to ever be written in any media whatsoever!
I mean... these are linear visual-novels, which is something I'd otherwise never really enjoy; but the writing in them all are so good that I completed all three. As a guy who doesn't typically enjoy those types of games, this is completely unnatural for me, let alone spending 75 hours in one. Yet they hooked me so much that I would spent HOURS per day just reading all these insane dialogue sequences, while I'm on my tippy toes, with my jaw hanging, experiencing the best video-game writing I've ever encountered. Basta! There so many iconic & memorable lines & moments throughout this trilogy, that they never leave your mind. You'll think back fondly to so many parts of this game with a huge grin, as it's all good memories. It's full-throttle top-tier writing all the time!
And the amount of 'Chekhov's gun' presences in this game is simple baffling!

You go up against all these prosecuters & murderers who are out to get Phoenix Wright, like they got the spiteful fire in their eyes and all.
Seeing the breakdowns, and finding the contradictions................ ohh so satisfying! It's some of the most satisfying & exciting moments in my history of gaming, ever.
If you haven't touched this trio of games before, do yourself a favour and buy them ASAP! Pronto!

It's like, the plot of these games are so bat-sh!t insane -- Like Phoenix Wright is defending his arch-nemesis childhood friend 'Miles Edgeworth', in a murder cases which Miles admitted to committing. And the prosection is led by Mile's former Sith Lord who's never lost a case in 40 years!! You wanna talk drama? Go tell all your bachelor shows to screw off! Come play Ace Attorney! You're in for a ride, laddie.



[h1] Achtung, baby! Let's rock! [/h1]

oh...my...god...
The soundtrack for these games some of the bests on the market. I've never experienced anything like it, not to the same degree. The sound-design is just simply outright unfathomable.
With all the blazing notes, and catchy rhythms; it all just seamlessly flow together into this elegant, beautiful maestro pot of elegance & rancid power fantasies; forming this majestic soundtrack to wonderfully go alongside with the game. To remove the soundtrack of this game is to remove so much of its very own spirit. Ace Attorney is only half itself without its music. The scenes & score slither together to bind a formation irremovable, as one are just not as powerful if not without the other, as they build on-top of each other. The music further emphasises the epic & sorrowful occasions to be held throughout the game, just like how the epic & sorrowful occasions emphasise the music. With only one, you only got half the experience. To experience one before the other is to lessen the experience to when the two of them conjoined.
It's so beautiful, it's so great, honestly.
And it's straight-up all bonerjams too. I can't explain it... it can only be understood the best audibly when accompanied with its possible contexts.
I listen to the soundtrack every week, it's great!
Still, I prefer Ace Attorney 4, 5,and 6's scores overall; but these are really wonderful regardless!



[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

The Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney Trilogy is one of the best gaming experiences one can play.
This is a game I feel I can recommend to everyone: noob, pro, non-reader, reader, dumb, smart, young, old; doesn't matter. I believe this can be an experience every demographic can enjoy! Just be capable of reading, at least. haha
What a godlike game, it no doubt fits in my top #10 all-time favourite video-games ever.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a very fun and hard game, and it is a solo game. Nothing is like what it seems to be at first after the first few cases, with an unexpected and unique twist in each case. 

It is a fun game, with funny characters, deep lore and a lot of joy when you find a contradiction! Nobody is safe from assumption, and if it gets too hard you can search the internet for a guide.


On the other hand, it is an extremely hard game. Sometimes, while you’re investigating, you might forget to do something and get stuck in that point of the game. You can always count on a guide to help you though.

All in all, This game was worth the hours of fun, even though I got stuck many times and had to look up a guide. It is a great game, and it’s got more cases to present in other Ace Attorney games! I really recommend this game. I hope you enjoy it!  “Objection!”!

Overall a great compilation of 3 games (Ace Attorney, Justice for All, Trials and Tribulations).

I would rate each game as follows (1-5, worst to best):
AA: 4*
JfA: 3*
TaT: 4*

The standout cases were: Rise from the Ashes, Bridge to the Turnabout and to a lesser degree Turnabout Memories, Turnabout Sisters, Turnabout Beginnings. You can probably see a pattern: the cases tied to the main story are more to my taste in general but it's not always the case: The Lost Turnabout.

The games also have one of the best soundtracks in history, which is no small feat.

Technically, negatives for me were lack of chat log and no autoplay. Content-wise, I have a huge problem with the potrayal and weird fixation on underage girls in these games.

Capcom is adding anti-consumer software, called Enigma, to all of its old games, in an effort to prevent modding. It introduces instability and performance problems, such as frame drops and crashes. This disgusting behavior punishes paying customers, and drives people towards piracy. Capcom doesn't deserve your money. Please vote with your wallets.

Great games and the updated sprites are nice too. I wish this collection brought some of the QoL changes from the newer games, like a dialogue transcript and the ability to go to any location you want but overall it's a solid trilogy of intriguing, funny, emotional and epic visual novel games.

70小时全成就，正式结束这个系列啦，逆转裁判4-6换主角了也没什么兴趣，之后跟着B站云一下成步堂相关剧情了，逆转检事1和2等steam版出了再玩吧，希望卡普空赶紧出逆检3好三部曲一起打包上架，会不会赚钱啊卡普空！
——————————————————
66小时成步堂三部曲结束，评价的话第一部9/10，第二部3/10，第三部7/10，第一部多2分主要在于初见新鲜感+没勾玉，勾玉系统属实太垃圾了。比较喜欢的案子1-4御剑案、1-5警署检察院案、2-2灵媒案、3-2怪盗案和3-5叶樱院案，都是案子本身有让我“哇，这个点有意思”的设计以及逻辑相对正常、推理相对流畅的。1-4巧妙在三人伪密室（电梯）的第四者，1-5的影片推理+同一人两个被害地特别有趣，2-2正当防卫到完全无罪，3-2犯人移动装饰来伪装日期+一罪不二审，3-5利用信息差降灵保护自己。虽然这几个案子都有瑕疵和令我暴躁的逻辑点，尤其灵媒案和最终案，但瑕不掩瑜。讨厌的案子2-3马戏团案、2-4王都楼案和3-3真假律师案，只能说是逻辑崩坏、胡乱吃书、全员降智、前后矛盾、故弄玄虚、部分触发苛刻且无提示。第一部初见真的好玩，互扔异议特别搞笑，第二部游玩体验奇差，好在第三部又恢复正常。整体下来最喜欢的人物还是千寻，温柔但果敢坚定；除此之外，成步堂、御剑、真宵、系锯刑警、矢张、彩芽、雾绪的人物塑造都很好，难得玩一款单机游戏会对这么多角色高好感。
最后再补一句，古早游戏里的男凝真的让人很不舒服，这游戏里太多猥琐男npc了，每部都有一个，像是什么游戏kpi指标一样，只能说看在古早日本游戏的份上我原谅。
————————————————————————
第一部真的很有质量，有趣且有逻辑，但第二部是什么鬼啊……再故意夸张我也无法接受狩魔冥动不动就法庭上抽人鞭子，你们立本法里没有故意伤害罪吗？？
灵媒案逻辑逆天，灵媒被附身杀了人，成步堂不希望真宵背负杀人的阴影所以想证明真宵的“绝对无辜”我尚且可以用“灵媒被附身时不会做梦”来洗，但检察官和法官和整个法院的人全都在认为“灵媒确实被附身了”的前提下还坚持灵媒有罪，啊？？而且姐妹长得根本不像，在被拍到了那么清楚的正脸照的情况下竟然是靠“化妆”这个理由就能说这是姐姐伪装，你这不是化妆，是易容吧？？
马戏团的案子简直一坨垃圾，凶手不能探出窗外看到受害人的位置，于是放了个10公斤的大箱子在楼下，并说受害人会因为知道这是她以前犯错的证据而弯腰搬箱子，所以能确定位置……但你原本想杀的是那个13岁的女儿啊？？？你放的箱子1.上锁了没人能看到内容物，2.内容物全是胡椒粉瓶，受害人搬走毫无意义，3.又大又重你指望一个13岁小女孩儿看到箱子的第一反应是去搬？？更荒谬的是扔半身像砸人还能拽回楼上，一路上竟然没有半身像和墙体的碰撞摩擦声，半身像在砸死受害者的时候竟然还正巧把受害者身上穿着的披风挂上了…………你哪怕说指挥猴子呢…………这个案子我看完最大感受是：狮子雷恩真惨，被马戏团动物表演了一辈子，老了还因为小女孩儿放的胡椒粉打喷嚏而伤了人被枪杀。
真宵被绑架的案子更是一个逻辑崩坏+吃书的合集，杀手脸上缝线这么明显的特征，成步堂硬是在第二次见面没认出来？杀手名字这么特殊，甚至都写在案情记录里了，成步堂再次听到这个名字硬是一点反应都没有？？游戏世界观设定了三日法庭，到第三天一定要做出有罪无罪判罚，结果第三天法庭上法官说明日再审？？？而这时候成步堂竟然反对明日再审，因为他要拖时间让警方找到真宵？？？你今天在法庭拖再久也不如明天再审拖得久啊。
玩第二部全程不断提醒自己别带脑子别带脑子，然而又会因为条件苛刻且没提示的剧情触发锁卡关。上一部碰运气出示证据成功的感受是“哇这个我没想到，但合情合理！”，这一部我直接穷举成功的感受是“你还能这么水剧情啊？”
玩第三部之前先给个差评。第二部烂得令人发指。
————————————————————————

Feels super dated. There's very little "game" here, it's more of an interactive graphic novel. Moving from place to place is a chore. Needing to get follow certain steps exactly as the game wants you to before you advance feels very limiting. The story itself is good, with some twists and turns, but the leaps in logic you need to make in order "win" the court cases is just a little too much. Sometimes the game wants you to present certain pieces of evidence that makes zero sense on the surface, but then the dialog afterwards fills in the logic gap. Like, yeah, that does make sense, but there was nothing to indicate to the player that it was the correct choice other than blind luck. 

This game is ultimately like a color-by-numbers book. Yeah, the picture looks good in the end, but you didn't really do anything to influence how it looks, you just followed a pre-defined path until it was finished.

Before playing the game, I always thought that both sides in criminal cases were lawyers, but I didn't expect it to be a debate between prosecutors and lawyers. 
After checking online, the primary task of a lawyer is to propose suggestions to the court according to the law for the defendant's innocence or lightening, mitigating or exempting punishment. 
He can do both guilt and innocence defense. When doing guilt defense, he can agree with the prosecutor's qualitative opinion on the case, but he cannot completely agree with the prosecutor's view as a second prosecutor. 
Perhaps there is still a gap between the real-life interest disputes and the behavior of advocating "truth" in the game [spoiler] (probably most people in reality are more like people like "Franziska von Karma") [/spoiler]. However, because of this, the most simple behavior of this kind of mutual debate in the game, which only seeks truth and fairness, is more memorable. 
Also, it's clearly a debate game! Who can tell me why I feel like I'm playing a monster-fighting game when I play it? The game's combat feel is so great!

This game was really long because it consists of three episodes.  It's a case-related interactive story where your character, a defense attorney, is put in some pretty comically impossible situations.  A lot of character reactions and mannerisms are pretty dang hilarious, like you would expect from this form of Japanese entertainment.

The cases throughout the episodes often relate to one another, but not always.  There are two forms of gameplay, investigation and trial.  Investigations involve reviewing crime scenes, speaking to people and presenting evidence to get more information.  Trials involve figuring out what truly happened by cross-examining witnesses for contradictions either by pressing their statements or presenting evidence, and by further proving your case by making decisions.  Most of the time, you really, really need to know the ins and outs of the case.  This game does NOT forgive you very easily for being all willy-nilly about pressing and presenting.  You must do so with meaningful purpose.  If you screw up enough times (in few cases, only one screw up will fail the entire trial) the verdict for the prosecution will be handed down and you will have to start all over.  Not to mention, the game does not spare you in making you feel like a total loser when this happens.

The biggest beef I had with this game was the fact that your opponents, the prosecutors, and a few disagreeable witnesses, act like the biggest freaking d0uchebags ever.  The second was that the judge(s) are complete imbeciles and will hastily disregard all of your decisive evidence just because you pressed the wrong freaking statement or something stupid like that and they possess no actual spine and basically let the prosecutor run the whole dang show.  I found myself calling my computer screen lots of derogatory terms because of this.  My wife:  "What are you doing down there??"

In the end, the stories are entertaining, the cases are interesting and the investigation/trial work requires you to think through everything in great detail, or you will not succeed.  If you're a good puzzle-solver and are a fan of legal themes, then you would like this game a lot.

Former positive review:
Ace Attorney is a series about arguably competent lawyers fighting in a kangaroo court to appease or threaten the judge into taking their sides and I think playing the games is a human right. I'm going to go off on a limb even and claim Ace Attorney is the best visual novel series ever made, or at least the best I've ever played. 

Sure, you could just watch a YouTube video on the games. You know, if you suck. Playing the games for yourself and experiencing the nonsense that goes on in this heaven-forsaken courtroom firsthand is definitely the best way to play, though. Make up your own jokes and baloney along the way and all that good stuff.

Also if it wasn't for some of the very explicitly Japanese-y content, you'd be unable to tell this game wasn't originally in English. The translation is stellar. Some may not like that the games had, and continue to change character names from the original Japanese, but considering a lot of the names are puns you'd be unable to understand if they didn't change them, I think it as a whole makes the game more enjoyable to a non-Japanese audience. Not to mention typos and grammar errors are few and far between which, for a text-based game series, is not an easy thing to check for.

My only complaint is that not enough of this series is on PC. NOT. ENOUGH. This trilogy and the Great Ace Attorney duology are the ONLY ones. Dammit man, I just want AA: Investigations on PC. Is that too much to ask? What about Apollo Justice? Dual Destinies? Spirit of Justice? There's so much of this series limited to platforms that aren't PC! I'd be glad to pay another however much it'd cost for a second trilogy with the other 3 games, or an Investigations collection or whatever. Come on, Capcom!

One of my favorite series since the Nintendo DS era. Seeing it remastered with HD graphics and the first three games bundled into one makes it even better. It's a very engaging visual novel with cases that will keep you thinking since it always takes surprising turns. It keeps getting crazier, especially it hits the second game! The lore that spans between all three games is interesting. Being put in the shoes of a lawyer also is a unique premise. The dialogue is very well written with a lot of humor and pretty much every character is memorable. I recently speedran the game to get all achievements and I think it says a lot that I still remembered the whole trilogy after all these years.

很早以前玩3DS的时候就听说过这部作品，但当时以为自己不会喜欢文字/剧情类游戏。最近看到各个平台玩梗的人越来越多，而且都是好梗，趁这次打折入了三部曲。

剧情方面要着重夸，其实当玩家被代入到游戏中时，自己也会猜测真相。甚至很多时候，玩家自己的解释都能自圆其说，但是游戏依然可以给出意料之外的结局。而且这些故事不单单是悬疑推理，还加入了宿命论、神秘主义和寓言故事的元素。让我甚至觉得有种看《岸边露半一动不动》的感觉。

把人物之间的情感以在我看来隐晦内敛的方式融入在悬疑故事中，同时又真正让玩家真真切切体会到了角色之间的炽热情感，在我看来真的是非常难得。

游戏性主要体现在调查和庭审，个人比较喜欢庭审过程。询问和指出矛盾是游戏核心，尤其是寻找库存中正确的证据并加以解释这一点真的对我来说很有吸引力。调查方面，感觉最突出的点是气氛，也就是真相慢慢显露的过程。不过有少数调查感觉有些重复了。

Okay, I give up. After 8 hours of playing Ace Attorney and getting through almost the first 4 cases, I can't handle any more.

This VN has got some of the most uncomfortable controls of any VN I have ever played. They're scattered all over the keyboard - one minute you're pressing space, then tab, then escape, then J, then you need to use the mouse for something else. It's absurdly byzantine for a VN, as if the game was programmed by an octopus.

You can't flick through text quickly because there are constant animated interludes that slow down the dialog. When you're not in the courtroom it takes 27 different button presses just to walk 2 rooms over and talk to someone. And you need to constantly walk 2 rooms over and talk to someone because the next piece of dialog only unlocks in one place if you follow exactly the perfect sequence of events in another place, and then you have to go back to the first place and do it all over again for the next dialog unlock. This game feels like a relic from the dark ages of point and click adventures. To be fair it is 20 years old, but even for the era this is offensively bad.

I might be able to overlook the hideous controls if the game was actually good, but it isn't! Everything in the artwork is rooted in Japan, but the translation explicitly sets itself in America so the dialog never matches the artwork and every scene feels weirdly hollow as a result. I know the whole gimmick is that the cases are bizarre, but no matter how much improbable nonsense they pile on, nothing ever gets wacky in a way that's actually interesting. It's always a kangaroo court. The judge puts up arbitrary roadblocks for no plot reason, it's simply a trick to make the player's life more difficult. All the characters are shallow and - even worse - stupid. You can sit there as a player and know exactly what happened but the game won't let you solve the case because you didn't pick up the right object or "press" on the right witness statement yet. It's just infuriating.

On the upside, the music is good, and the first time you see "objection!" it's totally meme-worthy and hilarious. But then it happens a dozen more times. I kept playing thinking that perhaps on the next day or the next case something new would be brought to the table, but nothing ever is. All the jokes are played out after the first half hour. I just cannot understand how people enjoy this game. It's so slow and frustrating and dull. There are so many better detective games, point and click adventures and visual novels out there. Not recommended at all.

I recommend you play the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy.

1) With three games in one (Ace Attorney, Justice for All, and Trials and Tribulations), this remastered and bundled trilogy is expansive and affordable.
2) The Capcom Sound Team made fantastic songs that accompany the setting well, making for many catchy tunes on this soundtrack.
3) This trilogy gives an immersive setting with unique gameplay elements and a story that progresses through the various chapters offered, adapting concepts and ramping up difficulty. The ensemble of characters and moments will leave you wanting more and wondering what could happen next in the plot – with many “turnabouts.”

The Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a memorable and well-crafted cult-classic trilogy you should add to your library.

I first heard about Ace Attorney around a decade ago. Didn't really pay it any mind until I found this exact trilogy on the App Store and decided I'd give it a shot. Never did I expect a game about solving murder cases to have such fun, memorable characters and godlike music. This has been a hard sell to my friends, but the few who have taken my advice and tried it have loved it. If you're at all interested, this collection is probably the most accessible the first three games have ever been. Purists complain that the aesthetic of this trilogy is too far removed from that of the original spritework, but I don't see it, and frankly if you've never played before, that shouldn't bother you. The latter half of this series is getting the compilation treatment next month and I couldn't be more excited; I haven't played those. Now's a perfect time to get into this series if you haven't yet

I mean, I like it. But I'm treating it like a VN and using a guide for most of it. If you don't want to do this and want to figure things out yourself, be aware that the game suffers from outstanding leaps of logic that defy reality. One whole case is centred around the idea that elevators are so airtight it can cause people to black out and become brain damaged. This is not a thing that normal, intelligent people would think of since it simply just isn't a thing that happens.

But then, this is the series where channelling ghosts is real and makes the possessed person appear like the person they're possessed by. Meaning a 7 year old becomes possessed and grows to like 6' tall with massive badonkadonks.

Also Gumshoe best guy.

I wish I could give it star-ratings instead of like vs. dislike. I'd give it 7/10.

Overall, a positive experience but there's too much backtracking and if you don't notice a clue then you can be stuck going back and forth between rooms looking for a clue.

It'd be nice if the investigators did their damn job and brought all evidence to court so I can spend time deducing rather than backtracking all the time.

That being said, this game makes you feel smart when you get things right and go "wtf" when attempting all 30 pieces of evidence a hundred times with everyone you talk to and in court after reloading another 100 times.

It's a love-hate relationship.

A classic, a masterpiece and a must have on the genre of VNs and mystery solving, without a doubt one of the most iconic experiences you can get, with really memorable characters, with a god-tier OST and definitely one of the most iconics plots and storylines we have out there, especially with the whole mechanic where you have to figure out the truth and progress through the story while utilizing logic and deducing what its happening when finding contradictions on testimonies, gathering information, investigating/examining places and finding clues, making you very immersed on the whole plot, that its of course insanely well writed with great, memorable and mind blowing moments.

The game overall it has a certain silliness that really brings up a unique charm and personality to it and all characters personalities and traits really makes you get attached to each case and story that you get to solve, the game has a lot of content and different cases/chapters and definitely manages to maintain its consistency on the overall quality, with every case and story having really memorable moments, characters, OSTs, plot twists and well writed storyline and plot.

Definitely the type of game where you wish you could forget everything just to play it all over again.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/787480/Phoenix_Wright_Ace_Attorney_Trilogy/]Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy[/url] is a collection of three visual novel adventure games initially released for the Game Boy Advance by [url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/capcom]CAPCOM[/url] and later updated for various platforms. The trilogy consists of "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney," "Justice for All," and "Trials and Tribulations." The game has received widespread acclaim from both critics and players. Reviewers have praised the compelling storytelling, the well-crafted characters, and the unique blend of adventure and courtroom drama. On platforms like [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/phoenix-wright-ace-attorney-trilogy/]Metacritic[/url], the games have consistently high scores, reflecting their quality and appeal.

The core gameplay is divided into two primary phases: the Investigation Phase and the Courtroom Phase. During the Investigation Phase, players, in the role of defense attorney Phoenix Wright, gather evidence, interview witnesses, and prepare for trial. This phase functions like a point-and-click adventure, where players interact with the environment and dialogue choices to uncover clues. The Courtroom Phase is where the game shines. Players present evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and find inconsistencies in testimonies. This involves carefully listening to statements, choosing when to press for more information, and presenting the right evidence at the right time to expose lies and contradictions.

A significant aspect of the gameplay involves using logic and deduction. Players must think like a lawyer, making connections between pieces of evidence and witness statements to solve the case. The game is heavily character-driven, with a cast of memorable and quirky characters. The interactions between these characters add depth to the story and gameplay.

The Trilogy excels in storytelling. Each case is packed with twists, humor, and drama, keeping players engaged from start to finish. The narrative is compelling, and the episodic nature of the cases makes the game highly addictive. The gameplay requires players to think critically, making it a mentally stimulating experience. The satisfaction of cracking a tough case by piecing together evidence and witness statements is unparalleled. The character development is a standout feature. Phoenix Wright, along with other characters like Maya Fey and Miles Edgeworth, grows throughout the series. This growth adds an emotional depth to the game, making players invested in their journeys. The courtroom battles offer a unique gameplay experience that sets the series apart from other visual novel games. The tension of finding the right evidence to present and the thrill of breaking down a witness's testimony is exceptionally gratifying. The game’s art style is charming, with well-designed characters and environments. The soundtrack is memorable and enhances the mood of both the investigative and courtroom scenes. The game is accessible to newcomers to the genre and offers substantial replay value due to its engaging narrative and character interactions.

In conclusion, "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy" is a masterpiece in the visual novel genre. Its blend of engaging storytelling, challenging puzzles, memorable characters, and unique courtroom gameplay makes it an unforgettable experience. The series has cultivated a passionate fan base. Fans appreciate the memorable characters and storylines, often citing the trilogy as a gateway into the visual novel genre. The games have also had a notable cultural impact, inspiring memes, fan art, and even cosplay, demonstrating the strong connection players feel to the series. Long-time fans of the series have expressed appreciation for the updated graphics and the accessibility of having the first three games in one package. Newcomers have found the trilogy to be an excellent introduction to the series. There's also a sense of nostalgia for players who experienced the original games, as the trilogy brings back fond memories with improved visuals and sound. While overwhelmingly positive, some players have noted the linear nature of the games and the occasional frustration when the game requires a very specific piece of evidence, which can lead to trial-and-error gameplay. However, these critiques are often minor in the broader context of the game's reception. Whether you're a fan of adventure games, a lover of good storytelling, or someone who enjoys intellectual challenges, this trilogy is a must-play.

Hmm... for 11h I was just clicking through dialogues (with an annoying sound). 
Couldn`t find the challenge. 
The only thing 'challenging' was to click on the right object to present it in the cross-examination - often with more luck than knowledge because the game wants you to find just the only - and very only - and right solution (pretty linear). 
Yes, there are different characters and personalities, but there are not very deep. 
(Especially women seem not scripted to be very smart). 
Just not my cup of tea.

This remastered collection improves the dialogue of the English version of the original game. It does not fix all of the typos and errors which is embarrassing. Any basic spellchecker would have tagged the typos when this game was released. It kind of demonstrates how lazy this remaster truly is in my opinion. The art style I believe is worse than the original pixel art. There are some characters (Mia) and poses (Old Von Karma finger wag, angry Edgeworth, some Atmey) that are just ugly and look off. The worst part is that it doesn't fix the problem during the investigation sections that old point and click adventures used to have with there being one solution to advancing and it's not ever obvious what the solution is. It gets compounded in the later games when progressing requires presenting evidence AND profiles to progress investigation. Some logic puzzles are still broken in terms if its actual logic, they didn't bother to fix "plot holes" if you want to call it at, in the remaster. 

I would not recommend this unless you are pretty driven to play this game already. If you're on the fence, annoyances will push you off to stop playing later on.

This is my third time buying this game, of course I recommend this.

I recommend this game to any person that likes puzzles, logic, visual novel or just want to try something new.

The first game in the trilogy might be the one that is the most rough around the edges, but it still holds up, and the case 5 of the first game might be one of my favorite.

The second game (JFA) is where the writing really took off for me, and it also made investigations a LOT better with the introduction of the Magatama. I like Franziska as the prosecutor, and it may have the weakest case (case 3), but it has a kicker final case.

The third game (T&T) is actually amazing, it takes everything you've learned from the two previous games and mix it in the perfect twist and logic that you could see in a game of this type. It ends on the best case the series ever had.

I've completed this game a number of times already on different consoles, and I will most likely play it through again in a year or two, the same way you would re-read a good book or re-watch through a series of movies you've enjoyed (Like Back to the Future that I watch probably every year at this point).

If I've convinced you into trying this game, have fun!

The Step ladder is a self-supporting portable ladder that is non-adjustable in length, with flat steps and a hinged design for ease of storage.  It is intended for use by one person.
Stepladders range in size from 4 ft. to 20 ft. in length along the side rail.  Stepladders shorter than 4 ft. are considered Step Stools.  The highest standing level on a step ladder is slightly more than 2 ft. from the top of the ladder.  The highest standing level is required to be marked on the specifications label on the side rail of the product. Therefore, when planning your job, the maximum work height is established by adding the user's height and reach to the highest standing level of the stepladder.

I know that there are a lot of joke reviews on this website (lol) but I'm going to write up a serious review of the game here for those who are looking for those.

[h1] TRILOGY (AS A COLLECTIVE) [/h1]
There are a number of things consistent throughout the series and aren't exclusive to any of the three games included in this HD remaster. Most of these are not inherently "bad" per se, but are things that you should should be aware of to know what you are getting into. Worth buying on sale.
[list]
    [*]You have to agree to a third party EULA 😔
    [*]This game is a visual novel. You have to click and progress. The game progresses through the dialogue between characters. This can be painful at times (especially during investigation chapters).
    [*]As the story is linear, you should play all the cases in order to understand the background for some key cases.
    [*]Furthermore, due to the dependence on story, this game has almost no replay value.
    [*]This game is meant to be a comedy. It does deliver, in my opinion.
    [*]This game sometimes requires specific evidence or gameplay to unlock achievements. I would recommend having a window open to an achievement guide to make sure you do not miss it, as some cases with achievements are several hours long, and there is nothing worse than replaying a case because you forgot [spoiler] a lunchbox [/spoiler].
    [*]Each case in this game spans from 1 hour up to over 10 -- I would not advise trying to play an entire case in one go.
[/list]

[h1] PHOENIX WRIGHT: ACE ATTORNEY [/h1]
The first game in the series that introduces important characters. I would consider this the best game in the main trilogy, but that is just my opinion. 
[list]
    [*]Most memorable characters are introduced and developed in this game.
    [*]2/5 cases focus on characterisation, 2/5 are meant to be humourous, and 1/5 is a mix of both.
    [*]None of the cases (except maybe the first one, that's a tutorial so it doesn't count) have an expected ending -- you find yourself feeling exactly as Phoenix does throughout.
    [*]Best soundtrack out of all three games. Most famous AA themes come from this game.
[/list]

[h1] Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney – Justice for All [/h1]
Weakest game in the trilogy, as a consequence of being a sequel. Worth playing JUST for the satisfaction of the last case, which had me nervous on the edge of my seat the entire time. Probably the best game in the whole series to date.
[list]
    [*]Two notable characters (Three if you are playing beyond this trilogy) are introduced in this game.
    [*]Most cases are weaker than the first game's ones.
    [*]You solve most cases in this game before Phoenix does. After you solve it mentally, the dialogue feels like hard labour to get through. 
    [*]Soundtrack is good but doesn't hit the same as the last game
    [*]Did I mention the last case?
[/list]

[h1] Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney – Trials and Tribulations [/h1]
Good game, some people consider it the best in the trilogy but I think that depends on how much you enjoy the new characters. 
[list]
    [*]I don't think any cases in this game suck. [spoiler] hold on I forgot about the fanservice-y one that one is annoying for obvious reasons lol [/spoiler]
    [*][spoiler]3/5 cases are linked to each other, [/spoiler]creating an overarching narrative. Interesting to see how they all connect -- everything comes neatly into place at the end. [spoiler]Additionally, there are links to cases in the previous games[/spoiler]
    [*]All cases in this game have some interesting twists and turns that are not similar to the previous two games.
    [*]Soundtrack is also very good, but doesn't hit the same as the first game, as aforementioned.
    [*]Last case is so long. It has a satisfying conclusion, but just might feel too long. I would recommend playing it over several days (or less if you are an epic gamer) because it is exhausting to get through all that dialogue. 
[/list]

[h1] is it worth playing this game? [/h1]
This game is overall an enjoyable experience that I would say holds at least 70-80 hours of gameplay. I do believe that it does appeal to mostly casual gamers, so make a decision on whether a lawyer anime visual novel is truly something you'd enjoy. I don't think it's good enough or cheap enough to buy it off-sale, so just wait for Capcom to inevitably drop another sale of this game -- usually available for at least 50% off.

Three classic games have made their way to PC and they look, sound, and play better than ever. This is the definitive way to experience these three monumental games all in one shiny, luxurious package. These games were to video games what Sherlock Holmes was to detective fiction. They blew open the doors for an entire genre and showed the world what good mystery writing, character writing, and worldbuilding can do to create a truly compelling piece of fiction. At the end of the day, their legacy cannot be overstated, and they must be experienced firsthand for anyone remotely interested in mystery games.

I've always wanted to play the Phoenix Wright games since I've heard they are some of the best games made for the GBA and DS. That being said, I can certainly say that they delivered with wacky courtroom antics/rules and overall story behind each case with interesting characters. This trilogy because of that definitely has me wanting to go and play the other games that were made after this. 

I will say however, I do wish that some quality of life fixes or improvements were brought over with the porting of these games to PC or any other modern console. One big one I was wishing for was maybe some sort of case overview for that specific episode/case that would be a lot better than just the court record. Often enough, there were times I had to take breaks and I would come back with not a full memory of what transpired in the investigation or trial phases. This would result me looking up a guide since I wasn't sure of what happened or just plum forgot. Maybe some sort of improved profile system which would clarify what an individual has said whenever you were talking to them at a given day or trial sort of like a log of everything they've told you about? I also kinda wish we had an improved travel menu for getting to place to place since it's quite tedious with the current one, but it is what it is. 

Overall, if you are looking for a good story based game, this one certainly delivers as stated and really has you think sometimes very hard. Sometimes the rules behind evidence or getting someone to speak is tricky, but despite these frustrations, I quite enjoyed the series and would recommend it highly.

[h1]On with the Desk Slams![/h1]
The Ace Attorney trilogy is one of the most renowned visual novels on the market and -- as I am to prove with the following evidence -- its popularity is justified. 

The hallmark of Ace Attorney games is, of course, the writing. Clever and saturated with idioms and wordplay, the text mimics the way people think and talk to minute details -- onomatopoeia and interjections included. While a slog at times, especially when reading through parts already experienced, the pace is usually brisk. It is important to pay attention to every line of text, as every utterance had been written with purpose, to strike a point or deliver a punchline. Many lines have a setup that pays off long after they are mentioned -- paying attention thus feels rewarding.

Characters deserve its own category -- they are incredibly varied. Though caricatures in an absurd, fantasy universe, they behave logically: they stay true to their beliefs, their reasoning and motivations are believable, may they be a sister from a mountain temple or a prodigical prosecutor. It is fun to unearth who and why holds a grudge, whether a person had been an accomplice to something, or what they are secretly plotting.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3060868390

With the novel's old-school flair and over-the-top characters, reading through a case may well be fun even for those who typically prefer action-oriented gameplay over stories. Abundance of animations, sprite variants, and clever uses of the game engine almost make one feel as if though they were watching an anime. Because progression is achieved through examinations and making use of evidence, Lotta engagement is involved. Though alternating between two modes adds variety and obviates staleness, longer chapters typically require more than one session due to exhaustion.

This brings us to several technical issues, or rather annoyances, which I take with the game: The option menu is severely lacking, text cannot be neither backtracked nor played automatically, and the number of save slots is insufficient. Most egregiously, it is impossible to mute text effects without muting all other sound effects. 

Soundtrack, however, is on point. Spanning over one hundred lively, electrical tracks, the albums endue the trilogy with its trademark charm.

What more is there to say then, other than that Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney is one of the best, classic visual novels on the market? If you decide to dive into it, you are in for a lot of jokes, murderous surprises, emotional twists, overly dramatic gestures, and best of all… objections!

In all seriousness, this game did so much for me. I was in a really awful place mentally before I got this game. I had no motivation to do anything and nothing to look forward to. Then, I discovered this game. Technically I was already aware of it. I knew it existed, and that it was about some silly blue lawyer. It wasn't until I saw someone play it that I had the desire to play it myself. So, I put it on my wish list and bought it as soon as It went on sale.
Suddenly I had something to look forward to every day after school. Not only that but the characters were endearing, and fun, but most off all relatable. I got particularly attached to Franziska and Maya, and their stories and issues. It was comforting to have characters I could relate to. 
Ace Attorney didn't cure all my issues, it didn't just make them go away, but it did help. It helped pull me out of that awful depressive episode, and I couldn't be more grateful.

TLDR:  Excellent writing can't save lawyer narrative game from bland playstyle.

I enjoy narrative games, like the ones made by Telltale. Someone suggested to me that I try this one and seeing it was highly rated, I figured I'd give it a shot.

At its heart, Phoenix Wright is a puzzle/logic game. Phoenix is the titular character, a rookie defense attorney who quickly assumes control of his own law firm. Gameplay circles around Wright's efforts to defend his clients and unravel criminal conspiracies. Interface is mostly through mouse/hotkey use, though a few puzzles involve using keys/sticks to rotate objects. The "cases" involve two major phases, which are sometimes repeated over several days, of investigation (where PW questions witnesses and searches crime scenes for evidence) and the courtroom, which involves cross-examining witnesses and presenting evidence found during investigation.

Up front, I'll say the storytelling in this game drew me in. While the dialogue was middling, the plots themselves were often intricate and nuanced, and went down roads I wasn't expecting. PW develops his confidence across cases and has a pretty good character arc. Relations with recurring characters--notably prosecutor Miles Edgeworth--is multi-dimensional and again, basically well-written. If I end up going further, it will be just for the stories. (Edit: I ended up finishing, just to see how it played out, and I was disappointed. Compared to the first two parts of the trilogy, the story in Trials and Tribulations is a jumbled mess that just didn't work for me, which is a shame.)

The courtroom interactions are mostly fun, with objections and counter-objections being thrown around. Prosecutors and witnesses will often sabotage PW's strategies, forcing the player to keep thinking. All I can tell players is to pay attention to everything that is said and pore over every piece of evidence. Nothing is timed, so don't feel rushed; stop and think things through. There is no penalty for pressing the witness, to try and wiggle lose more incriminating evidence or get them to lose their cool. Using evidence to object, however, can ding PW's rep with the judge if incorrect ... and if the judge loses his patience, he'll declare against the player, sending you back to the main menu (or latest save) to do it again. So present evidence with caution. PW's sidekick characters will often drop hints, which can help if you're stuck.

Sadly, the other half of the game--the investigations phase--is mostly clunky, boring, and repetitive. In many of the cases, it involves slowly traversing the various areas (which means backtracking over and over), exhausting the speech options of characters/witnesses present, and presenting evidence to spur their memories. Much of it is counter-intuitive and guesswork, and it all grows old very quickly. You cannot advance without collecting all required evidence--which makes sense, in a way, as you need it to win (see below). I absolutely detested wading through these screens again and again, trying to find the one thing I'd overlooked in order to advance the story.

Also, I think the humor will be hit and miss for players. Some landed for me but not all. If you're not into "zany" humor, this might fall flat.

And while I enjoyed the courtroom drama, at times the events are too far-fetched, even for this level of story. Specific instances are so far over the top--like prosecutors  and witnesses openly threatening or hitting people in a packed court--that I rolled my eyes a lot. Worse, it felt like so much was there just to stonewall obvious, and effective, points of defense by the player. Getting the defendant cleared on a technicality, such as the prosecution withholding key evidence or tampering with witnesses (which happens in almost every case in the game), should still count as a win, right? Not here. This is why you had to collect all evidence in the previous phase, because there is only one way to win. Thinking outside the box is necessary to find a solution ... but only the *correct* solution.

Back on the plus side, the game was stable, installed fast, and ran well. I didn't have any glitches or crashes. The minimalist, cartoonish art style plays right into the game's tone, and I laughed at some of the comic anime-esque character reactions. The sound is solid but the repetitive nature of the effects made me mute the game after a while.

The bulk of Steam Achievements look as though they will come naturally in gameplay, though a few are miss-able, so guides out, if you want to get them all the first time through.

I told myself I'd get about halfway through before writing this, to see if my opinion changed. I did get halfway, barely (I botched the final trial of the first game in the trilogy twice before winning). I see the appeal of Phoenix Wright, from the engaging stories, to some of the meme-worthy expressions. But after churning halfway through, I can sum up my feelings by saying, "Meh."

Pros
- Immersive, well-written stories
- Decent, multi-layered puzzle action in courtroom sequences

Cons
- Boring and frustrating investigation sequences
- Outlandish characters grow annoying or even cringeworthy
- Narrow paths to advance or win cases

Final Score: 5/10

---[2023]---------------
Ace Attorney is great. I've played a few cases each year ever since I started learning Japanese, and it's always great fun to come back to Naruhodo & Co and their antics (and with each year, it gets *that* much easier to follow along!)

A brilliant v-novel, that's what it is. At this point, I get so deep into the murder mystery aspect that I forget that it's in Japanese... that is, until you get to one of the super weird roadblock moments. Peeking at guides and seeing the weirdest english-i-fied names is super weird (Itonoko is [i]Gumboot???[/i])

->For those interested in playing 逆転裁判 in JP:
There's no furigana, and the vocab can be difficult at times. On the other hand, there's no time limit, each セリフ is pretty short, and you can gleam so much from the context that playing and understanding this game becomes at least "doable" within a... reasonable time period. The first time I tried (@6months) I got absolutely nowhere. At ~18 months it got doable with a lot of effort. And now, at 2 years, it's... still a challenge. That's not unexpected. These characters are treasures troves of yakuwarigo to an extent I have yet to find in the books I've read or movies I've watched. You could write a sociolinguistics paper on virtually every sentence that O-kyou says. That's part of the pull, isn't it? The challenge that drives you forward. ... Good luck.

Alright, did I pick this game up during the 2020 Steam Summer Sale play all of the first game and half of the second game just to not play it again until the Summer of this year 2023... Yes I did.

However don't let goofy fact about my experience deter you from playing this phenomenal collection. The music the stories and the characters are the best parts of this game. I enjoyed solving the cases and contradictions and rarely had times I needed to look stuff up, and let me tell you the satisfaction of thinking about how the evidence can help your case and it actually being right was great! The final case in the third game was the best case with amazing twists and turns every second something felt like it was going your way.

This game will always find a way to make you laugh and smile and that is just another reason as to why this game collection means so much to me. I love it so much that, one day I can't wait to replay this wonderful title in all of its glory!

I just learned that Apollo Justice Trilogy will make it's way to Consoles and PC very soon. So I decided to pick this up for collection's sake.

The first visual novel I ever played, I've played the original trilogy back on the DS (over 10 years ago). I replayed the trilogy again in 2019 on the Nintendo Switch and still enjoyed it. And once again booting up the game again after some years, the same wave of nostalgia hits hard. I just got this to add to my Steam library, but looks like I will be completing this game for a third time lol. Nothing beats Phoenix's iconic "Objection!" and "Take that!". Never gets old.

I don't often re-read visual novels, but this one is just that good. The same goofy characters, fantastic soundtrack, and the polished artwork is just as I remember it. There is something to enjoy about the story even after multiple playthroughs. It's around 50+ hours to complete all three. If there's any PW game you should play, it's the three in this Trilogy. This Trilogy is peak Phoenix Wright as I know it, and is required to play before even playing Apollo Justice.

Some only bad thing I can say but I'm just nit-picking at this point.
1: you don't have the liberty to make a million saves like you can with a traditional VN
2: there is no chat log, so sometimes you may accidentally skip over important dialogue that can't be seen again
3: sometimes it's difficult to figure out how to progress the story without a guide (even after many playthroughs) because you need to find that one item to present.

--This Review is solely for my experience of the series/franchise, and not the port--

The music, the visuals for its time, the characters, the character development, the character designs, and the plot progression are nothing short of perfect. Phoenix Wright's Ace Attorney Trilogy completely reignites the passion of the boring everyday courtrooms you see in real life into a dramatic, high-octane court case filled with timeless twists that will catch you off guard no matter how much you think you grasp the situation! Play the game first if you genuinely want the bonafide Ace Attorney experience. Don't start with the anime, as the charm of many things in this franchise is YOU figuring out the mysteries as Phoenix Wright.

It's tough to believe this game was developed so long ago, as its plots still rival any works you may see today. Besides a few references, this game does not feel out of date at all, even today!

Even if you may not be into the broader choice of visual novels, this is one of those games that anyone can get into if they appreciate solving mysteries and seeing through the eyes of Phoenix Wright, a rookie lawyer, as he uncovers the truth of a variety of well thought out murders against prosecutors that are just as amazing in how their roles are played in the court. With ace attorney comes a variety of lessons, morals, and sections where you can empathize with the characters involved and their motives for doing certain things.

Warning that Ace Attorney may not realistically portray the courtroom, defense attorneys, or prosecutors that we have in real life; however, it does paint a story, the journey of what being a lawyer means. A lawyer is still a human, and humans are bound to make mistakes. However, the courtroom is not a room of perfection but a room of justice and truth. Ace attorney clarifies that a clean win record means nothing if the whole truth is not found.

I recommend this game to anyone who loves the mystery genre with a bit of supernatural mixed into it. It may take some time to get used to for it to impact you as it has me, but it is worth it for what you'll end up witnessing and experiencing with this masterpiece of a game, a roller coaster of emotions. Buckle up as you are invited into the insane world of Phoenix Wright, uncovering mysteries and defending clients as both detective (figuratively) and Defense Attorney (literally) alike. You may need to find out what you find next.

My only regret is that I did not play this game sooner. You do find yourself feeling short of content like me when I wanted more; however, I also have to admit that everything was neatly wrapped up with the third game. I felt immersed in the world and its characters, so much so that I wanted to experience it again. There truly is nothing like this game and franchise around that can have the same impact it had on me when I first clicked on the 'play now' button.

Plots, characters, dialogues are great.

However, I find the cross-examination is somewhat arbitrary. Both the `press` and `present` system.

You can see clear contradictions between testimonies and evidences and got penalised for presenting them, just because it was not the time the devs intend yet.

I have to look at  a walkthrough more time than I would like, and often the steps I need to take is not make sense to me like press on a statement that is not at all suspicious just to get another key dialogue.

I just think that given how arbitrary it is, it would be good if you can select an option to just turn the penalised limit off.

Still enjoy the story though, the judge make me laugh multiple time when the lunch lady is on trial.

I think I might just `press` on every statement and see the walkthrough on what contradiction devs intend rather than try to solve the "puzzle".

I can't emphasize enough just how much I adore these games and the profound impact they've had on my life. They've been a wellspring of inspiration, enlightenment, and transformation for me! I used to create Phoenix Wrongs, which were animated and video-based comedy sketch parody videos inspired by the series. It was an absolute blast, and the Ace Attorney fanbase is truly one of a kind.

This series boasts some exceptional music, unforgettable and endearing characters, a perfect blend of humor, and writing that can take you on a whirlwind journey from heartwrenching and emotional to bittersweet and even tragically poignant moments. It's an absolute rollercoaster of emotions, and I can honestly say that I've never regretted a single moment I've spent immersed in this incredible series. It continues to captivate me to this very day!

[b] [i]> Be me, detective game enthusiast
> Hear about the Ace Attorney Trilogy, decide to give it a whirl
> Start the game, meet Phoenix Wright
> "Objection!" intensifies
> Realize that in the Ace Attorney world, "OBJECTION!" is the equivalent of "Hello"
> Begin yelling "OBJECTION!" at my cat, at the TV, at my reflection in the mirror
> Realize I may need to see a therapist
> Move on to investigate crime scenes
> Click on EVERYTHING
> "There's nothing of interest here." Every. Single. Time.
> Realize I'm basically a modern-day Sherlock Holmes, minus the genius part
> Meet Maya, the "spiritual" sidekick
> Realize she's one step away from summoning ghosts to testify in court
> Start wondering if she could summon my ex to testify about why she left me
> Become deeply invested in the most mundane court cases ever
> Spend hours cross-examining parrots and thinking it's perfectly normal
> Present irrelevant evidence, just to see Phoenix's over-the-top reactions
> "Take that!" *slams random object on the courtroom desk*
> Judge doesn't even flinch anymore
> Get the feeling the entire courtroom is used to Phoenix's shenanigans
> Face off against prosecutors who have the courtroom presence of WWE wrestlers
> Wonder if this is what real courtrooms are like
> Begin to suspect that being a lawyer involves a lot more yelling and dramatic finger-pointing than I originally thought
> Ace Attorney Logic: "If I just shout 'OBJECTION!' enough times, the truth will reveal itself"
> Actually works
> Feel like a legal mastermind
> Realize I've been playing for 10 hours straight and it's 3 AM
> Wonder if I should become a lawyer in real life
> Wake up with a new career plan, but realize I still can't present evidence to prove I'm responsible enough
> Ace Attorney Trilogy: 10/10 would shout "OBJECTION!" again
 [/i] [/b]

In the world of law and legal lore,
There's a trilogy we all adore.
Ace Attorney, Phoenix's quest,
In pixelated suits, he's dressed.

In courtrooms filled with wacky tales,
Where logic and absurdity set sails,
Phoenix Wright, the defense's star,
Takes on cases bizarre, no matter how far.

With Maya by his side, a spirit so bold,
Their bond is worth more than gold.
Together they face the strangest of crimes,
In this world where justice oftentimes rhymes.

From Steel Samurai to Turnabout Sisters,
Each case, a puzzle that twisters and twisters.
The characters are quirky, their antics are wild,
From Gumshoe's blunders to Edgeworth, so mild.

OBJECTIONs fly like confetti in the air,
As the truth is sought with determined flair.
The Judge, forever clueless it seems,
Adds to the game's comedic dreams.

From Larry's love life, always a mess,
To Mia's mentorship, a guiding caress.
We laugh, we cry, we shout, "Hold it!"
In the world of Ace Attorney, we're always in it.

So here's to Phoenix and his legal parade,
In this trilogy, our hearts are swayed.
With humor, heart, and cases so grand,
Ace Attorney, you truly understand.

Through pixelated screens, you make us cheer,
For a game so funny, endearing, and dear.
With OBJECTIONs loud and justice in sight,
Ace Attorney Trilogy, you shine so bright!

[i] [Scene: A beautiful wedding ceremony in progress. Phoenix and Maya are standing at the altar, about to exchange vows. Miles Edgeworth is sitting in the audience.]

Judge (Officiant): Dearly beloved, we are gathered here today to celebrate the union of Phoenix Wright and Maya Fey in holy matrimony.

[Phoenix and Maya exchange loving glances.]

Judge (Officiant): If anyone here has any reason why these two should not be joined in marriage, speak now or forever hold your peace.

[Miles Edgeworth stands up abruptly.]

Miles Edgeworth: OBJECTION!

[Gasps from the guests. Maya looks shocked. Phoenix facepalms.]

Phoenix Wright (whispering): Not again, Edgeworth!

Maya Fey (whispering): Seriously, Edgeworth? Now?

Judge (Officiant): Mr. Edgeworth, you cannot object at a wedding without a valid reason.

Miles Edgeworth (blushing): My apologies, Your Honor. Force of habit.

[The guests chuckle nervously.]

Judge (Officiant): Very well, please take your seat.

[Miles Edgeworth sits down, looking embarrassed.]

[The ceremony continues.]

Judge (Officiant): Now, if Phoenix and Maya have prepared their own vows, they may exchange them.

[Phoenix takes a deep breath and starts reciting his vows.]

Phoenix Wright: Maya, from the moment I met you, you brought light into my life. You've been my rock, my support, and my joy. I promise to love and cherish you for as long as I live.

[Miles Edgeworth starts to stand up again.]

Phoenix Wright (panicking, whispering): No, Edgeworth, don't!

[Maya grabs Edgeworth by the arm and pulls him back down.]

Maya Fey (whispering): Stay seated, Edgeworth!

[Miles Edgeworth sits down, grumbling.]

[Phoenix continues with his vows.]

Phoenix Wright: I promise to be with you through the good times and the bad, and to never rest until I've found the truth in your heart.

[Maya smiles and wipes away a tear.]

Maya Fey: Phoenix, you're the Ace Attorney of my heart, and I promise to bring the spirit of the courtroom into our everyday lives. I'll even let you win objections sometimes.

[The guests laugh.]

Judge (Officiant): By the power vested in me, I now pronounce you husband and wife. You may kiss the bride.

[Phoenix and Maya share a passionate kiss.]

[Miles Edgeworth can't help himself.]

Miles Edgeworth: OBJECTION!

[Phoenix and Maya break their kiss, looking exasperated.]

Phoenix Wright (frustrated): Edgeworth, seriously?

Miles Edgeworth: My apologies again. I just can't help myself.

[The guests burst into laughter, and Phoenix and Maya finally share their first official married kiss.]

[End scene.]

In the world of Ace Attorney, even weddings are filled with objections! [/i]

So, I've had my eye on the AA Trilogy for awhile now and I've only ever heard great things, but I was never really been a big visual novel/point+click fan, so I waited forever to sink the 30 bucks. I just bought the game last night and spent near the entirety of my Sunday sinking 10 hours into it in almost one sitting. From the very beginning everything about it has been amazing. The very first thing I noticed was the music, which was a straight up bop and It had me dancing in my chair at 7:30 in the morning. The story is both edge-of-your-seat exciting and slapstick hilarious, with ridiculous characters that make me belly laugh. I loved April May as a witness. The general gameplay isn't bad, but it can be tedious especially in more difficult trial sections where you need to chain it seems like endless amounts of dialogue "presses" in exactly the right order to get the desired outcome, but apart from that I've been loving it. Definitely glad I finally decided to pick it up, and totally worth the $30 if you're like me and just not quite sure if you want to dump the cash on it.

Lawyer: Your Honor, if the court would indulge me, I'd like to call the witness to the stand to provide their testimony on the matter of the "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy."

Witness: Certainly, Your Honor. I'm here to share my thoughts on this remarkable game.

Lawyer: Now, Witness, could you please describe your experience with the "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy"?

Witness: Well, as a player, I found it to be an exceptional video game experience. The storytelling is second to none. It's like being immersed in a gripping courtroom drama, Your Honor. The way the cases unfold, the characters' development, it's all meticulously crafted.

Lawyer: Meticulously crafted, you say? Could you elaborate on that, Witness?

Witness: Certainly, Your Honor. The evidence, the testimonies, and the way the player must piece together the truth—it's like presenting a legal case in a court of law. It requires critical thinking, attention to detail, and a keen sense of logic, much like the skills required of an attorney.

Lawyer: Fascinating. And how about the characters in the game, Witness?

Witness: The characters are incredibly well-developed, Your Honor. They have distinct personalities and motives that come into play during the trials. It's like witnessing the dynamics between lawyers, witnesses, and judges in real-life courtrooms. You become emotionally invested in their stories.

Lawyer: Emotionally invested, you say? That's quite intriguing. How about the game's music and presentation?

Witness: The music is exceptional, Your Honor. It sets the tone perfectly, just like the atmosphere in a courtroom. It enhances the drama and immerses you in the proceedings. The visual style, too, complements the game's themes and narratives.

Lawyer: Thank you, Witness. Your insights into the game's storytelling, characters, and presentation are quite enlightening. In your opinion, would you recommend the "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy" to others?

Witness: Absolutely, Your Honor. If you have an appreciation for intricate storytelling, engaging characters, and the thrill of a courtroom drama, this game is a must-play. It provides a unique and immersive experience that is both intellectually stimulating and emotionally satisfying.

Lawyer: Your testimony is duly noted, Witness. I believe your perspective on the "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy" sheds light on its merits as an exceptional video game. Thank you for your insights.

Witness: It's been my pleasure, Your Honor. I hope my testimony aids the court in understanding the value of this extraordinary game.
