I LOVE the Ace Attorney games - every single one of them. They're my childhood and a nostalgic escape in my adulthood, I have racked up thousands of hours playing them all through more than thrice on my Nintendo DS...but when it comes to the Steam version of these games I have one solid reason for not recommending. 

Part of the gameplay is to search for evidence in crime scenes. In the original Nintendo platform versions, this manifests as a red target cursor that you move around the screen and click on things (anything you want) in view on your screen. If you click on useless items, you'll get useless answers. If you click on useful items, you'll get useful advice. You've no idea what to click on sometimes, you have to make links between what you know in your head which leads you to look for the right item to click on. OR you can mindlessly click till you find the right answer - your choice in the end. Part of the fun is not knowing what to do sometimes, scrounging around with frustration until you finally get it right and then it all falls into place. 

HOWEVER, in the Steam version of the games, this part of the gameplay has been changed. 'Useful items' (or at least items with unique dialogue) in every crime scene you're supposed to search for evidence has been flagged with a magnifying glass. 

Now I know to most people, this won't seem like a big deal and to other they may actually prefer it at first glance (as I did initially) but here's why I now despise the choice to do this:

Flagging all the useful items you're supposed to click in each scene completely removes any investigative aspect of the gameplay and reduces this portion of the games to nothing more than a click through story. This is NOT what the original games were about. Now I know that Ace Attorney is the kind of game where you do have to find the right move to progress and yes it can funnel you a bit. And yes, I get that you could just mindlessly click around till you finally clicked on the right item and could move on with the story but you had a choice - this is my point. You could try and make connections in your head and search the scene for items that looked interesting - even useless items you clicked on could sometime trigger hilarious exchanges between the characters. And because of the opportunity for fun dialogue, it was fun to struggle to find the answer (whether you were trying to work it out or not). 

Flagging all the points of interest right up front COMPLETELY DESTROYS this aspect of the game. I couldn't even get through the first actual game because I was so bored. Flagging points of interest up front does actually make a difference. I don't care if in the end I can click mindlessly till I land on the right thing, I want to feel like an attorney playing detective. I enjoyed clicking on things I thought were relevant but turned out were just scenery because that's part of the detective work. Sure you can choose to 'ignore' the flags, but that's like handing someone an answer sheet that's always in front of your and saying you can choose not to look at it. It.makes.a.difference.

Not to mention, flagging everything worth clicking on reduces the instinct to look around at the actual visuals - no it's not a Greek tapestry but it's still fun enjoyable visual content that you just end up not bothering to look at and enjoy because you're drawn to the 'right answers'. Part of investigating the scenes in AA is looking around for clues. Not just looking through pre-approved clues like you're ticking boxes off a list.

I'm bitter about this I know.

So if that aspect of gameplay is important to you, save your money unless it gets heavily discounted, you might still enjoy it for the plots and banter (which are of course still excellent). Otherwise, consider buying a DS and playing the original Nintendo versions it's way more enjoyable in my opinion.

As long as you have a walkthrough on hand, this is a fantastic time. My only complaint is the strike system; if you present wrong evidence enough times, you'll "lose" and be forced all the way back to the main menu, where you have to then reload from the last save. If you're 90% of the way through the case and make a mistake? Tough luck kiddo, gotta replay EVERYTHING from the start of the trial.

Otherwise, this is a gem of an experience. Funny dialogue, quirky interactions, and every now and then you'll get that A-HA! moment that makes you feel like a genius.

I liked this game a lot! I think it's probably my favourite mystery game I've ever played. Here are some positives about the game:

 - The atmosphere struck a perfect balance between lighthearted humour, intense battles of deduction, and heartfelt moments. I think the soundtrack contributed a lot to this. Upon first hearing the soundtrack, it didn't sound like anything special, but after playing through the game, each theme became associated with the emotions of the moments when it played. 

 - The twists in this game are well-written. It is a mystery game and twists are expected, so many times I was able to piece things together ahead of time. However, it doesn't detract at all from the emotional impact when the truth is revealed. Even if you figure out the who and how of a case, the really juicy, emotional details of why are left until the end. In fact, I've found that being able to solve the whodunnit ahead of time increases my immersion and makes me feel smarter for having puzzled out the answer alongside the characters.

 - The characters are well written and memorable. Every character has their memorable quirks of character design and personality. I never feel that the writing of any character is too shallow, because the trial always reveals complexity in even the side characters. The motivation of every character is believable, and is consistent to their characterisation. Central characters like Phoenix and Edgeworth are given satisfying character development arcs.

 - The story is creative and well-structured. Although there are some tropes of the mystery genre that this game relies upon, overall the stories are refreshing and unexpected. The story has an episodic structure, but there are still overarching mysteries that are slowly revealed. The finale is satisfying and ties up all the loose ends cleanly.

Here is my singular negative about the game:

 - The game can be very particular about which pieces of evidence you have to present first and which dialogues you have to unlock. Even if you've figured out the contradiction already, you can't arrive at the conclusion until the game says that you can.

 Overall, I had a really positive experience with this game. I hope you play it and enjoy it!

It's a great thing that these games are available stateside. That said, much of what happens in this game is VERY Japan. There are some extremely bizarre characters and highly unusual story lines. If that's your thing then you will very likely love this game. The game is very long. If it's your first time playing these games you can expect to spend 60-80 hours on a full play through. As far as replay value goes, the game is very low on it. You may do a second play through to pick up specific achievements, but all of them can be obtained on your first run. The cases can be intricate and some of them require a lot of thought on your part. That said, some of them can also be very long winded and can start to feel like a chore. I think it's worth picking up if you're fan of visual novels, investigations, and puzzles.

Years have flowed like legal arguments since the Ace Attorney Trilogy first graced the DS system, yet its foundation remains unshaken—a true testament to its timeless charm. So, if you find yourself wandering through these lines, grasp your metaphorical legal briefcase, proudly pin that attorney badge, and set forth on an expedition toward justice—one ladder, or dare I say, one stepladder at a time.

And if you've journeyed this far, you've earned an extra quirky challenge! March over to your nearest window, peer out at the unsuspecting world beyond, and with the conviction of a courtroom ace, let loose a resounding 'TAKE THAT!' at your nearest neighbor.

It's such a popular game for its worth and while I write this the game has %97 positive reviews in steam. I also have to mention that I played 4th, 5th, 6th and now near the end of the 2nd after 1st game. I'm not a quitter so I kinda stuck but seriously in a shortest way I could sum up is, the games are nonsensical and chore to play. I can't believe of its popularity against other mystery or detective games. 

Between trials you try to move around menu driven locations and to move the game forward you have to go specific places sometimes. So you get stuck sometimes because of it, not much of a sense in these specific places. To make it worse, most places have sub locations so you cant see them all in a bigger list. So you have to click back and forth to progress in game. I mean it is ridicilous, no person would enjoy these parts.

Trials are where the game is at but there are times you have to make such leaps of logic, you start to click things and hope for the best. Savescumming is a must as I see it. But I cant hold this problem much more than this, the game is about Wright's bluffs and fluffs for his dear life. It's very child friendly and also childlike, so no need say more. Most lines, animations, twists are nonsensical and it is what it is. Whole series is like that.

The main gripe of mine is metaphysical subjects in all the games in the series. [spoiler]All cases are about low probability events, closed room style weird machinations, good old luck or unluck. All events are somehow realistic. And you have to jump hoops to reveal them. All good and fine. Ah, also there is dead man spirits and people that channel them. Also these channelings change the physical appearance of said mediums. You can see peoples lies like some sort of locks and chains. In every game there were such things, I wont list them all. And most important part is all these metaphysical things exist in the game world and they are OK. No one bats an eye. Cases you say? Nah man, there aren't metaphysical thing to explain the murder. It's just not real, OK! Move along you fraud of an attorney. [/spoiler]

I'm very well aware that I sound very mad.  But I gotta say I can't recommend this game to anyone. There are very good mystery/detective/whodidit games and visual novels out there. This series are not one of them.

I grew up with a Nintendo DS, and Pheonix Wright: Ace Attorney was one of my favorite DS game series that I ever played, and I can say without a doubt that there's a reason I loved this series so much as a kid. The Pheonix Wright trilogy definitely stands up to scrutiny, unlike 100% of the witness testimonies within the game. These games are really good in depth visual novel mystery games, and the closest comparison I could make would be the Danganronpa games. But it is within that role that these games excel- the characters they create, the stories they tell, and even their limited (compared to non-visual novel games) gameplay make them very much worth playing.

I'll review the three games contained within this trilogy pack, but before I talk about what I like about them, I need to discuss their (in my opinion at least) only real flaw: the overly complex hoops that the player has to jump through when attempting to answer questions or point out contradictions in people's testimonies. Sometimes, in order to point out a contradiction, you need to present evidence that contradicts a statement, but the court record will contain multiple pieces of evidence that could be used to point out this contradiction, and you will be penalized if you choose the wrong one. Or, a witness in the courtroom might make two similar statements that you know contradict your evidence, but only one of them is the statement that you're supposed to object to, etc etc. This can sometimes result in a frustrating experience, especially during some of the more complex episodes in each game. However, thankfully the game has an incredibly forgiving save/load system, and as such, while this issue can sometimes be frustrating, it ultimately doesn't detract too much from the experience, and I still found the games worth playing.

Pheonix Wright: Ace Attorney is the first entry in the trilogy and indeed in the entire series, and is without a doubt the best of the three overall. It establishes a very simple but reliable gameplay formula, tells entertaining and compelling stories, and fully establishes the world of Pheonix Wright, and as such is a very solid experience. At least, I can say that for the original four episodes in this game, which were all that the game came with when originally released for the Gameboy Advance in Japan. When the game was ported to the Nintendo DS and translated for English-speaking audiences, a fifth episode was added, and while it tells one of the best stories in the entire trilogy and adds fun new gameplay mechanics to the already established formula from the other four episodes, unfortunately the gameplay within the courtroom falls apart a little in this episode. It's here that the issue I mentioned earlier with the Pheonix Wright games really starts to appear, especially since this episode has one of the most complex plots of any in the trilogy. However, I still very much enjoyed this episode, especially for the new mechanics it made use of, and found the characters to be highly compelling, so i don't think it detracts from the experience too much.

Pheonix Wright: Justice For All is an interesting game, as it was the only one of the trilogy that I never actually played when I was younger. As such, I was excited to find that I had no idea what the stories would be. Unfortunately, this game turned out to be my least favorite of the three. I don't believe this was due to the lack of prior experience with the game or the nostalgia factor, but I also could be biased as well, so take my opinion on this one with a grain of salt. I'll start off with the positives about this one: It introduces a completely new mechanic that really adds to the investigation portion of the experience: Psychelocks, which are opportunities to expose lies from witnesses outside of the courtroom and gain information. This really helps make the player more invested in the investigation portion of the game, and adds to the overall gameplay experience as well. In addition, the game introduces a lot of great characters, themes and plotlines that are very important to the third game in the trilogy, which is my personal favorite.
Unfortunately, this game also contains some of the worst episodes/stories in the entire trilogy, which are bogged down by overly complex paths the player has to take, confusing justifications for which evidence to use or which statement to press, and (worst of all, in my opinion) recycled plot outlines. For example, the first episode in this game involves someone accused of murdering their lover, but is actually [spoiler]being framed by a conman[/spoiler]- which is basically the exact plot of the first episode in the first game. This might sound like an isolated incident, but most of the other episodes all essentially boil down to plots from the previous game. The second episode again involves [spoiler]Maya being framed for a murder[/spoiler] and the final episode recycles so many characters and is again about [spoiler]an actor from a kids samurai show supposedly killing another fellow actor from a kids samurai show[/spoiler]. 
It's unfortunate, too, because the specifics of these episodes are (in some of them, particularly the fourth episode) actually pretty interesting, but that's overshadowed by the recycled characters and plotlines, as well as the fact that this game suffers from the complex hoops issue more than any of the other two games; in particular, the third episode with the Big Top Circus being the worst offender. That episode is honestly my personal contender for worst in the series; the plot is semi interesting, but the characters introduced are mostly annoying, and both the steps required to progress the investigation and the actions required in the courtroom are vague and overly complicated at the same time, requiring you to do things in a specific order without offering much guidance for what order to do them. All of this to say, while this game is valuable to the series as a whole, has some of it's own merits, and isn't really a bad game, it's the entry in the trilogy that I have the most issues with and enjoyed the least.

The final entry in the trilogy, and my personal favorite, is Pheonix Wright: Trials and Tribulations. While as a game it has more of the complexity issue than the first game, it makes up for this with far more interesting plotlines (in my opinion) and maintains the new mechanics and fun characters from the previous game, while also introducing entirely new characters and plotlines. It also managed to completely remove the more annoying recurring characters from the previous games (such as a certain [spoiler]windbag who was a chore to talk to due to her completely unnecessary and long winded dialogue[/spoiler], and a completely [spoiler]inept photographer who somehow managed to make a return appearance in not one, but TWO episodes in the previous game[/spoiler]), which I found to be refreshing. While there are one or two very minor plot points that are recycled, thankfully these matter very little to the plot of each episode, and are overshadowed by the really in depth and interesting plots also found in those episodes. Overall, Trials and Tribulations manages to return to the interesting storytelling of the first game, and also perfects the complexity of narrative and new mechanics found in the second game while simultaneously avoiding almost all of that same games pitfalls. It also has my personal favorite episode in the entire series, found in episode 5, which I feel is honestly the overall best episode in the entire series, outside of maybe the fourth episode of the first game.

Overall, I would absolutely recommend the Pheonix Wright games to anyone who enjoys a good courtroom drama, mystery, or visual novel in general, and while the games are not perfect (in particular the second game, Pheonix Wright: Justice For All), I think these games are great experiences and honestly some of my favorite games I've ever played.

[This is a spoiler-free review that covers how the game works and the experience you have in store for you as vaguely as possible.]

This game is awesome.

Obviously, you play as a defense lawyer, and it's not just one game, but a collection of the games in the Ace Attorney series that center around Phoenix Wright. You build your case by examining crime scenes, collecting evidence, and talking to people, which includes presenting evidence to them to see what they know about it. Despite all this investigating, you nearly always go into trial without a solid idea of how to prove your client is innocent. Every case is a constant struggle where you're struggling to stay afloat by finding cracks in the testimonies and evidence presented. Doing so gradually reveals the truth, exposing the real culprit of the crime in question and what actually went down. This makes for some really good twists that really caught me off guard in some cases. Even when you have a good idea of who the killer actually is (as in the first cases of games, which serve as a sort of tutorial), getting to the point of proving it by finding out what really happened is a great and entertaining mystery in itself. The game has a good sense of atmosphere (as much as a visual novel can have) and has exciting, actually good music that changes and intensifies as you get closer to the truth and witnesses get more and more nervous. The sense of justice you feel after clawing your way to victory and exposing liars and corruption is rewarding, especially with the excessive animations of characters breaking down when you corner them for good. This release also has achievements for pursuing additional conversations and other content not required to win the case as fast as possible, which is a nice addition to further incentivize seeking these things out.

The characters in the game are a big part of its appeal as well. They all have distinct personalities and designs, and their interactions add a lot to the investigation process. Many characters are recurring, and there are fun recurring bits as well, such as Edgeworth not being able to get his witnesses to state their names and professions, or Gumshoe getting his salary cut. The cases are chronologically ordered, and a general overarching narrative based on relationships between the characters develops. This doesn't always impact the facts of the cases themselves, but influences how characters interact with each other within new cases as you get further along. Most recurring characters demonstrate character development to some degree as well, as their opinions or situations change as the series progresses. This excludes the judge, who basically just agrees with the last decently logical line of thinking he heard and is a hilarious character representing everything a judge should not be. Thankfully, you (and sometimes the prosecution) are thorough and provide enough evidence that the judge doesn't really have to make a decision. 

The only real criticism I have is that the game is pretty linear, which results in you not being able to utilize things you noticed immediately. This isn't necessarily a bad thing since the story is entertaining and you can in fact fail and lose the case, but if you notice a contradiction in the evidence before the game prompts you to point it out, you are left waiting to do so or suffer a penalty for trying to present the contradiction when that's not what the game wants. From the case progression and what the characters are talking about before your choice, however, it is fairly obvious what the question at hand is and you can avoid selecting evidence at the wrong time easily. By no means does this mean that the game always tells you the right answer, it just provides sufficient context for you to base your objection on. That doesn't make it less frustrating to know something you can't use, though.

Overall, this is a very entertaining and enjoyable game. Save scumming is sometimes necessary in cases where you have no idea what Phoenix Wright is about to say to stay afloat, but in my opinion it doesn't affect the experience of the great stories the game tells. If you enjoy visual novels or investigative/mystery games, this is an easy recommendation, but the stories are so interesting and the experience is so fun I'd heavily recommend that anyone give it a try.

*OBJECTION!*

I had no idea coming into this game that it had a full storyline.  My understanding of the series prior to playing it was that it was a bunch of unrelated short stories.  While the stories themselves have unique qualities and each one has its own charm, part of the fun of this series is that they all tell an overall story and the characters actually develop over time as the story progresses.  The gameplay itself is a fun challenge, though often the contradiction can be spotted but the way it wants the presentation of evidence is different from the way that you lay it down.  So I like the general idea of this game, but I just think that in moments, figuring out how the game wants you to proceed can be difficult.  In addition, I think certain characters could do with a wardrobe change, as this game could be enjoyable for a younger audience if not for what seems to be at least semi-mature wardrobe content.  As the only main difference in the games is in their plots, I'll rate each one below:

PW:AA - The introduction to the universe of Phoenix Wright.  This is the game that established the basic gameplay, developed the original cast, and did something very unique at the time that has now been replicated by several other games that are clearly paying homage to a classic.  Phoenix and Edgeworth make a perfect initial pair in court, and I just think this game deserves a lot of love. 8/10.

PW:JFA - This game introduced us to the successor prosecutor, and while I thought this new prosecutor gimmick was a stupid way to contrast her with Edgeworth, they actually developed her character to give her purpose throughout the entire storyline.  This game also introduced us to the magatama, which makes for a nice way to get the feeling of a trial before the trial has actually begun.  Pearly also appeared this game for the first time, and while I never saw a need for her character when she was first introduced, she's a character that has grown on me.  Finally, I'd like to add that the last game in this one was particularly well-written and overall a great mystery story.  It also tied in nicely to one of the classic episodes from the last game, so props to the writers for making this one a fitting sequel and something just as worthy of praise as the original. 8/10.

PW:T&T - In my opinion, one of the hardest things to do in a universe that has been well-established is to create an adequate final episode that ties all loose ends back up together again.  This game was pretty self-contained for the first few games but eventually they not only tied the specific game up to itself, but it also pretty much solved the remaining loose ends that we had been needing resolved from the past games, so there was a lot to love about this one.  Godot was the best prosecutor character in all three games, and anyone who has a different opinion on that is just straight-up incorrect.  Not sure if I liked what they did with his character, but I also thought that what they did in that episode was not totally out of character for the series.  The ending of the trilogy was impressive in terms of the number of loose ends that it tied together.  My only real complaint with the way the last story played out was in Maya's "strength" in handling it all for Pearly's sake.  After all she'd been through, I wish we'd seen a little more "realness," but maybe that's too much to expect from a cartoon medium paralegal.  In any case, the storyline was fascinating and I liked where they went with it.  9/10.

A charming take on the visual novel formula that combines investigation scenes collecting evidence, and trial scenes where you try to point out contradictions in testimony using evidence. Unfortunately this series suffers from bad writing and how strictly it wants you to follow its formulaic approach.

The investigations won't progress until you exhaustively check every item on every person or go to every location looking for the next event trigger so you don't miss anything for the court scenes. This ensures you never go into a case without all the info 'required' to make winning possible but makes the game very tedious.

The difficulty comes from selecting the right evidence in court but there's many points where suddenly the next choice is basically a game over if you don't select the right combination. This is made worse by the game wanting you to present evidence in a very specific order.

There were multiple times I wanted to point out clear contradictions but I was getting ahead of the story so it failed me for doing so. What's most frustrating is that stories are uncovered during the trials. Wright spends most of each episode bluffing and guessing his way through the court scenes, figuring things out only at the last moment which leaves you in the dark too and unable to do more than guess at where the writer is going. I think it's meant to make it more tense but it just feels hollow and makes the character seem inept.

Maybe if the stories were a bit less cliched and the gameplay more varied it would be more fun. Psyche-locks were an interesting addition but quickly became stale because they're court gameplay during investigations. Also what happened to 3D evidence? An interesting premise but does very little with it, they should have just made an anime instead.

Ace Attorney is a legendary game series, and with the Apollo Justice Trilogy set to come out next year (2024) I found myself coming back to play this trilogy to remind myself why the franchise is so special. Lets talk about it.

TLDR: Ace Attorney is a visual novel game, that means most of the game interaction doesn't actually happen in the game itself. It's really an elaborate puzzle game that you must piece together. Acting as both a detective and a defense attorney, you will go through 14 different cases and find the truth behind each of them. This is a thinking game, and the later trials in each entry of the trilogy will challenge your ability to both think logically and make creative, but accurate, connections.

Story: 
Without spoiling anything, I'm going to overview the story as best I can. Each entry in this trilogy is spaced out by a year. The timeline is fairly linear, but there are 2 cases you will go through that take place in the past. It's not continuity breaking at all, and actually makes that game my favorite of the three because it feels the most connected.

Typically, each case or "episode" will be a self-contained story. You will notice recurring characters, but that is generally all that repeats. You will go from a tutorial case in each game, which outlines the basic mechanics of how the game works, before getting in to the real content. These tutorial cases do, however, have story weight so they are very well utilized. 

When people discuss great stories told through video games, you'll often hear names like "The Last of Us" and "The Witcher" and "Mass Effect" among others. Those games all tell great stories, but they're a different kind of great story. In those games you play as the chosen one, a hero destined to save the world/universe from certain doom. In Ace Attorney, you're just a defense attorney that is fighting uphill to find the truth. I'd argue that Ace Attorney's story, particularly in Trials and Tribulations, is as compelling as those other great video game stories.

I'm going to list off my favorite cases by number, so the first case in the first game would be case #1 and the last case in game #3 would be case #14. Cases 4, 14, and 9 are outstanding. They are the climactic cases of each game, and are delightful to go through. Case #14 is probably the best case in the series as a whole because it really does wrap up the trilogy in an excellent way.

PS. Case #5 is a love it or hate it situation. I personally enjoy the court segments of that case quite a bit except for a certain vase section, but the investigation portions felt like they took forever.

Music:
Ace attorney games have phenomenal music, but it might not be for everyone. Remember, these games were developed originally for the GameBoy, and sound great when taken in that context. My personal favorite tune is the main prosecutor's music from the third game, Trials and Tribulations. The way that the music is used in gameplay as well is phenomenal as you'll know immediately if you're on the right track. When you present the correct piece of evidence, the music stops. It makes you feel like a genius in an incredibly subtle way.

Characters:
The characters in Ace Attorney are pun-filled and vibrant. There's hardly a character that isn't well developed or established in these games, and that's part of what makes them so beloved. You'll encounter some gems of text boxes along the journey through this game. The "West Clownadelphia" and "A breach? Here? Baliff! Get my steed! We must retreat at once!" are hilarious. There are some duds for characters, but overall this trilogy has the best cast of characters you'll find outside of a Persona or Final Fantasy game.

Graphics:
An older game for sure, but the HD face-lift the trilogy received does marvels for my enjoyment of the game. I play on a 4k 48" monitor, and the game is gorgeous. I love the art-style, it feels like you're playing through a comic book. The animations are still a bit janky, but overall the game could easily pass for a "retro indie game" today.

Audience:
Ace attorney games are meant for everyone, but the common theme in all of these games is investigating murders. because of that, blood is regularly mentioned and how murders can/are committed is also mentioned. I'd give this an age rating of PG-13 if it was a TV show.

Gameplay:
As mentioned before, this is really a visual novel game. That means you're effectively reading a book and trying to guess how it ends to progress the story. This lends itself to much more of a mental game than anything else, and that type of gameplay can turn a lot of people away from this type of game. Don't let it turn you away.

PC Requirements:
This game can be installed and played on a smart-fridge.

Difficulty:
There are some massive difficulty spikes in this trilogy. The first case in each game is typically very easy, and its meant to get you mentally prepared for what is to come. The final case or cases in each game are the most difficult, and that certainly makes sense from a developer standpoint. If you recall how i numbered the cases before, Case #5 is easily the hardest case in this trilogy. It is long, it requires an extreme amount of mental gymnastics, and can absolutely make you hate the series. The reason for this is because Case #5 was originally developed for the first game's re-release on the Nintendo DS and they wanted to make full use of the DS's features. However, it feels out of place both in terms of the main characters involved and their relationships at that point, along with the otherworldly confidence you, Phoenix, have during the trial segments.

Games 2 and 3 do not have a case anywhere near as challenging as Game 1's 5th and final case. You will either love that challenge or resent it.

Game-Time:
Now it says I have 70 hours in the game, that's only true because i forgot i had it open twice overnight. Your experience with this trilogy should get you around 40-55 hours on average, but obviously how good you are at deduction can change that figure by quite a bit.

Price:
Get it on sale, this game can go on sale for as low as $10 or less, i'd definitely recommend grabbing it then.

Bugs: Never experienced a bug with this game, it is exceptionally well done.

Final Score:
9/10. 

Conclusion:
For what Ace Attorney sets out to do, its almost perfect. It is the best visual novel you will ever play unless you dig deep into ones that eventually became TV shows or anime (which this one also, coincidentally, did; there's even a stageplay and live action move for it). The only real complaints i have with this game are the investigation sections. They are often supremely vague and unclear as to how to progress, and you'll find yourself using everything on everyone until you finally get the right solution to move on.

If the investigation sections were cleaner, this game would be a 10/10. As it stands, 9/10. Highly recommended to all.

Excellent collection of a classic mystery solving trilogy. There are many visual novels out there, but few of them manage to integrate interactive gameplay seamlessly into the story as well as Ace Attorney. While the level of challenge can fluctuate wildly between too easy and too difficult, the intricate story, characters, and logic puzzles are what make the Ace Attorney games truly iconic. The second game is a pretty underwhelming follow-up, but the first and third entries are very well-crafted and cohesive experiences that are sure to stick with me.

Don't let the title fool you. This game is less about being a lawyer than it is being a detective. But don't also let the fool you into thinking this is gonna be a bad game because it most certainly is not. Most of the episodes have highly compelling stories and mysteries. A lot of this game is paying attention to clues and testimonies. You need to really use your brain and think about how certain events unfolded and contradictions in people's testimonies. There are two ways you could approach this game that I feel you could find enjoyable, either you can take it seriously and really immerse yourself in the episodes and trying to defend your client, or you could laugh at all of the weird oddities of the Ace Attorney universe. If you can find enjoyment in either of things, I think you'll find yourself quite enjoying this game. I will say that this game is not without it's flaws. The quality of each episode can vary and whilst I would say all of them are not bad, not all of them are masterpieces either. But regardless, there is a reason this game has overwhelmingly positive reviews and if it sounds of any interest to you, I do recommend it. Overall, 8.5/10.

ENG: WHAT A PERFECT GAME, I'm still on the first of the trilogy, I still have a lot to play, but I'll say EVERYTHING that I loved and what I didn't like so much.
To begin with, the game starts and it looks like it's going to be a cool game, just about judgments, without a big story behind it, BUT IN THE SECOND EPISODE, suddenly someone you created an affection for, because he was the one who taught you how things work, Mia, the boss DIES, and the investigation begins, the story gets difficult, you think that everything is going to go wrong at several times, even more so when you discover that Mr. White is extremely powerful, corrupt and manipulated everyone, when everything seems to be going well, you go after him, and he makes YOU TURN THE SUSPECT, you think it's all over but when you find contradictions in his testimony, when you find evidence that they exonerate you and blame him, YOU SCREAM OF HAPPINESS, you feel pleasure and pride in yourself when you succeed.
You also create affection for Alice, like a daughter, and you cry when Alice incorporates Aline in a spiritual way, this game is incredible.

Characters: 8/10
Some characters end up being a bit poorly presented, like the first Lawyer we are debating, but in general, most characters are good and endearing.

History: 10/10
There's nothing to explain, right?

Art: 10/10
The game design, the scenarios are very beautiful, the dialogues, everything has a very beautiful design.

"Animations": 999/10
Let's say it doesn't really have animations, but I wanted to use it to talk about the actions of the characters in debate, like the point that Phoenix makes, the tap on the table that Phoenix and Edgeworth tap on the table, AND SIGNIFICANT, even more so when we're in a tense situation and we ask for protest, and we are anxious about a very important test, I almost have a heart attack at that time.

Game rating: 9999/10
WHAT A PERFECT GAME, YOU CAN PLAY IT WILL BE WORTH IT.

I have played every entry of the Ace Attorney series to this day, and i can say that it is a fantastic game series for anyone with a remote interest in problem solving and some patience. While some of its legal reasoning and story elements can be confusing or disagreeable, the charm of this trilogy is apparent from the start. 

Some characters will pull your heartstrings while others make you want to take a break from the game, but shouting "Objection!" in a kangaroo court has never been more entertaining. Despite its many gimmicks and oddballs, the game pulls off powerful moments with hardly any voice acting and basic graphics. 

Each game in the trilogy displays an improvement in story development and mechanics. This trilogy will simultaneously make you feel intelligent and... not as intelligent at times, but the journey is rewarding in itself. It is a great introduction to the series, and I highly recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind reading quite a bit. 

There are some gameplay aspects that can be infuriating at times, but I think that they get improved upon dramatically in later entries of the series. Even with these slight criticisms, I would say that it is worth spending time and money on.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Overall not a bad game, but I'll probably stop after I push through the first game in the trilogy. 
    
+ Writing is pretty amusing. I've laughed out loud a few times despite this game obviously being aimed at much younger players.
+ Characters are goofy and likable.
+ Music is pretty good.

+/- Sometimes seems like you have to read the programmers' minds to know which specific piece of evidence you have to present from many options that seem valid. It doesn't always feel like your fault when you mess up. Each case seems to have one or two answers that seem very counterintuitive.
+/- Aside from the iconic shots of the lawyers in the courtroom, the graphics are worse than I expected. It looks like an early 2000s flash game. Even for a port of a GBA/DS game, it looks pretty rough.

------- The flashing. Good heavens, the flashing. The characters are fun, and the dialogue is entertaining, but I almost don't want to read it, because the game emphasizes things by playing an annoying sound effect and flashing the screen to white. When you're talking to excitable characters like Maya Fey, the screen flashes almost constantly. It's unbelievably aggravating, and there's no way to turn it off. It would be impossible to overstate just how annoying it really is. It's awful, truly awful. This is the reason I probably won't finish the trilogy anytime soon. I won't be able to tolerate the horrendous flashing for another two games.

For the uninitiated, it's a visual novel puzzle game with lots of interesting characters, clever writing (occasional puns, 2004 internet memes that haven't aged as poorly as I thought they might, silly reincorporated gags), and often a lot of heartwarming moments that really make the characters feel like real people that exist somewhere.

You'll get a lot of mileage out of this game, since it has all 3 games.

I rank them in this order of quality:
1.) Phoenix Wright: Ace Attourney (because it's hard to beat the one that started it all)
2.) Phoenix Wright: Trials & Tribulations (because the story and music are just too good)
3.) Phoenix Wright: Justice For All (because the music is bad across the board and Wendy Oldbag can get bent)

If you're interested in this one, consider checking out Apollo Justice when the next Ace Attorney Trilogy is released (which has some of the best and highest fidelity music in the series), as well as Miles Edgeworth Ace Investigations on the DS, and then download the rom for the second game which wasn't originally localized for American audience due to the high cost and low returns they would have gotten from doing so.

In short, I love Phoenix Wright. I grew up with it when I was about 14 and still play it to this day. Nothing can touch it. Danganronpa is a cheap PW imitation for explicit edgy weeaboos who need to see blood and pain to get their rocks off, but you can't beat the original.

Buy it and hopefully they'll bring the other ones to consoles. Capcom is on a ROLL with their games lately - Monster Hunter World, Megaman Legacy Collection 1&2, Megaman X Legacy Collection 1&2, Beat'em'up Bundle, Resident Evil 2, Devil May Cry 5, Ghost Trick, and now this?

I made a SUPER long video review about this game - things I liked, things I disliked, and a lot of discussion of how damn good the soundtrack is.

Having finished the "Phoenix Wright" games, I feel strange. I played about one every eighteen months, and every one of them—despite at times being frustrating—left me feeling like I'd just said bye to friends, especially this last one. They're not perfect. The second game meanders; the last case in the trilogy goes too supernatural—and melodramatic—for my tastes; at times I knew exactly what to do, but couldn't figure-out what the game wanted me to do; they're overwritten. I mean, that last case? Anime-over-real-life-logic to a fault. But it's a great, charming series. Very fun. *Very* funny. Goofy and loving it. They made me care about visual novels, which I just don't, usually. And they made me care about the characters. Just superb, overall. Get them.

I've always loved these games. If you like a somewhat point and click, heavily dialogue with almost a puzzle aspect then this trilogy is for you. I feel as though some dialogue has been changed in some situations, Don't quote me on that, but I feel like something is off from what I remember. The game play can get a little tedious when having to move from place to place and sometimes you feel like you've found the answer in a certain piece of evidence that actually proves your point but find out the hard way it's not supposed to be used until it's pressed in the cross examination. Other than that, I have nothing but love for the original trilogy and Ace Attorney Investigations featuring Edgeworth. The stories are well thought out and you find yourself invested in the characters, the motives, and of course what will happen next. They did some sprucing on the graphics but to be honest I prefer the pixelated images of the DS version. Gives it the nostalgia I feel seeing these characters again. It is worth the buy, but do try to catch it at an awesome sale or even bundled with the new trilogy. I can't express how happy I am to have this in my library. It was something I played for the hell of it when I was younger and now it's always a part of my happiest memories. I had never imagined highly anticipating the next game or even getting the rest of the trilogy. So all I can really say is that you will love it but you will be very sad when it ends. I've played the other games afterwards but they don't hold a candle to the original trilogy with Phoenix wright. I really enjoy Ace Attorney Investigations and I keep holding out that we will get a switch and/or PC release of 1 and the not localized 2.

[b] The Ace Attorney trilogy has it’s good moments [/b], but they are buried in between more mediocre episodes. Even though the plot ultimately falls flat especially compared to modern standards, it can still be fun to play. [b]Just don’t pay the full price for it [/b], the game is definitely not worth it. It’s a simple port with improved graphics and doesn’t offer anything additional that would justify the cash grabbing price.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+ Characters have unique designs and mannerisms.
+ Improved graphics over the original.
+ It’s a nostalgia trip for original trilogy players.
+ Soundtrack is pretty good.
+ You can squeeze a lot of play hours from it, even if you played the trilogy before.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
- In-game penalties vary in their severity, sometimes hurting you just a bit and sometimes giving you just one chance, regardless of your “health”. This encourages maniacal save scumming which isn’t much fun.
- Plot gets repetitive very quickly and you end up thinking whether half of world’s population has a tragically deceased sibling.
- Some characters are too cartoonish for their own good.
- The investigative parts can be a painful experience especially when having to deal with infuriating characters that keep reappearing in the game.
- There are sometimes plot points that are pretty obvious but will remain hidden in plain sight until the game arbitrarily demands you to expose them.
- You can’t really have fun playing the game blind. A guide is highly recommended if you want to maintain your sanity.

It reminded me how old this game actually is when I was playing it. A digicam was still a new tech. We are so far away from that point, and yet everything else in this game does not feel old. Everything about this game is iconic and I love every second of it. I haven't finished it yet, but I won't stop any time soon.

The first game was ok until chapter 5 and then the formula got very tiresome. It's all trial-and-error point-and-click guessing puzzles, cringeworthy dialogue and repetitive unskippable animations of people blowing bubblegum, waving their hair, or worst of all; the Cyclops guy drinking coffee. Very cheaply made with no voice-acting except for the words "objection" or “take that”, and it goes on for far too long. The latter probably being how they still get away with the high price, even on 50% discount.

It has taken several months to slog through the trilogy in between playing better games. I could've just quit but I wanted my money’s worth and to finish the story for closure. After that I won’t be touching this series again.

Despite having played it on Game Boy years ago, it still remains enjoyable. The game is visually upscaled with a sleek UI and is fully translated in multiple languages so that you can play through various localized versions.

All three games in the trilogy are some of the best I've ever played. As someone completely new to the series, I was hooked nearly immediately. You (usually) play as Phoenix Wright a defense lawyer, and gather evidence, interview witnesses, and use your gathered information to stumble your way through your client's defense. The game plays as a visual novel, involving lots of heavy reading and requires paying close attention to solve it's mysteries, so keep that in mind if that's not your cup of tea. All of the characters are oozing with charm, and the mysteries that unravel themselves kept me on the edge of my seat in every case.

I did have a few annoyances with the game, like sometimes the evidence needed didn't seem to match up with the dialogue it needed to be presented on, so don't feel bad about using a guide if you find yourself stuck on a puzzle for too long. The difficulty curve is a bit inconsistent, and the penalty system is overly harsh at the best of times, so be sure to save very often if you don't want to repeat hours of content. Despite these minor annoyances, I absolutely adore this trilogy. I found myself engaged for every minute of the 50 hour play time. If you're a fan of mystery/puzzle games, I would absolutely recommend it, especially if you catch it on sale for $10 like I did.

If you're a fan of visual novels, you shouldn't miss out on Ace Attorney; its humour and sensitivity are brilliant. 

The characters the foundation of this game; all of them are well written, and while sometimes they tend to be extravagant and exaggerated, they are human — meaning they express strong emotions and form meaningful bonds. The details matter, the silly dialogues tell wholesome stories. While some barely legal things happen in the courtroom, you should let that slide since it's hilarious (poor Phoenix). The cases are interesting and sometimes annoying, both in the challenging way and in the "I wish this character wasn't so stereotypically infuriating" — which isn't exactly a good thing, but it certainly makes more complex characters pop out.

The music is amazing, not much to say about that. The soundtracks are memorable and characteristic. The story flows nicely and develops through the trials, which are really interesting and fun to solve. In general, Ace Attorney's vibe is really peculiar and such a style with a strong personality is rare.

I highly recommend playing this game. Despite its flaws (overly stereotypical characters, the terrible movement system) it's a game that really deserves the hype. It's like a big inside joke between members of a family — in this case, AA's community. Hope you enjoy it!

Why isn't 9/11 ever mentioned in Ace Attorney?

We all know Ace Attorney takes place in the United States, so you'd think they would mention 9/11 at least once. Especially when talking about DL-6, I mean, it takes place three months after 9/11. Why are Von Karma and Gregory Edgeworth busy fighting in a trial about cupcake wars when America just suffered the biggest act of terrorism ever? Aren't these characters the slightest bit patriotic? The original trilogy was also made around 2001-2004 so it's weird Takumi wasn't thinking about 9/11 enough to write dialogue about it.

I would mention The Inherited Turnabout but I always forget that's actually 2000, so 9/11 hadn't happened yet. In fact, there's even a deleted scene where one of the sculptures is a representation of New York and it has the Twin Towers, but they deleted it for aging too badly. Apparently AAI2-3 was in the works all the way back since 2001, which makes sense seeing everything that happens in the first game is a reference to this case.

Anyway, this just bothered me and I can't bring myself to say "Ace Attorney is a very accurate representation of the USA" when they never mention 9/11 once.

Among the many games I have played, the Ace Attorney series holds a special place in my heart. This franchise, particularly the game "Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney" and its sequels, has captivated me with its unique blend of courtroom drama, intriguing storytelling, and memorable characters. In this article, I will share the reasons why I love the Ace Attorney series and why it has become one of my all-time favorites.

Engaging Storytelling:
At the core of the Ace Attorney games lies their enthralling storytelling. As a player, I am cast into the role of Phoenix Wright, a rookie defense attorney, and tasked with defending the innocent in complex murder trials. The game masterfully weaves together intricate plotlines filled with suspense, unexpected twists, and emotional moments that keep me invested from start to finish. Each case presents a puzzle to solve, with cleverly hidden clues and testimonies to dissect. The gradual unraveling of the truth, accompanied by gripping courtroom battles, creates an intense and immersive experience.

Unique Gameplay Mechanics:
Unlike most mainstream video games, Ace Attorney primarily focuses on investigation and courtroom proceedings rather than action-packed sequences. The gameplay revolves around examining crime scenes, gathering evidence, cross-examining witnesses, and presenting decisive arguments in court. This combination of puzzle-solving and logical reasoning offers a refreshing change of pace, challenging my critical thinking skills and keeping me engaged throughout. The feeling of successfully exposing contradictions and presenting evidence to turn the tide in favor of justice is immensely satisfying.

Memorable Characters:
The Ace Attorney series boasts a diverse cast of colorful characters, each with their distinct personalities and quirks. From the determined and righteous Phoenix Wright to the enigmatic prosecutor Miles Edgeworth, the characters are brilliantly written and bring the game's world to life. The witty dialogue, humorous interactions, and memorable catchphrases create a delightful atmosphere, even in the midst of intense courtroom battles. The recurring characters and their evolving relationships provide a sense of continuity and make every new installment feel like a reunion with old friends.

Themes of Justice and Morality:
Underlying the thrilling gameplay and captivating narratives, the Ace Attorney series explores deeper themes of justice, morality, and the human condition. The games often delve into complex moral dilemmas, challenging players to question their own sense of right and wrong. They highlight the importance of seeking truth, the flaws in the legal system, and the consequences of corruption. The thought-provoking nature of the stories elevates the game beyond mere entertainment, prompting reflection on real-world issues.

The Ace Attorney series has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape, captivating players worldwide with its gripping narratives, unique gameplay mechanics, and memorable characters. As a fan of the franchise, I am drawn to its engrossing storytelling, challenging puzzles, and thought-provoking themes. It has ignited my passion for justice, honed my analytical skills, and provided countless hours of entertainment. If you seek a game that combines legal drama, intriguing mysteries, and a touch of humor, look no further than the Ace Attorney series. It has undoubtedly earned its place among the greatest video game franchises of all time.

However, i've played the DS versions of the Trilogy, and i feel very biased torwards them sprite-wise. I really don't like some HD sprites, but the fact this game had a PC port only by 2019 is insane.

However, the Ace Attorney franchise ever since i played the first game in 2016 has changed my life. I've replayed the series up to Investigations 2 (and only played DD/SoJ once, but i shall check them out again soonish, or maybe if a PC port comes), and i feel like the franchise set up my standard for character development and games in general, no wonder it's the most influential VN and it inspired many other games. Despite the silliness of the series, it still has a rather "normal" level of grounded-upness you don't see in other detective visual novels (except maybe Hotel Dusk/Last Window, really funny i know).

Our beloved Shu Takumi also made Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective, which is actually getting a PC port, although it is not a visual novel itself, but you can definitely see the AA influence in it.

Charming visual novel / detective series by Capcom; Engaging and memorable. Sometimes requires a lot of "trial and error" work which is frustrating, but the mysteries are fun to solve overall. Will be playing the rest of the series now!

A fun trilogy of Visual Novels through its puzzles, animated characters, and solid background music. Keeps things engaging with its twists in discoveries through your investigations and court trials as a defense attorney, as well as character development. Both the main overarching story line as well as side stories are all fairly well written to have some things obvious to the player but still keep some surprises as they are progressed.

It is still a Visual Novel with a fair amount of trial and error choices, so expect the slower gameplay that comes with it. Quick skipping using one button helps to move repeated text along at a reasonable pace.

The English localization is mostly good, but there's a few typos and some cultural dissonance. This is because the game was originally set in Japan, but the main cast of characters are noted as American in the localization. Meanwhile the American characters were shifted to being German. This creates some growing number of oddities in the game in some character lines, setting aesthetics, and cultural value differences.

A well-written, extremely absurd series. I'd give it a solid 7/10. It could really use modern features like textbox hide, backlog, CG viewer, auto-advance toggle. But the game is older and doesn't fit into the standard VN mold, so it is what it is.

There are some really great characters in here. Everything is connected. (Don't bother theorizing or trying to guess case results in advance. Sometimes it is not really knowable until you're going through it.)

Franziska love. Godot love. Viola love. Mia love.

Overall pretty fun, entertaining stories and characters.

But a few things I didn't like:

- Some puzzles require too much of a leap of logic, practically the only way to beat them is by trial and error (save scum and try every clue).
- Mouse/keyboard controls are very bad for the 3D / rotation puzzles
- The [spoiler]supernatural aspects[/spoiler] really detract from a game that should be logical.
- Weird sexualisation of a minor character. I don't have a problem with sexy characters; I have a problem with them making a 17-year-old (who chooses to wear modest clothes) get [spoiler]super-cleavage when she channels an adult woman. Almost seems like someone on the dev team has a non-consent kink since the game says she loses control of herself when she channels and a spirit takes over... and somehow the spirits always rearrange the modest clothes to become extra revealing (more revealing than their own outfits when they were alive).[/spoiler].

Look. In terms of age, this game is old enough to drink in nearly every country in the world. Some of the references are dated, the puns eye-roll worthy, and the logic a tad forced. There's times when the scenarios are so contrived that it borders on breaking verisimilitude. 

All that said, it remains one of the most fantastic [series of] games I've ever played. The stories are engaging and just surreal enough that it remains difficult to call twists before they happen. The writing is punchy and enjoyable with just enough camp to keep from letting the tone get to serious. The characters are as adorable as their personalities. The music alone will have you thinking about the cases long after you've closed the game.

If you've never played a visual novel style game but thought you might enjoy the relaxing pace, do yourself a favor and pick this up. I guarantee you won't regret it.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is perfectly at home on PC especially on the big TV screen, its gameplay fun and engaging for players both new and old. Although it has few minor issues, the overall experience is one highly recommended to anyone looking for a new game (or three). If you’ve never played the Ace Attorney games before, or if you’re looking for a new set of visual novel-style games to sink your teeth into, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is absolutely a must-buy on. With great humor, memorable stories and characters, a unique take on the legal system and – of course – a killer soundtrack, you really can’t go wrong. Just remember to only raise your objections when you actually have the evidence to support them, or you’ll learn the hard way that the Judge will only forgive so many spontaneous outbursts.

PROS:
✓ Great writing, with a memorable cast of characters
✓ Colorful, vibrant and refined visuals
✓ Stylish, fairly challenging gameplay
✓ Interesting compilation of stories within
✓ Upgraded interface
✓ Lengthy campaign
✓ Epic soundtrack

CONS:
- Requires leaps in logic
- Some hard-to-find objectives
- No text log
- Some obscure cases

It's hard to write an engaging review when the game in question is so good, and everyone knows how good it is. What more can I add? It's three really well-made games in one, great value for money, and an example of a remaster done pretty much perfectly.

My only negatives are small and inconsequential in view of the whole. I found some characters irritating (chiefly Franziska Von Karma), as well as the tendency to make the hero take a lot of mental (and physical, see Franziska) abuse during the course of the games. But that's easily balanced out by other characters I do like, for example Maya and Pearl Fey; my main man Will Powers; and the hilariously pathetic Moe the Clown. The general tone is over-the-top, the characters larger-than-life, and that can get a-bit-much, but on the whole it rides that line where I can bear the sillier elements, because the cases are always interesting.

In the second and third games of the trilogy, I feel that their respective final chapters got a bit convoluted and couldn't quite stick the landing, if you know what I mean. But it's a minor complaint, they're still enjoyable to experience.

Just buy it, you won't regret it. But maybe disable the screen shake effect as I did.

It was fun for the first two/three cases or so, but as it goes on I felt like it had some problems.
The pacing is an issue for me later in the game - the cases seem to drag out longer and longer, partially due to more gameplay but largely due to unnecessary dialogue and repetition. 
Story issues - the whole courtroom procedure is ridiculous, but that's part of the charm. What I had issue with is the other part of the story, the crimes. The last two in particular - the story was full of gaping plot holes and non-sequiturs and things that just didn't make sense. Combined with the sluggish pace, I just wanted to get them over with. 
So overall, it's a neat idea and was executed well for the first couple of cases, but that's where it runs out of steam. I think maybe they tried to up the ante by making cases longer and more convoluted, but it just made the game worse. If I could go back, I wouldn't buy it again.

This is not a lawyer or detective game, but simply a set of visual novels. Your enjoyment will depend entirely on wether you like the zany anime characters and absurd scenarios, which I do not. Unlike in, let's say, LA Noire, where you can miss clues or witnesses and botch interrogations, in Ace Attorney you'll always be forced to exhaust all options before events trigger and you move from field investigation to courtroom battles. Once you are in court, you can still choose the wrong piece of evidence, but you'll be given plenty of retries and cases don't veer from pre-established outcomes. Usually, after a lenghty "bout" against a witness that constantly alters his or her testimony to suit his or her needs (which would completely destroy its credibility in a reasonable environment, but not here), you'll reach a point where you show the conclusive evidence to sway the judge, and then a ridiculous, out of the blue event will trigger that will prolong the case. Afterwards, PW will be at a loss, but suddenly something will happen (like, a ghost will show up, or a surprise witness will forcefully take the stand), and then the judge will ask you: "well Mr. Wright, please show us the piece of evidence that proves that what you are saying is true", desperately trying not to be completely obvious as to what that is. This will repeat a few times per day at court, which will serve either to amuse you or roll your eyes.  Guess which one was my reaction.

The game treads lightly around morbid themes like murder, using non-stop levity, which is alright, don't get me wrong, but I felt like I was constantly going asleep as I played this since there were no stakes at all. It's not the most rivetting "game" Capcom has ever made, and I certainly regret ever buying this because it was not cheap.

A stupendous crime solver visual novel that you should definitely play if you're into the likes of who-done-it's such as Columbo. The localization is definitely a bit iffy (it obviously took place in Japan but they made it take place in the US since our tiny minds can't comprehend countries existing outside of the US, there's some pop culture references that are really dated by now, etc.) but a lot of the cases drew me in where I was sitting there for hours on end not able to put it down, and I'm really not that big of a VN player. I will say that some cases had some questionable aspects to it, whether it was a contradicting oversight of a case that isn't mentioned or a case going into the realm of just being plain silly in how a murder was carried out, I still overall enjoyed my experience with the PW trilogy.
With this being sort of a 'remaster' though, the character and BG sprites are passable. It does kinda look like they just put it through an upscaling filter or something, not 100% sure though. Whether or not the original sprites are better is just subjective. It doesn't feel like they did much beyond that to be a remaster though, they really could have implemented a message history and other QoL things that VNs have nowadays. I did read they fixed up some errors from the original releases, though I don't know what these specifically were.

If you haven't played the trilogy before this is a definite buy, there's still the option of the original releases though if you really wanna. If you have played them, there's nothing really new here beyond fixing errors and updated art (you should still buy it and play it though so we can hopefully get more games and re-releases of the sequels).

Proud pricetag for a cheap remake (pixel graphics replaced by vector graphics that look like amateurish flash games from the early 2000s). User interface not adapted to modern hardware. The remake had sold over 800k times by end of 2020, most importantly for the switch, but no touchscreen support, not even mouse support. Yes, to click somewhere, you have to move the pointer with cursor keys and press enter. In a game using unity from 2019 that was remade for modern platforms.

The story of the game is nice and entertaining, the writing is good, although repeatedly following the same patterns and sometimes predictable.
Characters and legal system are completely silly, but its a game, with not much relation to reality. 

It is rather a visual novel than a game. The puzzles are usually not challenging and often there are strong hints what to do next (I should go there, I should talk to that person, I should present this). It only gets difficult if something lacks a bit of logic or if the game expects you to do exactly one thing, while another would logically be good, too.

The user interface is bad. Moving between places is unnecessarily complicated, so is switching between the modes for movement, investigations, talk and presenting.
In later episodes, additional mechanisms are added, which don't add an additional puzzle challenge but additional chores for the player.
Text is often repeated (at court or when talking/presenting to a person), its also not ideal that if you visit the same place on another day, what you already had explored becomes unexplored again and exploring repeats the same dialogs. This combined with a limited possibility to speed up or skip text, makes the game longer just through repetition. 
The mechanism to lose the game and having to start from last savegame is also a bad idea, because it again adds unneccessary repetition, but it does not hurt much as the game is so easy, you won't lose.

I had much higher expectations as the mechanics of pressing and objection with presenting a proof have good potential.
This is rather played for the story and characters, but the slow-as-molasses pace of the gameplay and tedious chores prevent just enjoying the flow of the story.
And in the end, while the stories are entertaining and touch some interesting questions they lack really interesting dilemmata and had to sacrifice some potential qualities of the story for the gameplay and twists.

It is visible that they tried to do it better but still the game transports stereotype gender roles. It helps a bit that they replaced one of the male villains by a female one, gave the protagonist a female boss in the beginning, and one womans naive play with her female attributes turns out to the disguise of a criminal - but still controlled by her male boss.  Most of the persons at court (judge, prosecutor, attorney) are male, and females appear most prominently as 16 year old girls that try to help the male protagonist and require his approval.
But the game should be judged considering the time and cultural context of its creation and its effort to break with gender stereotypes should be appreciated.

Absolutely splendid game(s). The cases are full of twists and turns to keep you engaged, and the trilogy tells a complete narrative with almost no loose ends remaining. One thing to note is that this game doesn't go for the 100% scientific approach that one might expect of a game that involves criminal investigation, but it's arguably more entertaining that way. Also, sometimes the answers the game requires from you aren't that obvious, but thankfully you can manually save at virtually any point in the game.

Some typical anime fan-service is present, the most egregious being a few minor characters, but nothing too bad. Localisation is noticeable since there is no way anyone will believe the setting is America, but it allows the game(s) to have a certain charm to them that's rarer to find in modern day localisations.

A few things worth noting:
a. The play order for the games are, in order:
    1. Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney
    2. Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Justice for All
    3. Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Trials and Tribulations

b. That being said, Chapter 5 of the 1st game (Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney) was originally released after everything else in the trilogy. I didn't have any issues playing it before the 2nd and 3rd game, but it's noticeably different than everything else in the trilogy.

c. There are some points in the game where, if you save, might lock you into game overs or a bad ending. It's fairly obvious when that is, so just be careful and you'll be fine.

All in all, highly recommended for anyone fond of mystery-solving.

The Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a collection of three visual novel adventure games that were originally released for the Nintendo DS and later ported to other platforms. The games put players in the role of Phoenix Wright, a defense attorney who must gather evidence, question witnesses, and present his case in court to prove his clients' innocence. The gameplay consists of two main parts: investigation and trial. During the investigation phase, players can move around different locations, talk to characters, and gather evidence. During the trial phase, players must present evidence and cross-examine witnesses to prove their client's innocence.

The game is known for its engaging storyline, memorable characters, and challenging puzzles. The dialogue and script is witty and well written. The game's art style is colorful and expressive and the character designs are memorable and unique. The game's soundtrack is also noteworthy, with catchy and memorable tracks that add to the game's overall charm.
The Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy includes three games: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Justice for All, and Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Trials and Tribulations. Each game features a series of cases that players must solve by gathering evidence, questioning witnesses, and presenting their case in court.

In the first game, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney, players take on the role of a rookie defense attorney named Phoenix Wright as he takes on a series of cases. The game introduces players to the series' core gameplay mechanics and characters. The second game, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Justice for All, continues Phoenix's journey as a defense attorney and introduces new gameplay mechanics and characters. The third game, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney - Trials and Tribulations, concludes Phoenix's story and offers some of the series' most challenging cases yet.

One of the strengths of the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is its engaging and well-written storyline. Each case in the game is filled with twists and turns, and players will find themselves on the edge of their seat as they try to unravel the truth. The characters in the game are also well-developed and memorable, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations.

The gameplay in Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is also noteworthy. The game's investigation phase is filled with challenging puzzles that require players to think critically and pay attention to detail. The trial phase is equally challenging, as players must present evidence and cross-examine witnesses to prove their client's innocence.

The game's art style is also noteworthy. The game's 2D sprites and colorful backgrounds are expressive and memorable. The character designs are unique and memorable, and the game's soundtrack is catchy and memorable.

Overall, the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a must-play for fans of visual novels, adventure games, and courtroom dramas. The game's engaging storyline, memorable characters, and challenging puzzles make it a great addition to any player's game collection. It's not just a game but an interactive novel where you are the main character, the plot is well written, the characters are well developed, it is a rich and immersive experience.

Morbius is a 2022 American superhero film based on the Marvel Comics character of the same name, produced by Columbia Pictures in association with Marvel. Distributed by Sony Pictures Releasing, it is the third film in Sony's Spider-Man Universe (SSU). Directed by Daniel Espinosa and written by Matt Sazama and Burk Sharpless, it stars Jared Leto as Dr. Michael Morbius, alongside Matt Smith, Adria Arjona, Jared Harris, Al Madrigal, and Tyrese Gibson. In the film, Morbius and his surrogate brother Milo (Smith) become living vampires after curing themselves of a rare blood disease.

There were several attempts to bring Morbius to the big screen since 1998, including joining the Blade franchise as an antagonist and having a solo film produced by Artisan Entertainment, neither of which ever came to fruition. After announcing plans for a new shared universe of films inspired by Spider-Man related characters beginning with Venom (2018), Sony began developing a film based on Morbius. Sazama and Sharpless had written a script by November 2017, and Leto and Espinosa officially joined in June 2018. Work on the film began at the end of the year with further casting, ahead of production starting in London in February 2019. Filming was confirmed to have been completed by June 2019, with reshoots happening in Los Angeles the following February.

Morbius premiered at the Plaza Carso in Mexico City on March 10, 2022 and was theatrically released in the United States on April 1, 2022, after being delayed several times from an initial July 2020 date, primarily due to the COVID-19 pandemic. It received largely negative reviews from critics, with criticism towards its writing, visual effects, and post-credits scenes, though Smith's performance received some praise. The film was also a box-office bomb and grossed $167 million worldwide. Due to the poor critical and commercial reception, it became the subject of various internet memes.

At a hospital in Greece, 10-year-old Michael Morbius welcomes his surrogate brother Lucien, whom he unintentionally renames Milo; they bond over their shared blood illness and desire to be "normal". Their adoptive father and hospital director Nicholas arranges for Morbius to attend medical school in New York while he focuses on caring for Milo....
