An enthralling game throughout three originally separate games, the Ace Attorney Trilogy has a unique, engaging story line showing character growth and consistent gameplay mechanics across all three franchises. What really stuck out to me was the continuity (minus one case - if you play the Trilogy, you'll understand which one ;)) across the games. Unlike other games, there weren't any noticeable plot holes for me. One of the biggest criticisms of the game I have seen lie in its false depiction of actual court situations in both Japan (where the game was originally made) and its US localization (which I played); however, this is exactly *why* the Trilogy works for me - it takes place in a dystopic alternate universe where the court systems are so riddled with cases that lawyers have little time to prepare for cases, and cases cannot exceed an abnormally low number of days. There are also supernatural twists which accent the appeal of the game, in my opinion. Though certainly a victim of the "Third Case Disease" across all three games, this game is easy to pick up, and hard to put down as you try to object, press and present your way to victory!

I was hoping to come up with a good review while I was objecting, your honor...
I didn't.

The gameplay isn't any better. Phoenix Wright forces the player to move around too much to find the plot. In the explore sections the player examines, talks, moves, and shows evidence. The player moves to a location, performs a single action, then runs to another area. Repeat. The exact actions must be performed in the correct order. It's easy to miss one obscure action. To avoid frustration I ask every question and present every piece of evidence to everyone I meet. This creates its own feeling of frustration. It's not a game if I have to play this way to proceed. It's checking items off a list. At trial the player needs to present the precise piece of evidence at the perfect time. Sometimes the answer is obvious, but it's also obscure and unguessable. This is a common problem with adventure games. Frustrated players look up answers to continue the story. Except that the story isn't great either.

The characters are the only redeeming feature of Phoenix Wright. The lead and recurring characters are charming, sarcastic, clueless, humorous, and determined to do right, whether it's Gumshoe, Edgeworth, Phoenix, or Maya/Mia.

Honestly, I never wanted to be a lawyer. I always thought it was tedious job, always having to defend people good and bad. Getting in between personal disputes. The sleepless nights. The potentially awful pay. It wasn't what I wanted to do, but I had no choice. 
However, my entire view changed once I saw the prosecutor. His name? Miles Edgeworth. He's a fancy looking man who wears red. He's cocky, sharp, and a bit of a jerk. But something about him.. I couldn't keep away, not even for a second. Ever since I first saw him, if I saw a case he was working on I would join instantly. He's a beautiful man, and I can't stand to be away from him. 
One day, as I was getting ready to confess to Edgeworth, I ran into a man in orange. He said his name was Damon Gant, and he claimed to be a part of the police force. I didn't mind, though I told him I would talk to him later. He didn't like that I said this, and before I knew it my vision was dark, and I was never able to open my eyes again. My body has not been found.

The trilogy originally comes from Gameboy Advance and has been released several times on newer consoles and handhelds. The trilogy offers varied (murder) cases that we, as lawyer Phoenix Wright, have to solve through investigations, cross-examinations and bluffs (lol) to get to the truth in the end. The game requires a bit of thinking and reading, so it's not for people who expect action-packed gameplay here. Each case has its own storyline, which mostly explains the backstories of various characters in more detail, to end up with a perfectly tied up overall package. Of course, the stories also contain plot twists, and it's not always immediately clear who is actually the culprit. All in all, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy tells a nice story, which I can recommend to everyone!

This game was made for the mystery, riddle, locked-room enthusiast. There is no plot or deeply compelling sotry-telling, instead, the focus of the game is it's narrative-based, logic puzzles.

The puzzles are ridiculously fun, and mostly well-written, with well-paced bits of information and clues that help players theory-craft, and build their case. The logic jumps get kind of stupid in the later games, but its an old game, and there's some really nice walkthrus online for when ur stuck. Each chapter is a time-sink though, and it's awkward trying to pick-up a chp midway after setting it down, so you'd need to set aside a good few hours for each chp.

The cast is adorable, with a recurring main cast and the one-episode characters being played by easily digestible caricatures, each episode feels new, and stand-alone, as we're confronted by totally new, lively characters each time. The main cast, is stupidly funny and loveable, the dynamics between each character is fun and there's nobody in the game to dislike.

While light-hearted, this game does require using ur brain, if ur looking for a game to blindly click through, this probably isn't gonna be it. But if ur looking for an engaging game, full of fun puzzles and characters then this'll be ur jam.

I'll drop a serious review this time. Ace attorney 1 is a fun enough and rather goofy game which may not be everyone's cup of tea. I am on the fence since I think there's a lot to like but sometimes think the games tone can be off putting for me (we're investigating murder here lets calm down on the banter a bit). The game has some poor narrative decisions and I think regardless of how much you like the game, it can be frustrating to try and figure out the right things to do to move the story along when doing investigations. Furthermore, some gameplay decisions are also a bit frustrating such as presenting the same piece of evidence twice in a row during some cases. That being said, I think that the main cast of Phoenix, Maya and Edgeworth are all fairly likable with Edgeworth easily being my favorite character in the game. The 4th trial is by far the best one this game has to offer as it does wonders to build Edgeworths character in particular. Overall, I give this game a 6/10. Its alright, not bad but not amazing but worth giving a shot.

Repetitive, and sometimes frustrating gameplay. Probably not everyone's cup of tea, but the game has a pretty good storyline and if you don't mind visual novels and heaviy story based games, then you'll probably like this.

Overall, id rate this a 4/5 and would recommend it to most people, $30 for it is rather pricey, though.

The game is very much on rails. It's very repetitive. You don't need to be particularly cleaver. The information gathering portions have a lot of back-and-forth. Go to area A, ask all the question ( choices don't matter ), inspect all objects, go to area B, repeat, go to area C, repeat, go to area A, repeat, go to area C, repeat. There might be a character that wasn't there before. You just go back and forth until you trigger the event for the next day.
For courtroom days you just 'press the witness' on every question. On appropriate responses you submit the appropriate evidence.
The stories and animation are fun, but the gameplay isn't. It's just a time suck.

It's a glorified "remember the highlighted text simulator" in visual novel format. You also get penalised for figuring out things too early when the story isn't ready for you, and there's not much creativity in how you answer or act. A lot of time is spent jumping between the same 4-5 locations hoping for a cutscene trigger or in some cases even waiting for a full on deus ex machina when there are no contradictions to point out.

The music and assets are also heavily recycled between scenes and episodes and get old quickly. Considering how tedious this game is, my guess is most fans of this series picked this up out of childhood nostalgia.

Finally, the port is also strangely done and manages to take up 60% cpu. This game is literally a slideshow lmao, if rendering needs to be done it should be done on the gpu. There's an unofficial fix for the new AA game but not this trilogy.

However, the character dialogue is hilarious, especially the elder von Karma. Flavour text is also well done.
If that's your thing, get this game and have a good time. If you're looking for a puzzle solving game, look elsewhere.

I put this game on my wishlist because of the "OBJECTON!" memes... A couple of years later I finally got it and I'm sorry I didn't buy it earlier. The entire game is quite witty and meme-worthy. It's the first visual novel style game that I'm playing and I believe it is a great introduction to the genre, but also sets the bar quite high. If you don't mind the quite passive style of play and focusing on thinking about how the different pieces of evidence and testimony are tied together, I strongly recommend giving this game a chance!

What I especially liked:
Obviously, for a visual novel, the story is pretty important and for me, it was pretty good (even though not perfect). Let's say that by the time you're done with the game, you'd be content with it.
To strengthen the story, each character has their own distinct personality. They can often be described as silly, extreme or stereotypical, but this only contributes to the game's atmosphere. Many of the characters also have their own "soundtrack", which I found pretty cool!

What I didn't like so much:
The game is quite long. It's true that it's technically 3 games, with 14 cases in total, but it took me more than 60 hours to finish it and, honestly, by the end I was a bit tired of it.
There are some cases where it wasn't clear to me where I have to go or that I need to present some evidence to somebody in order to proceed. This can be frustrating at times.
Another small issue I had is that sometimes during trials I found a general contradiction, but it took me some trial and error to figure out the exact piece of evidence and exact line of testimony where it needs to be presented.

All of this taken into account, I recommend this game wholeheartedly. It's also quite often on sale, so it's easy to get it discounted.

The only part of the game that I wasn't always a huge fan of were the investigations. Highly recommended.  For anyone unfamiliar with the franchise - this is a trilogy of games that each have 4-5 court cases within them, and you're usually playing as Phoenix Wright, the defense attorney trying to prove a client's innocence.  There are investigation segments and trial segments, and most of the gameplay involves choosing dialogue options and solving the mysteries primarily by finding contradictions in what people say.  The cases vary in how easy/hard, long/short, clever/convoluted they can be, but there are several real gems in the mix.  Each of the three games also has an understated arc related to one or more of the "regular" characters (generally one of the defense attorneys or prosecutors) that pulla a little bit from earlier cases into the later ones in the games.

And that's where the real joy of the game lies, because on another level this series is all about the major characters.  The regular and recurring ones - on both Phoenix's defense team and on the assorted prosecutors' side -  are wonderful, and you end up uncovering things about them as you work through the court cases.  What starts off looking like a goofy, over-the-top courtroom investigation ends up being a universe filled with people whose relationships to each other make you really care.  The one-off characters in the court cases can be idiotic, sometimes funny, sometimes interesting, and sometimes just annoying.  But the core characters throughout the trilogy (Phoenix, Edgeworth, Maya, Mia, Godot, etc.) are worth every minute spent learning their stories.

[h3]Opening Statement[/h3]
I discovered Ace Attorney game purely by chance, had never played before or watch any of its anime before but it left a lasting impression on me. I bought the game during sale and didn't have any high expectation for it. I'm a big fan of detective/mystery games and i figured why not give it a try as most of the review were positive and seems like It could be fun. I was immediately hooked on it and that's how I came to like the Ace Attorney series as a whole.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The Ace Attorney Trilogy features 3 separate games combined into one. The gameplay aspect is pretty basic and it is what you would expect from a visual novel. Most of the gameplay relies heavily on point and click and occasionally other formats. The storyline is also linear with one exception if i recall correctly on JFA Case 4 where you have the option to get the Bad Ending. Every chapter or case as some may refer to it are split into 2 parts. One is the [b]Investigation[/b] and the other is [b]Trial[/b]. The investigation is self explanatory as you move around the map to gather evidence before heading on to trial. If you have played any Danganronpa game before, it is similar to that. If I'm not mistaken you will need all clues before you can proceed to the trial sessions so don't worry on missing out on anything. For achievement hunters you may refer to online guides on it as some of it require you to trigger specific dialogue from the cast for it. The trial part is where things start to get more fun. No it is not the same as Danganronpa, close but no quite. The trial session consist of Cross-Examination where you would need to find contradictory points on the statement provided by the witness. The game is also not too easy nor is it too hard, it requires you to think carefully before presenting an answer. Sometimes you are also require to examine the clues provided carefully as not all of the descriptions are provided. The game is also not too punishing on its players, If you made a mistake you can either stick with it or just reload from the nearest save point of your choosing. Speaking of save, the game doesn't have auto-save but it does prompt for you to save once a section of the game has been completed but you are able to save as frequent as you like. The game also have some running jokes which I enjoyed but some are just too annoying for me but overall It does balance well between taking itself seriously and making jokes.

[h3]Graphics & Soundtrack[/h3]
The soundtrack of the game for me personally are amazing. I'm especially fond of Turnabout Sister & Turnabout Sister Ballad. The OST for the Cross-Examination and Objection! are also really good. They remix it a bit throughout the series whilst retaining its original feel to it therefore I think it is really well done. The game doesn't featured voice character therefore nothing much can be said regarding there except a few "Objection" line from the Main Characters. The graphics for the game are nothing to shout about as it is just remastered from the original 2001 - 2004 games but it does allow for 1080p resolution which is a plus in my opinion. The game does have few animations, nothing too fancy but it does its job conveying the emotional state that the characters are in. 

[h3]Closing Arguments[/h3]
As with every great game, it does suffer from few problems here and there however with Ace Attorney Trilogy I do feel that the problems are really minor that It doesn't ruin the entire gameplay. Some of the issue such as the screen shake can often be solved by turning it off. The game's story is good but not great with some minor plot conveniences and change of rules but it is a good game nonetheless. I highly recommend you try the game for yourself and if you're stuck you may look for walkthrough online. Overall I enjoyed the game and wish I could forget the game and play it from blank slate again as it is one of my favourite Detective game.

A great port of the original Ace Attorney game trilogy. Still a good set of games all these years later; wide cast of compelling and unique characters (and by god are they unique), some intriguing cases that have interesting twists and turns, and underlying stories and character arcs that range from hilarious to touching. 

The Ace Attorney games are a bit infamous for some "moon logic" sections, and it's true there are times where what is needed to progress is extremely unclear -- plus, in some cases, you can easily figure out solutions before the [i]characters[/i] do and are penalised if you try to follow that path too early. The game is very particular about the order of actions and When and How you talk to people or present evidence and such, and sometimes it doesn't do a great job of telling you what it wants from you at that precise moment. But it doesn't detract from the overall experience too much - saves can be made at almost any point without repercussions and the health mechanic when you make a mistake is fairly generous, and there are plenty of walkthroughs online if you get truly stuck and don't want to brute-force it.

Brilliant concept but just ended up falling flat for me.

Each case begins with the wandering the crime scene to collect clues. This is very tedious, lots of retracing steps and going back and forth to discover a handful of clues. There's no skill or puzzle aspect to it really, just talk to one person go and talk to someone else, who sends you back to the first one. Tedious, and by far the worst thing about the game. I found myself clicking around for long periods of time and feeling like nothing relevant was happening.

The meat of the game is the courtroom scene (which makes it such a shame that you'll spend more that half the time doing the 'explore the crime scene' padding). 
This is much more compelling, question suspects and then use evidence to catch them in contradictions. It's a great idea but can be frustrating. Sometimes you've worked out whodunnit too soon and you have to go through the motions before you can confront someone with the killer piece of evidence. Sometimes the contradictions aren't quite in the places you expect and you can find yourself brute-forcing it, not because you haven't worked out what's going on, but because you can't work out the precise moment to object.

I'd be able to overlook these flaws if it was all courtroom. But I just gave up at the the end of one case because I couldn't face over an hour of fetch quests and dialogue before I got to play the actual game.

A collection of soul, arranged in thoughtful and endearing puzzles.

Each of these games are fantastic, but it's how each culminate in their own climax that really defines them as legendary, and how the third takes every step of the journey and capitalizes on the lot that makes this trilogy a real masterpiece. I streamed this whole collection for my boyfriend- a lifelong Ace Attorney fan- and had an absolute blast every step of the way. The first two cases get you set off to a solid start in a journey that's as uplifting as it is devastating. Like the best legal dramas, many events, especially in the later games, are spun and kept in motion by larger than life characters, yet certain connecting threads keep them tied down to earth, their motives surprisingly base and human in satisfying confessions. 

By the end of this 70+ hour long story, I was really, really hoping it'd never end, and I always consider that the defining mark of a masterpiece. 

As golden and enduring as a well-worn badge.

This trilogy is a great way for newcomers to enjoy the first three Phoenix Wright games, each game is filled with compelling courtroom drama. The first three games roughly amount to a good 80 hours or more of gameplay, making this a great deal for Ace Attorney newbies. 

For returning players you get exactly what you expect, but with a fresh new look which has proven to be somewhat divisive within the fan base. I personally do not mind the new hand drawn character images, but I totally understand why someone would prefer the original sprites. I don't think too much is lost in the transition, but the charm the original games had is somewhat dampened by the new designs. The new graphical style isn’t bad or ugly, but there is an appeal to the original sprite work that could be argued is lost by the HD trilogy. It's up for you to decide which to play, but I love the convenience and pricing of this trilogy. It's perfect for most players.

As for the games themselves, they play as well as they did originally. For those unfamiliar with Phoenix Wright, all three games in the trilogy consist of unique cases, each of which last a few days in which you must collect evidence, speak to witnesses, present evidence in the courtroom and cross examine suspects. It's a fun gameplay loop that never gets old. Hearing Phoenix shout out OBJECTION! For the hundredth time when you finally nail a lying suspect is just a thrill. The music especially pumps you up during these moments.

And despite the games being pretty old, the cases still hold up remarkably well. There are some exceptions, like Turnabout Big Top which has some dodgy character writing surrounding a young love interest, but this is an exception. The majority of the cases are superb and this is down to the writing. It knows when to be funny, serious or even poignant. This trilogy is a very convenient package of three beloved games and is well worth it for anyone who enjoys a good adventure/visual novel.

If you don't know what you do in this game, you are Phoenix Wright, defense attorney at law. Your job is to prove your client's innocence before the court in a judicial system that is beyond weighted against the defendant. The system is based on japanese courts with a healthy dose of fiction and translator shenanigans thrown in for good measure, so if you know law then this won't exactly be a work-sim.
In court you hear testimony and cross-examine witnesses. It is mostly a logic puzzle to figure out inconsistencies in the witness' story and to get more information, while not making baseless conjectures or trying to prove something without proper evidence. You aren't using courtroom strategies or trying to plead to a (non-existent) jury for lighter sentencing. You are getting a full acquittal while providing the actual culprit or the electric chair (because it's always a murder case, somehow) for your client.
Outside of court you are snooping around crime scenes, finding evidence, talking to witnesses and others, [spoiler]and doing your best to not get killed by the prosecution, the murderer, a monkey, guilt or any other random individual, object or concept wanting to obstruct justice.[/spoiler] It is more or less an easy point-and-click game with some deduction going on.

That description might not sell it to you, but most of the cases have very intriguing twists and turns, and the two different styles of gameplay work together very well. While in court you make mental notes of who you want to hear from more and what to investigate further in the free-time, and while out sleuthing you are putting together theories to test in the courtroom.
It's not perfect. There are a fair few leaps of logic that make little sense, both for your case and just how they relate to anything. There are also quite a few coincidences and contrivances that make for bad cases (the vase in From the Ashes and the entirety of Big Top come to mind). But despite these things, I would say that these are fantastic games. Despite the previously mentioned issues, From the Ashes is my favorite case in the trilogy. A solid purchase at even non-discounted price.

A GREAT STORY 9/10
some problems in details, still good enough.

I am at the mercy of the writer's thought processes. Such as, Episode #2, I have an autopsy that says the murder occurred at 9pm. A supposed witness was busy at 9pm. Therefore, this should negate the witness testimony to the murder, or at least, exact times mattered in Episode #1 so I assumed exact times mattered in Episode #2, but they didn't. So I couldn't figure out what evidence the game wanted me to present. It's hard to make a game like this work when there are multiple arguments to be made and the player has to attempt to get into the mind of the writers. Kind of annoyed right now. 

Plus, this is a bunch of just click here and save this piece of info, click there, okay, maybe it's evidence, but you won't know it until the game reveals it in the story. Case in point. Episode #2: You acquire a receipt as evidence. What does the receipt say??? Well, the game doesn't let you examine the receipt so you are at the mercy of the story which decides to finally use the receipt as plot armor to save your case by revealing what it says.

Characters are fun tho, and I'm going to keep playing but I can't recommend such a linear title. This truly is a visual novel, not a game. I was going to refund it, but Steam said I had played for 76 minutes at 10:40pm so I figured I'd finish out Episode #2. Anyways, at 10:58pm when I finished Episode #2, Steam said I had played for 2.1hrs, and thus, outside the return window! NOW THERE"S A CASE TO SOLVE>

So I am stuck here with an okay game, and I'm trying to beat all games I own so here i am playing for a couple 40 hours more.

::Update::

Oof, Episode #3 is getting very long in the tooth. Why does every witness have to revise their testimony 3 or 4 times? Like I don't feel like I am doing anything other than pressing "Q" to Press the witness. Also, most decisions given by the game lead to the same path/answer so that's ULTRA Lame. I even tried accepting that a possible murderer had no motive for killing someone, and the game said, "NOOOOO!!!!, SHE GAWDDAMM DID IT. YOU HAVE TO COME UP WITH SOME BULLCRAP MOTIVE TO PROVE SHE DID IT."  And thus, the game looped me into the witness's testimony again, even tho I didn't really care b/c I had proved my client's innocence and so I didn't care what this other person did. Not my case . Not my problem. Well, except in this game it became my problem b/c you know it's a video ga... ::cough:: VISUAL NOVEL ::cough cough::

a nice collection of three quality games! i played ace attorney on the nintendo ds maybe five or so years ago for the first time, and when i saw this collection available on steam, i scooped it up quickly. overall, i think a lot of people would enjoy playing this trilogy, including some people who would not consider themselves "traditional gamers."

[b]overview:[/b]
the ace attorney trilogy has a lot of entertaining characters, fun cases, and engaging mysteries. the gameplay loop tends to be pretty consistent throughout: there has been a murder and then you alternate between collecting clues while investigating and putting those clues together during the trial segments. there is a lot of reading (i think the only spoken dialogue i remember is when someone yells "OBJECTION!" which, come on, is great), but i wouldn't classify these games strictly as visual novels since they do require a lot of player input and problem solving. 

[b]possible negatives:[/b]
- one thing i found irritating at times was how you move between areas when investigating. from your current location you have specific, limited locations you can travel to. as the cases develop and you will unlock more and more places to visit. trying to go to a certain area may mean passing through three or four other locations along the way just to get to the new spot. since there isn't any type of map to show you which areas are connected (if i am wrong, please let me know!), sometimes you are blindly clicking between areas to find the one you need, or even worse, you don't realize there is a new area to go to.
- i'm sure this will be a very controversial potential negative, but i felt this collection may be too long(!), particularly if you don't want to do so much reading or you find the gameplay loop to be anything less than enthralling. i started playing this mid 2019 and finished it late 2022. after finishing the first game in the trilogy, which added an extra case that the ds version did not have, i felt a bit burned out and needed a break. when i came back to the collection, by the time i got to the third game (trials & tribulations) i realized i was somewhat mentally checked out, not because the game quality was lacking, but because it was just so much content. it took me 67 hours to finish everything, which qualifies as a very long game for me. i'm sure some people will love that this collection is so long, and people who qualify game purchases by the "$1=1 hour of gameplay" will be ecstatic. again, i don't think there were any bad cases, but at a point i just wanted to be done with the ace attorney trilogy.
- lastly, i did have a graphical glitch at times where some of the text was dark grey instead of white, which made it hard to read against a dark background. this didn't happen very often, and it seemed pretty random.

[b]in conclusion:[/b]
basically everything else the game had to offer was a positive! i don't regret my time with the phoenix wright: ace attorney trilogy, and i do think i will check out other ace attorney games in due time.

Better Call Saul references aside, this is a fairly decent game; basically just remasters of the DS games. I never really played this series when it originally came out in the States (I played Professor Layton instead; which is kind of how I indirectly found out about this series via hearing about the game "Professor Layton vs Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney" for 3DS); however, you're getting three games for the price of one; would you rather have spent $105 (the average price of a new DS game back then was $35) on the three games back in the 2000s or $30 for three games in this one package now?

Overall, if you're interested in a visual novel game with a little bit of thinking involved, this game is for you. Just remember to save your game ([spoiler]especially at the end of case 4 of Justice for All, otherwise you get a secret achievement[/spoiler]).

I played this game in my early twenties and it was a formative experience, to say the least. It's immersive and gritty, but camp and fun at the same time. The characters are wonderful, from protagonists to BBEGs. Even the "boring" characters have a spark. The stories and ethical dilemmas played out are complex and the way they connect is crazy. Then there's the aspect of it being satirical criticism of the Japanese court systems (which pretty much covers every time you'd want to cry, 'wait, isn't that unrealistic?!' yes. Yes it is, like a satire of judicial systems should be).

I know it is on gaming platforms, but approach this as a cross between a movie and a book with some puzzling to do, not a literal 'game'. You will enjoy it more for what it is that way. (This should be obvious given that it is a VN, but I think some people forget what a *novel* is.)

Anyway.

The original Phoenix Wright trilogy is a fantastic collection of some fantastic visual novels. They're not perfect, of course, but all 3 games in this collection tell great stories with a broad cast of characters who are (mostly) all charming and endearing. The remastered graphics have their pros and cons, as they do look nicer than the original sprites on the GameBoy Advance/DS, but the animations have lost many frames as a result, making them significantly less smooth and fluid.

If you like some good mysteries or quirky yet compelling characters, absolutely give these games a try; they provide a great package of adventures across all 3 titles.

A fun visual novel kind of game with a lovely Japanese art style and fun characters. The game consists of a series of short stories - each one is a different court case. Your role is to interview people, obtain information, find evidence, and then use it in court to establish the truth and protect your clients. You'll need to use logic and think outside the box to get those wins. Each story is split in to chapters for convenience, and you can save when you want so it's ideal for casual players that have limited time. I recommend this game for lovers of both puzzles and visual novels!

It's like Perry Mason, Columbo, and an anime VN had a baby and that baby was a Capcom game. Corny jokes, some great twists and turns, and it makes you feel like an Ace Attorney when you get some lying SOB on the ropes by BTFOing them with FACTS AND LOGIC.

It does kinda sag in the middle with JFA, but it picks right back up in its final arc. I will say that it can be frustratingly video gamey in when/how you're supposed to present evidence. Like if you know Person A couldn't have given Person B McGuffin X, because you have it in your pocket, you may have to wait several times to press them into clarifying what exactly it was, who exactly they were going to give it to, and what their mother's maiden name was before you can FINALLY present the evidence. But of course there are guides in case you get stuck and only want to enjoy the story, which is kinda the whole point.

As an added bonus, there are a few bits of evidence that are straight out of specific mystery stories, which I thought was neat.

I now realize it was a mistake to wait so long to play Ace Attorney. As of the third case for the first game, I do not regret my purchase whatsoever - the writing is sharp, funny, and perpetually surprising, and I can't help but find that the game constantly puts a smile on my face. I would highly recommend it to anybody who is vaguely interested in the series but has never played it yet (and presumably if you're a fan, it's worth it too).

This game is beautiful! The plot of every case is threaded so carefully and perfectly so that you are always speculating about the truth as you play through - this gives the game a really exciting feel. The dialogue is really well-written. Some of the cases have investigation stages that drag on a little bit. In particular I found this to be the case for Chapter 3 in Justice for All (the second game). However with a total of 14 chapters to play across the trilogy, there are so many preposterous but clever cases to solve, and the game is like no other.

Okay, so, I may have ended up wading through most of this game with the help of an online guide, I'll admit that. Ironically, what first brought me to the guide wasn't the trials, but the investigations. I got stuck with not knowing where to go or who to talk to and what to present to them at a couple points. And when I did use it in trials, in most cases, I had some idea of what point I wanted to make, I just wasn't sure on what statement or in which order to present things. And yes, when presenting evidence, the statement you present on matters: something that initially surprised me. Even if two statements are related or two halves of one sentence, don't expect them both to be valid present points! I'd recommend saving often if you don't want to use a guide.

With that fact admitted, I still have to say that I really enjoyed getting to play these classic games. It's not surprising at all that Phoenix Wright and company get their place in pop culture: they earned it. I really hope that some of the later games get a turn at being updated and ported to Steam, although it seems unlikely. Hey, Capcom, if you're reading this...well, probably not. But if you are, great job. It takes skill to make games that can still hold water years later, still be enjoyable to someone younger than the games. Well done.

After watching someone play through to the first halve of the second case, I was intrigued. The game looked like it had good humor and was fun to play, and I was absolutely right. I don't usually audibly laugh at games, but Ace Attorney is one of those few, and that's why I love it so much. Every character is perfectly designed to fit their personality, on top of that there designs are so recognizable and vibrant.

Ace Attorney games are visual novels, but I'd argue that they are puzzle games filled with amazing stories. You can't skip all the dialogue to get through faster, because the game will give you a question that you have to present a piece of evidence for. Multiple times you have to stop and think, "how did that happen" and come up with a reasonable explanation (mostly reasonable). The story across the three games, without going into to much detail, is perfect and mesh so well together. Characters go through arcs that perfectly go alongside the court cases. You get filled with so many questions that are all seamlessly answered by the end.

This is three great games in one great package, and they all fit so well as a trilogy. If you're interested in Ace Attorney, this is the game to get. It's a great first game for Ace Attorney and is well worth it.

I somehow never got to play any Ace Attorney games in my childhood. While I knew all the memes - OBJECTION - it took me more than a quarter decade to whip out the AA trilogy. Overall, they are great games that are fully deserving of its loyal fanbase. And to take it away straight away: [b]I highly recommend to buy the trilogy![/b] But this does not mean that it is a perfect game either...

[list]
[*][b] Story:[/b] Most stories from the first three games are standalone side stories, but some cases are actually linked to each other. Those cases that actually have an impact on the world are by far the best. Unluckily, the writing for each case varies in quality significantly.
[*][b] Gameplay:[/b] Click-puzzle-game. I would not even call it gameplay - it is a visual novel after all. I am curious how many books equal those three games, but one thing is for sure: Binging more than one case in one sitting is really tough. And even playing through one case in one sitting is not the easiest. But maybe it's just cause I do not have the fresh attention span of a teenager anymore.
[*][b] Visuals:[/b] Quite unique splasharts for each character. While the art is not of high quality, I got used to it pretty fast. Nothing to add here.
[*][b] Characters:[/b] Obnoxious. Look, there were some characters which I really liked: Ace, Mia, Edgeworth, Maya, Pearly...the main cast was likeable. Even Franziska with her one-dimensional gimmick grew on me. But holy...the one-off cast was god awful most of the time. Against his best efforts, Butz did not ruin 1-4 and 3-5. I know that it is rather cartoony, but the side cast is so one-dimensional and it is just annoying. There is no need to have a second comedy-act when you already have Gumshoe as well. It was too much. This in turn means that cases with actually decent and more complex (as much as it is possible) personalities are immediately waaay better (2-4, 3-5, 1-5, etc.). And that is the kicker that bothered me from time to time. It is really hard to read novels of text from characters that are just not likeable.
[*][b] Enjoyment:[/b] I am glad that I played the games! The fond memories of the good cases will remain. Weirdly enough, I am apperently in the small minority that thinks that the second game was really good and actually better than the third one which was solely saved by the last case - linked with references from 3-1 and 3-4. Big Top was not as bad as people say it is and 2-2 and 2-4 are both in my Top 5 easily. I just hope I can block out the god awful cases soon enough. I do recommend the trilogy but comparing it to Danganronpa the characters as well as the writing are far worse. AA often has really anticlimactic reveals after which you still have to play for an hour. Danganronpa hit the plot twist element way better. Or do you have any objections to that?
[/list]

I know this review is basically pointless, as there are an abundance of positive reviews for this game already, but there's a good reason for that: these games are amazing.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney:
While not as innovative as its successors, this game is the perfect introduction into this bizarre world of anime lawyers, desk abuse and courtroom carelessness. In this game Phoenix Wright and his friends must face a dangerous threat: sarcasm! (If you're an actual lawyer, deliberately fail the bar exam before playing this). 

Courtroom sections are the highlight of the game, as investigation sections are just *trial* and error, as you present every piece of evidence to people in the hope that they have something even remotely interesting to say about it. Courtroom sections are, basically, an anime battle between a law school drop-out and a fancy dressing, rule-bending courtroom dictator who are in a race to convince the judge that the other's argument is baseless conjecture. 

Speaking of the judge, he's best described as a baboon who snuck into the courthouse, stole a gavel and decided the prosecutors were the coolest kids on the block. This game is great and is a perfect introduction to Phoenix Wright's struggles to be taken seriously.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Justice For All:
This game continues the story of our kooky main cast in an excellent fashion. This time they have a new obstacle in their path: the full titles of their personage! The new additions to the cast are great and fit right in with J'Murica's run-down, ridiculous and inconsistent excuse for a legal system. (Now's probably a good time to mention, that, because of localisation choices, these games have a desire to be in America which doesn't quite fit with the original Japanese setting. Hence: J'Murica). 

There's a new gamplay mechanic that spices up investigation sections to make them just as interesting as courtroom section. (Although, courtroom sections are still more fun). This game is great, although, the first is maybe a smidge better. However, this is still an amazingly fun ride through Phoenix Wright's attempts to look like a competent lawyer

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Trials and Tribulations:
This game concludes the story of Phoenix Wright and his gang of idiotic companions as they face their most terrifying challenge yet, the spawn of the devil itself: coffee! The new gameplay mechanic introduced in the previous game has been perfected here and it's almost as good as the courtroom sections, now.

There isn't much to say about this game other than it expands on the formula from the previous 2 in ridiculously creative ways. This game is amazing and truly earns its reputation as the best in the series. Strap yourself in for a fantastic ride as Phoenix Wright tries, for the final time, to convince the world that he's worthy of his cereal-box acquired attorney's badge.

[h1]Is Edgeworth Gay?[/h1]
Section 5A:

Yes.

Section 5B:

Just kidding, I do have actual reasoning behind this.

i) Edgeworth Isn’t Attracted to Women

It’s pretty obvious that whenever Edgeworth interacts with, is flirted with, or is approached by women attempting to flirt with him, his reactions to their flirting range from indignant to completely oblivious. Women who are noted in-universe to be particularly attractive have absolutely no effect on him: from April May, to Angel Starr, to Dahlia Hawthorne, any and every female character who relies on charm or capturing the attention of men find a brick wall in Edgeworth. About the only woman whose affections he notices is Oldbag, and that’s only because she’s… well, Oldbag. He’s somewhere between apprehensive and confused at learning he has female admirers, wondering if he “really inspires such frothing desire from the female masses” in Bridge to the Turnabout.

This is especially notable in his own games, particularly Turnabout Airlines, where we are given gems such as “Oh, now I get it. Maybe you’ve ‘got your eye’ on Ms Rhoda…” “Of course I’m keeping an eye on her. I can’t very well let her escape, can I?” “Never mind…”, “I can’t think of a single reason why I’d want to buy you anything,” (addressed to a woman who literally wears her flight attendant uniform open to seduce the pilot) and a particular comment about the female flight attendants’ room: “One would think that [women’s] perfume ‘smells great’, however, to me it simply smells… not that I have any interest in what lies behind this door.” The comment in English can be read as him just disliking the smell of perfume, but the way the Japanese version is phrased was interpreted by many fans as not just being disinterested in perfume, but women in general.

The only time Edgeworth has ever shown even remote interest in any woman is during his Takarazuka musical, which, as I have stressed earlier, is absolutely obligated to have the protagonist in a m/f romance. Hell, the romance itself is far less prominent than in other Takarazuka plays; the woman in question doesn’t even kiss him, simply giving him a rose which he keeps to the end of the play, and the traditional couple’s dance at the end of the play is given to a different pair of characters.

So, Edgeworth is definitely not interested in women. That leaves us with two broad possibilities: he is aroace (not to be confused with asexual, which refers to lack of sexual attraction and still connotes the possibility of romantic love; aroace is a term referring to those who experience neither romantic nor sexual attraction), or he is gay.

 

ii) Edgeworth Is Attracted to Men

Now this is the point of contention. Is Edgeworth gay or European disinterested in romance entirely? Surprisingly, there’s far more evidence for the first possibility than you’d think.

Returning to Turnabout Airlines, talking to the (male) passenger surrounded by bottles gives you this exchange: the passenger asks “How about it? How about a glass together?” and Edgeworth, without a second thought, assumes he is the one getting hit on- and responds with an uncharacteristically polite “Um, sorry, but I must decline.” There is literally no other flirtatious interaction which Edgeworth responds to with such awareness and civility. He doesn’t even notice Rhoda’s crush on him for the entire case! The passenger, on his part, replies “I wasn’t talking to you! I was asking the cute attendant!”. A case later, he also seems to react to Agent Lang taunting him and calling him a “pretty boy”, but makes little effort to discourage him from doing so.

Then, of course, there is the marriage conversation in SoJ’s DLC. People seem to believe this is a one-hit-kill of any and all Edgeworth ships. It is not. The line about wishing to remain unwed is almost exactly the same in the Japanese version, and in Japan, there is still no such thing as same-sex marriage. If the writers had been attempting to convey that he is simply uninterested in romance, why not just have him say that he has no intention of falling in love, ever? (It’s also important to note that we are never given a statement on whether same-sex marriage even exists in Japanifornia. As it stands, Ace Attorney’s semi-fictional hybrid country resembles Japan somewhat more than it resembles California; who’s to say same-sex marriage does exist there? Criminal law, at least, follows Japanese convention. We’ve never seen a canonical married gay couple in modern-day Japanifornia. It’s sad to say, but it’s a fair bet that as it stands, two men can’t get married in the Ace Attorney universe.)

Also- and I think I mentioned this earlier, but I’ll say it again- Edgeworth only ever objects to the prospect of “getting married”. Sure, he’s irritated by Phoenix trying to bring up the power of love as evidence in a court of law, but his refutations revolve around the idea of him getting married and “settling down” (i.e. starting a family with a woman), not the idea of falling in love. It is marriage, and heterosexual marriage in particular, which disinterests him.

Not to mention that from a more subjective standpoint of queer-coding, Edgeworth hits several boxes for stereotypes. While this is obviously ineffective at determining someone’s sexuality in real life, giving fictional characters certain traits can be viewed as a hint towards their sexuality- like a certain hairstyle on a lesbian or a piercing in a certain ear for a gay man. Bearing in mind that this is Suekane, an experienced BL artist, that we’re talking about- she knew what she was doing.

Edgeworth wears nothing but pink and frills, and clearly takes interest in the way he looks. He solves a murder in his manga series simply by judging a girl’s choice in shoes. In terms of Japanese culture, he slots right into the “bishonen” stereotype, what English-speakers would call a “pretty boy” (and, as Suekane had experience with yaoi- which bishonen frequently overlaps with- this was probably intentional). He’s noted in-universe to be particularly attractive, but he barely notices girls and has clearly never dated one. To me, his narrative of growing up in a strict household like von Karma’s also has a certain resonance with the narrative of the closet. All in all, he fits pretty solidly into the stereotype of a gay character. Again, none of this is proof he is gay; someone can check all these boxes and more and still be straight. But combined with all the evidence above… Edgeworth being coded specifically as a gay man is the most logical conclusion.

Okay, so Edgeworth’s gay. Is Phoenix bisexual? …Honestly, we have no hard evidence one way or the other. We’ve only ever really seen him be attracted to women, but those instances are relatively few and far between; he notices people like April and Angel, was definitely in love with Dahlia/Iris, and has crushes on a few girls in the casebooks. On the other hand, he doesn’t seem to be particularly heteronormative; he pretty clearly thought Lana and Mia had dated, is quite confident when he declares White and Grossberg must be lovers, and easily picks up on Max flirting with him in Big Top (although his reaction is, understandably, one of disgust.) Bisexual people can be anywhere on the Kinsey scale, and were Phoenix to be confirmed or hinted to be bisexual he would be no exception. And, of course, there’s the way he interacts with Edgeworth.

Ultimately, neither of these characters’ sexualities have been confirmed. It’s pretty likely that Edgeworth is gay; it is not impossible for Phoenix to be bisexual. Sexuality, therefore, is in no way a hurdle for Narumitsu.

[h1] Ace Attorney: A hidden masterpiece. [/h1]

 A highly entertaining game with a compelling cast and a hooking plot. The trilogy follows Phoenix Wright, a newbie defense attorney and our protagonist, as he grows into a great lawyer by unravelling mysteries, saving lives, wining trials and making friends.
 The games' mechanics are really simple, they resemble a mouse-only puzzle-like sort of game, where your greatest skill is your wits and not how many headshots you can get. Their simplicity allows for any type of player to enjoy them, yet they are not dull and thanks to all the thinking involved and the evolution of the gameplay, hardly feel repetitive.
 Nevertheless, the main factor of these games are its stories. Interesting cases, thought-provoking dilemmas, character development, fun investigations, dynamic trials, humorous dialogues. In terms of writing, this games have it all. The identity of this trilogy is clearly defined and if it is to your liking, you are sure to become a fan.
 Unluckily, Capcom has seem to have abandoned Spanish speaking communities, but for those who are able to access this content I pray you give it a chance. Although this may not be the kind of game that we are used to at present, it is an unforgettable champion in its unique genre. A game that could easily be forgotten because of its age and outdated playability; a masterpiece that is good enough to be kept alive by avid fans and thunderstruck newcomers that have fallen in love with this rare marvel.

Yes, my username is based on Ace Attorney. Yes, I will be biased (but I do have a criticism too!)

I played this trilogy originally on the Nintendo DS. Honestly, I prefer the DS version because I think the graphics look more authentic, but other than that and the achievements, the DS version and this version are identical. This is a great, cheaper alternative to play the series without trying to get a DS and grab the DS titles.

I purchased this game solely for the achievements and being able to have an Ace Attorney background, honestly. Judge all you like, I'm obsessed. So, I did wait for a sale because as someone who played the game before, I did not think it was worth full retail price. it IS worth full retail price if you've never played before.

What can I say about this game?

Story: legendary, keeps you on the edge of your seat, has twists and turns you don't see coming, keeps you invested (I laughed, cried and gasped throughout my original playthrough and it takes a lot for media to invoke emotion in me)

Characters: Colorful, intricate, interesting, unforgettable (even the secondary characters or characters that are barely shown/used)

Music: Iconic (I still listen to it casually on Spotify to this day)

Puzzles/Problem Solving: Well, about that...

My only criticism of this series as a whole is the puzzle solving. This game progresses very particularly. You may have figured out the case before the game really allows you to. Only certain evidence, statements, and examining will move you forward, even if you're ahead of the game logically. When I first played the series, I found myself saying "Oh, c'mon!" and "Really??" because I had figured out things faster than the game thought I would or didn't understand the logic the game was using and I was stuck until I pressed every statement, presented all evidence, and examined EVERYTHING.

For example (a spoiler free example): One character requests a script. I know exactly where to find it. I go there, but the game will not allow me to grab it and take it back until I show another character a memo asking for a script. Only THEN can I go back, grab the script, and take it back to the character who requested it.

And that's an example where it was actually easy to figure out the sequence of events. It's not always that easy.

But honestly, I managed to overlook that for just how original and fantastic this series is. It was still satisfying to finally figure out the mystery and move the story along.

Get this game. I think if you like murder mysteries and/or story heavy gameplay, you'll adore this cult classic.

A masterpiece Trilogy with incredible writing, a killer soundtrack that's had me addicted for years, and tons of heart and soul put into every little detail. I played this game for the first time on the iOS Trilogy version and this is literally the best they could have possibly done outside of a complete rewrite to fix some of the continuity errors, logical leaps, and plot holes. There's no game on the planet I would recommend more if you are a fan of page-turning novels and stories than this one. The insight into the problems with the Japanese legal system creates some of the most unique, suspenseful moments a book or visual novel about lawyers going to court could ever produce. 

This isn't an accurate representation of an American court system, because of legal issues such as Conflict of Interest, evidence law and the rights of the accused spelled out in the Constitution. They would ruin any chance of a majority of the events in this story occurring the way they do in-game. The game is set in a bizarro Los Angeles mixed up with tons of Japanese culture (if you are playing the English version - I assume it's localized differently with other language settings), so it's important to keep in mind that the original trilogy of games were originally created and developed in Japan for the GBA back in the first half of the 2000s (2001 for AA, 2002 for JFA and 2004 for T&T). The games were not released outside of Japan until the DS remake of the first game that added the Rise from the Ashes to the case roster of that game. (Note: Rise from the Ashes was written after the completion of the first three games, so in order to truly appreciate it, I recommend newcomers to complete it after the final case in the original trilogy, as it contains little references here and there that you will only pick up on after playing the full trilogy first.) Thus, the game was meant to be a parody of the Japanese legal system, in which the game goes out of its way to highlight its many faults. As the series progressed, however, standards such as the Three-Day trial system and Prosecutors having the advantage became key to the identity of the series. In other words, even with the 3DS games' slightly less quality writing and story direction, it still maintains the identity and original message of the Trilogy. They still look to this game for its roots, even if they have tried to expand the AA universe in some interesting ways. 

That's what's so amazing about this Trilogy. It established a world, a legacy, for these characters to live and breathe in. The characters in this story are real. They have struggles and triumphs just like all of us. These games have changed the way I see the world and the people around me. I always try to maintain an open mind and think rationally through heated, emotional situations like the game teaches you to. I've learned to become more of a critical thinker, and less reliant on impressions and gut feelings. This game changes you, and you will never see the world the same once you click the next button on the final piece of dialogue. I'm so happy to get to relive this Trilogy again in with such beautiful, clean-looking visuals. They even fixed huge issues that plagued the iOS port, such as the speed of the text and animations, and especially noticeable was how they fixed some of the music differences back to their original states in the DS versions. I blitzed through this game because I had my tonsils removed and I was in the mood for a trip down memory lane. I do not regret one minute of this, and I even got 100% of the achievements, which I highly recommend because there are no other completion requirements if you are a completionist like me. There are even detailed guides for the games in the Guides section for the game if you are stuck and need help with story triggers, contradictions or achievements, which are the three most commonly reported "stuck points". I highly recommend trying to get into the game's mindset and figure things out on your own, as it will help with your critical thinking skills and ultimately help you become a better player, but there is no shame if you get super stuck. 

If you want to continue this series after you are done, I recommend playing the series chronologically. That means playing Ace Attorney Investigations 1 and 2 FIRST before Apollo Justice since they are between T&T and AJ. There are many ways to play the later DS games in the series (DS, 3DS, iOS), and both 3DS games (Dual Destinies, which is next after AJ, followed by Spirit of Justice) are available on iOS and 3DS (duh). The Professor Layton crossover is sadly 3DS exclusive, and Investigations 2 has had no official English release. Luckily, there are English Patches online you can apply to legally acquired copies of AAI2. Search up Ace Attorney Investigations 2 English Patch for AAI2. The Great Ace Attorney Chronicles is a duology set a century before the events of the trilogy, and I highly recommend checking out the collection now that it is out on Steam and consoles.

Thank you Ace Attorney for consistently being one of the best game franchises, and I look forward to many more years of Objections and puzzling cases as the Handheld and Consoles merge and technology continues to grow. At least we know Phoenix will always carry around his trusty old-fashioned cellular phone, no matter how crazy mobile devices get.

I've completed it recently. 
It took two years actually. I loved the first instalment but was a bit weary of all the brain juice used in searching and reading that I took a break and played other action games. 

My only complaint is that, sometimes the trial dialogue is a bit hidden. 

Example: 
You have 5 statements and you press on every one of them. And you think you had unlocked all dialogue and wonder what you're missing. 

Turns out that you have to press on the 4th statement, and go back to the 2nd statement to press again.

The writing is quite good and most of the mysteries are engaging.
The trial mechanics can sometimes feel a bit tedious. There were times when I understood what conclusion I was supposed to draw, but not quite how the game wanted me to show my work through the cross/evidence.
Personally, I would rank the games in the following order: 1 > 3 >> 2.

You know, I was gonna watch the anime and not bother with the game at first, but after browsing through reddit, mal and some other anime forums, it became clear that the game was far better than the anime. So I decided to buy this game during a sale where it was 50%, so for 20$ and I gave it a try. I've finished the first three chapters and currently on the fourth and let me tell you, this game is so fucking worth paying for, even if it's not on sale and you have to buy it for 40$. 

The music is just so good. It has that nostalgic feel, it helps with setting the scenes and it evokes a lot of different emotions from you. But the big part is definitely the story. It keeps you hooked from the very first scene all the way to the very end of the case for each chapter. The detective like gameplay where you try to find clues while talking to people and going to places really keeps your attention. The characters are also just so iconic and unforgettable. Phoenix Wright, Miles Edgeworth, Mia and Maya Fey, the judge and so on. It's a joy to be around them and they each have their own little quirks and surprises. 

Overall, I think it's worth paying 40$ for this game, but if you want to save money, wait until a sale comes by. But whatever you do, you are 100% going to enjoy this game

[h1]“A lawyer only cries once it’s all over.”[/h1]

[h2][u]Opening Statement[/u][/h2]
[i]Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy[/i] (PW:AAT) is a rerelease of the first three games in the Phoenix Wright series that debut in the early 2000’s. Somehow, I managed to avoid the games in these past two decades and thus I have no nostalgia for the series. All I really knew of the series was “Objection!” and “lol lawyer game”. This is a review from the perspective of someone playing this classic for the first time. I stand before the judge and jury today to make the case for why it is a great game that still holds up today.

[h2][u]Evidence #1: Gameplay [/u][/h2]
PW:AAT is a visual novel with logic and deduction puzzles to navigate through the story. As a visual novel, the game has a lot of text and thus requires the player to do a lot of reading. However, the text is accompanied by various characters, their animations, and beautiful backdrops. It feels more at times like an interactive anime set in a whacky court-room drama and investigations held at the scenes of crime.

That said, this lawyer game does not stand up to scrutiny when cross-examined by actual lawyers. The player has to keep in mind that this is a fictional world, an odd mix of the USA and Japan, that follows its own set of rules for court procedure. In this world, the system is heavily slanted against the defense (a satirical commentary on Japan’s legal system, apparently). As the player is the defense, this is also for the sake of gameplay and challenge. There just wouldn’t be much game nor entertainment if the court was realistic.

Each game is divided into cases; a crime happens and you must defend the prime suspect. After such an opening scene, the case then plays out in alternating phases. During the investigation phase, the player travels from scene to scene to gather clues and talk to witnesses. Then there is the trial phase where the case proceeds to the court room. This is where the game isn’t very realistic but it makes for intriguing gameplay.  Each case starts with the prosecution making their case and they drive the court as they call witnesses and pull never-seen-before evidence out of their asses. It is your job to scrutinize witness testimony. Press them when they are being vague and provide evidence that contradicts their testimony and exposes lies. This is why I suggest the game is more of a logic and deduction puzzle game. Aside from the witness testimony, there are other times where the player is prompted to make choices or provide evidence to paint a scenario of what may have actually happened. 

[h2][u]Evidence #2: Characters[/u][/h2]
This wonderful whacky world has so many interesting characters and really bring the game, and especially the court, to life. At minimum, there is always Phoenix Wright (the player), an assistant, the accused, the judge, and the prosecutor. There are also usually the detective and multiple witnesses to interact with. They are all very much their own characters and have their own personality. 

However, with such variety, the characters are not all winners. Many characters are written with a defining gimmick. If that gimmick falls flat, it’s really hard to recover and the character may just be annoying and grating rather than endearing. For example, one character’s shtick seems to be bringing a whip to the court room and whipping the entire courtroom. It was funny at first, more so due to the others reactions at the absurdity. But the joke would not stop. The game really has a bad habit of beating a dead horse with their jokes sometimes. There is also an uncomfortable amount of other anime tropes like old men perving on women. It’s gross at times.
Objection! Despite those flaws, I still feel there is a net positive of great characters. While there are some characters that fall flat, the ones that remain strong are really good. There is not a single case I dislike even when there was a lot of screentime for a character that got on my nerves. This was largely due to a great story and amazing characters carrying it on their backs. Phoenix Wright himself is a worthy star who grows from an inexperienced rookie lawyer to an attorney on a quest to determine what justice and being a defense attorney really means to him. It’s sort of like an anime coming of age story with a lawyer as the hero.

[h2][u]Evidence #3: Story[/u][/h2]
The trilogy follows Phoenix Wright and his growth as a lawyer. I was pleasantly surprised by how much the games cases and story flowed together. This truly feels like a trilogy and not just three standalone games. Yet they could easily be played on their own as well. I recommend playing the games in order for the best flow.

The first case always acts as a tutorial and is both shorter and easier to solve. In the middle are cases designed to either foreshadow or hint future overall plot development for the game or even the whole trilogy – or to build up character development for the same reason. The final case of each game is truly remarkable. If ever the game feels tiring due to an obnoxious character, it’s worth pushing on to the final case. They are that good and still resonate with me even after finishing the games.

One minor gripe is the over-use of flashbacks. Even the game made fun of itself at one point when a character asked, “Do you remember when X” and the witness replied, “yes, it was five minutes ago.” This might be a fault of myself binging through the series but it was annoying at times to be constantly reminded of past cases or events that were still fresh on my mind.

Objection! That said, the use of flashbacks is still also nice as it really highlights how much the various events and cases throughout the series interweave with one another to make an overarching narrative for the whole trilogy. The third game is especially heavy on story with a fantastic finish that left me satisfied with the ending.

[h2][u]Kudos[/u][/h2]
- Can save pretty much anytime
- Great characters and developments
- Super fun mysteries to figure out

[h2][u]Objections[/u][/h2]
- Over-use of flashbacks 
- Some annoying character quirks
- THAT STUPID ROTATING JAR

[h2][u]Specs[/u][/h2]
Game runs fine.

Operating System: Windows 10
Processor (CPU): Intel Core i5-3570K CPU @3.40GHz
Graphics Card (GPU): NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1070
Memory (RAM) 16 GB

[h2][u]Case Summary[/u][/h2]
This is three games in one which is already great value for the price. If you’re a fan of visual novels at all, or if an interactive anime with murder mysteries sounds fun, then this is definitely a game for you. If you do not like reading and crave intense action experience, then this should be avoided. That said – this game does get tense when you get into the story. After playing this game you will feel like you’re ready for law school. You won’t be, because its not realistic at all. But it’s the heart that counts. And this game is full of it. Absolutely love it and I sincerely hope the sequels come to Steam next. After all, a lawyer only cries once it’s all over, and I’m not out of tears yet.

A fantastic mystery/detective visual novel mixed with a courtroom drama. 

The collection contains the first three original games from the Nintendo DS, each containing about four to five chapters. The games being "Ace Attorney", "Justice for All", and "Trials and Tribulations".  You work your way through court proceedings, attempting to discern fact from fib, uncover evidence from the scene of the crime, question witness testimonies, and most importantly, uncover the truth of what really happened. 

The only real complaint I have is that the solutions for some of the puzzles are truly headscratching. A majority of the time, you're not expected to remember any fine details, and anything you do need to know/remember is logged in the Court Record for your convinence. But even then, some of the solutions present in some of the trials felt a little far fetched for my logic. As a result, save scumming until I eventually just brute forced the right answer occured a few times. Thankfully this seemed to be an exception, as for the most part I've been able to make educated guesses to narrow down the possible options. And when you suddenly get a flash of realization, it's one of the biggest dopamine hits you can get.

The story is fantasic, the characters are always a joy to see, and the games build themselves a story arc over time. Also the clown makes a Fresh Prince meme, which is even better.

The trilogy is well worth the full price (it goes on sale frequently too!) There's dozens of hours worth of game here, provided you rely on a bare minimum of guides/help from friends. 

If you play the first game and like it, I highly recommend playing the other two. I see people leaving reviews and they've only experienced the first game. The first game is great, but the following titles really add layers upon layers of depth to the characters and lore of the story. Definitely a long term investment of your time - but so worth it!

The first time I was interested in this game is because of Amber Heard & Johnny Depp's case, I was itching to play pretend as a lawyer. And I love to find faults in people.

Truth to be told, I was not a big fan of Visual Novel games since I tend to get bored easily. In my opinion, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy has a retro game charm and the fun mechanics that prevents the game to become stale, and actually, I don't mind to read at all for this game. It's fun to question people's judgement and try to find their faults. Although for some parts, the conversation and the game play can become a tad bit repetitive. 

But despite all of that, I really love how this game manage to balance out the fun things to do like investigations and collecting evidences between all the readings.

Admittedly, this trilogy marks my introduction to the visual novel genre. However, I would like to state that this trilogy is one of the greatest virtual storytelling experiences I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I will divide this review into four parts: the good, the neutral, the bad, and the important.

The good:

The stories themselves, especially the looming, overarching story of the Fey clan, are overall really solid. I genuinely like most of the characters, and while the settings are not super memorable, I find that even most of the only tolerable characters bring something to the table that increases my enjoyment of the games. However, all of this pales in comparison to the sheer emotional impact of this series. I've cried, I've laughed, I've cheered, I've raged, I've held my breath for fear of something terrible, I've done it all. If you like a game that genuinely makes you care about certain characters, and want to feel everything the protagonist does, then look no further than this game,

The game is divided into two types of gameplay: the investigation phases, and the trials. The trials are overwhelmingly where the heart and soul of the games lie. The gameplay loop of pressing the witnesses for more information and then presenting evidence to destroy their case is just too satisfying for its own good. I eventually found myself audibly shouting at the screen in triumph when I'd finally get a witness cornered.

I cannot talk about this trilogy without singing the praises of the soundtrack. Keep in mind that the first game released in 2001 for a handheld device. Despite this, the soundtrack of this trilogy manages to carry the exact amount of weight, positive and negative, that makes this trilogy really shine.

The neutral:

The investigation phases were not nearly as fun as the trials. Yes, important story beats happen, and I appreciate some things that happen during them, but I found more than anything that the story made up for the gameplay, which consists of searching locations for evidence, talking to characters, presenting evidence to the characters for more information, and, in the last two games, pressing characters for confessions. I think CAPCOM realized that the first game needed more during the investigation scenes, so they added something to make them more interesting. The main thing is, the story makes or breaks the investigation. Some investigations were somewhat tedious to get through simply because the cases were not as interesting, and other investigations held some of the biggest heart and soul of the story. Overall, they're a part of the game, and YMMV.

The bad:

So, the game sets up expectations for certain logic scenarios to behave certain ways, then it defies them in ways that don't make sense at all in the second game. Additionally, sometimes, you might have the right idea for a contradiction, but the game will not allow you to present this contradiction in the way that makes the most sense to you, or sometimes it might be presented too early to be accepted as part of the story.

Additionally, sometimes there are parts of certain stories where some logic just... doesn't flow. The story is strong enough that you might not notice it on your first playthrough, but still.

I must also say that the replay value is pretty low. Basically, once the story is given, you know how things will go. I guess if you go long enough that you forget the puzzles, then you'll be fine, but still.

The important:

Some parts of this game involve some situations that are a little... uncomfortable, if you think about them. This primarily comes into play thanks to the usage of something known as (minor spoilers ahead) [spoiler] the Kurain Channeling Technique, a spirit channeling technique where the medium channeling takes on both the spirit and the overall physical form of the deceased, while remaining themselves. At some point, this involves a young child taking on the appearance of a large-chested woman, in clothes that are child-sized, leaving the character in a rather revealing outfit. The game treats this character as the deceased person being channeled, but thanks to the explanation of this technique, there is no mistaking the fact that it is a child. Thankfully, no weird comments are made about either character when this happens, but it's still not something to feel super comfy about. [/spoiler] TL:DR; there exists a part where a kid looks uncomfortably like an adult, drawn in such a way that it seems a little sus.

The game does deal with murder cases, but it also does deal with mental health and suicide at times. The actual moments of death are not shown, only corpses in photographs or occasionally cutscenes. Be advised that some parts of this game are heavily tragic, and while most cases end on a positive note, the road to the end is not an easy one.

Verdict:

Though there are some flaws, and some aspects of the trilogy that make it certainly not for everyone, I maintain that anyone who can play these games really should, especially if they are wanting something rich in story and suspense. The characters, music, and delightfully mind-bending cases more than make up for the faults of the game. My suggestion? Play the first case in game one, and you will get a good feel for whether you will like the game or not.

Thanks for reading.

These games are extremely S L O W.

Now that that's out of the way, they're pretty fun as far as logic puzzlers go.
Sometimes it can be a bit of a stretch to figure out which piece of evidence you need to use on what specific line of a testimony, or what specific dialogue option you need to chose to advance the day, but it makes you feel like a gigabrained genius when you put the pieces together and have everything click.

Be forewarned, these games originally released in the early 2000's and hot damn does the ui feel like it. Having to bring up the 'move' menu 5 times in order to slowly click your way through every location leading to your destination is tedious as all hell, and overall every button and method of interaction with the game itself is super clunky despite this being a remaster. 

But then again this is one of the only VNs on steam that won't get you disowned by your parents so I guess that evens it out.

Alright, so I've played the first game of the trilogy and I gotta say that I really enjoyed my time with it so far. The story is really interesting albeit very weird at times. If you are looking for a visual novel to play and you like mystery and crime, don't hesitate to give this title a try!

This is a visual novel: Find clues at crime scenes, inspect police reports, interrogate witnesses. Most importantly, though, bring it all together in the trial. Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney is, at times, as satisfying as a good episode of Detective Conan, and every bit as quirky - the conclusions are sometimes pretty far out there, and some of the characters are weird Japanese stereotypes (as is often the case in Conan as well). But that's exactly what I love that about this game.

The way court hearings are interpreted can be frustrating: it is never enough to prove the defendent innocent, you must also supply the court with the real criminal plus complete evidence. On the other hand, it's probably better that way from a story-telling point of view.
