A collection of 3 very fun visual novel-type games, where stuff can easily go from 0 to 100 in the blink of an eye and then keep getting crazier and crazier. This game doesn't take itself too seriously, at least from what I've played, but the storylines for the cases are still solid enough to keep you enticed and motivate the player to pay attention to the details. Very rarely do the cases outstay their welcome since tension constantly rises, new evidence and perspectives pop up throughout the episodes, and the charm and dialogue of each of the characters keeps it engaging. They pulled it off really well in T&T, with the final case wrapping up a lot of loose ends for the characters and gave the trilogy a pretty satisfying ending. The actual courtroom debate portion of the game is actually quite straightforward, at least from what I've played, and you're usually not required to remember anything that's not in the court record. It's a fun, logical, and not overly-complex system, which I like because it lets pinheads such as myself make mistakes and forget multiple things, while at the same time still requires you to make logical connections instead of pure guesswork. Sometimes this isn't the case though, and this is where I think the games start to show their weakness, and it's especially prevalent in JFA. There's multiple things to point out but only one thing is the right answer to progress through the linear story, which obviously sucks and forces you into either savescumming or using a walkthrough to see "the right" evidence. Also the games punish you WAAAAYYYY too hard for presenting wrong evidence, even in longer trials and the obviously tougher sections! I mean, 5 chances for the entire trial? You're just begging your players to cheat and savescum at that point! Most of the time it isn't like this, but when it is like this it just makes the game drag HARD, and if you eventually find the solution by yourself it rarely feels rewarding, you either feel stupid for not knowing or resentful at the game for the solution being ridiculous.

Overall very good, definitely worth the purchase. I think the first one is the best as its cases were the most consistently good and it had some of the most charming and memorable characters IMO. It also doesn't overload you with information and evidence (aside from episode 5 which sticks out like a sore thumb because of how long it is) which I think definitely works the best with the harsh penalty system. JFA and T&T were also good, but I felt some cases outstayed their welcome a bit, namely episode 3 in JFA and episode 2 in T&T, and they also started overloading the player with evidence. As a whole though, it's definitely a great trilogy of games and a worthwhile experience.

Phenomenal! Fans of Danganronpa will rejoice as Ace Attorney is also filled with plethora of twists that will make you think outside the box! It plays out like a anime series, so if you are not an anime fan, but you enjoy solving mysteries then please push through as the game is wonderful, great storytelling and fantastic twists!

The game has a limited amount of background music, and there is no voiceover - please keep that in mind. Visually it's very satisfying, the animations are good, and the characters have their own personalities (though a lot of stereotypes!). Giving OBJECTION! is very satisfying, not to mention revealing motifs, evidence and so on - there is a cool track when you make a huge case breakthrough, especially when you see other characters react to them!

Overall I give this one a solid 9/10 - it's ideal for what it brings to the table, I just wished for voiceover, but I understand the limitations. Get the trilogy - it's really worth it!

I will start off by saying, I definitely don't think this type of game is for everyone. You need a certain mindset when you are playing and that is not bad at all. I just think that you must be ready to be thinking hard about things when you are playing this game.

I love all of the games in this package I found myself having fun on every episode and enjoying the story that links between each entry in the series. The cases are a ton of fun and I found myself being thoroughly challenged many times. This game has no replay value whatsoever but if you play each game in this package you will get your fill. This game has inspired me to play other Ace Attorney games which are also a ton of fun. The characters, the story, and the writing is very well done and I highly recommend this game for anyone to pay. If you don't know anything about Ace Attorney this is the place to start and fall in love with the series.

If you like story heavy, visual novel types of games then this  hits the mark. If you've never played Ace Attorney the most similar thing would be Danganronpa. You see the crime scene, look at evidence and at the court, you piece together slowly what really happened. I really enjoyed this game and the courtroom but my only gripe with it was sometimes at the start, you could see if your client was guilty or not and piece some things together that Phoenix couldn't see.

Because of this, I didn't feel like I was really solving or going into the mind game of if my client was telling me the truth because I knew what happened. Granted this wasn't all cases and one case really had a twist about the usual formula but it did kill the vibe of solving things. 

The characters were delightful and charming, even though I still refuse to believe that a detective could give out so much evidence in a real world but you know, its a game. Some lines are really cheesy and gimicky but that's the charm. Overall, its a long game to complete all of the cases but the ride is enjoyable and fun, so try not to take things seriously and enjoy it for what it is.

Played through the first 4 cases and just started the 5th. Been great so far. I don't know why but I wasn't expecting a lot going in, I suppose I should have been since it's a game of such legendary stature. Anyway, my lack of expectation was misplaced. The first game at least, is fantastic. 

Is it at all accurate to actual court proceedings? Absolutely not. Are there a TON of plot contrivances and unnecessary drama? Yes, the whole basis of having to catch the actual killer to prove your clients innocence is so ridiculous, basically the whole premise is a contrivance and unnecessary drama.

That being said, it's beautiful. When this game really gets going I'm audibly shouting and freaking out in front my computer screen. It's very "hype", as one might say. When the pieces slide together, and the music kicks in, and you know exactly what piece of evidence to submit to prove everything!... Well, there just isn't anything like it. 

I'd criticize the game for it's lack of real "gameplay"; there are very few points where you actually have choice in the plot, at least for the first game in the trilogy, but the interactive element is where all the excitement is derived from. 

Basically, the fact that you have to follow (at least to some extent) what's happening and submit the evidence yourself makes sure that you're in on the excitement. So if you get stumped somewhere, unlike a non-interactive medium where Phoenix might reveal the plot and you go "ohh, that makes sense, I'm an idiot" and leave unsatisfied, you have to solve the puzzle. When it does click in your brain, you can't submit that evidence fast enough. I'm practically salivating waiting for the prosecutor to shut their yap so I can deal the finishing blow with a... damaged vacuum cleaner or something.

The only thing I can say to it's detriment is that it takes a little time to get on the game's wavelength. I actually had to look up a guide in the second chapter for a few of the evidence submissions. It wasn't that I didn't understand the contradiction, I just wasn't sure how to submit evidence in a way that would tell the game what I was getting at. The evidence system can be a little bit contrived and even if you see a contradiction you can't always point it out until the preset moment that it's been written into the plot to be exposed. I haven't had to look anything up since though, as I understand now typically what the game expects from me and that sometimes it will require me to submit the same evidence multiple times even for something we JUST went over, which I was shying away from at first thinking it was "too obvious". Sometimes the game is just giving you additional prompts for the sake of giving you additional prompts when there really needn't be any. Trust your gut though and you'll figure out what the game wants from you, try not to overthink it like I did.

Anyway, other than that, it's been all good. Now that I better understand the way the developers tend to think and structure the trials, I've been able to breeze through pretty well, even when I don't fully grasp a line of inquiry, I can usually use context to figure out what I'm supposed to be presenting. 

Can't wait to continue, would recommend.

Ace Attorney is one of those games that had a huge impact on my gaming life. I remember originally picking up this series on the Nintendo DS mostly because I thought I should probably branch out and play other games that are not Pokemon, AND it had been rec'd by my friends and internet strangers (the good ol' days of the mid-2000's....)

I was skeptical at first: how fun can a game about LAWYERS (?!?!) be? But I quickly became obsessed. I've played and replayed these games, I've ranted and raved to friends until they gave in to also play these games. Capcom has probably gotten an inordinate amount of my money because I will buy this game for those who are skeptical about how fun a game about LAWYERS (??!?!) can be! I still come back to this series periodically, even 15 years after I first clicked that Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney card into my broken, floppy DS lite. 

It's fun, sometimes the logic can be dubious at best (and this is part of the reason why it really excels at replay-ability, like, how did I even get to that conclusion in the first place?!!?) It's hilarious, it's heartfelt, there's stepladders.... 

Do yourself a favor and give this game a go. Playthrough takes a little getting used to if you're like me and you remember doing this with a stylus, but, man, I cannot sing the praises of this ridiculous series enough.

Literally my favourite game (well technically games) right now, very much invested in this franchise. There are so many lovable and fun characters with interesting backstories, arcs, and symbolism (ahem ahem love me some good character foils). That being said, I wasn't expecting so many minor characters to reoccur in various cases, which was a pleasant surprise. I especially enjoyed watching the larger story at hand unravel as events from different cases throughout the trilogy came together to form a domino effect. It's like you're filling out a puzzle, yet as you step away from it, you realise there's a larger puzzle to complete, and this puzzle you were just working on was just a small piece of it. 

For the most part, the episodes are really interesting (except for turnabout big top, i want to scrub that from my memory), although i think for some players they may not enjoy the point and click aspect of investigating which can seem tedious. I don't really have any major gripes with the trilogy, the soundtrack is great, I really enjoy the game-play, the story lines, and the characters, so I definitely recommend it. :)

Anyways CAPCOM can you hurry up and repackage the next 3 games as a trilogy and put it on Steam, i don't want to buy them separately.

- It swung over like a pendulum?

- The witness is projecting his clumsiness and sorrow onto the victim?

If you would regardless enjoy a linear story with thrilling murder mysteries, a colorful cast worth bonding to and crying for (in both directions), and a soundtrack that perfectly sets the mood each scene, you've hit the jackpot.

I have wanted to play these games for the longest time, but unfortunately never seemed to be able to find them in stock back in the day. This trilogy contains the first 3 games in one convenient package, and everything works pretty well. 

The game itself is an adventure game with the trappings of a courtroom drama, but really everything is pretty much on rails, and your choices don't matter a whole lot. Even when it comes to issues of murder and revenge, the game never takes itself too seriously. Good thing too, since the episodic plots are really stupid, and mostly just played for laughs. 

My only real issue that I've noticed in the first game so far is that this game stretches the idea of "logic" REALLY far sometimes, and some of the contradictions you are asked to find aren't contradictions at all. It is the age old problem of point and click games, where you have to sort of predict how something in your inventory, or an available dialogue option with be interpreted by the game, thus moving the plot forward. And when all else fails, just use every item and click on everything. 

All in all, these games don't really hold a candle to the classic lucasarts adventure games, nor to their handheld contemporaries like 999 or Hotel Dusk. However, the Ace Attorney games are still pretty entertaining, all told, and definitely beat the pants off of modern trial-themed games like Danganrompa. I'd recommend it.

Are you thinking about playing Ace Attorney: Chronicles but saw this one first?  Stop right there and purchase this one, then.  Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is the one for you.

Is it better than the newer AA:C? Nope, not saying that.  I'm just saying you should buy PW:AAT first.  

Have you watched the trailers but you are still unsure?  Allow me to try to convince you.  You play as a brand new attorney, Phoenix Wright, who winds up with a small number of regulars plus a healthy dose of new and recycled characters who help you (or don't help you) solve a case through investigation and then discovery of facts during the trial.  The humor is very much of Japanese style, which is to say that it's pretty funny, and the translation company did quite a good job of porting the dialogue into English.

It should go with saying that you need to be able to suspend your belief in how the court system should work.  Your defense cases go to trial on the day after the crime is committed (yes, that right... the day after they are committed), the judge is easily influenced by everyone (the sadist prosecutors and the obviously conniving witnesses) except for you, and there is a spirit medium that physically conjures your boss from the grave from time to time.

Don't let that scare you, though.  This game is really good.  Each story line is clever, and if you are patient enough, you can interact certain places that are present in nearly every episode and enjoy clever little pieces of dialogue that change every day.  Did I mention the humor?  The story is cleverly written and even worth investing in a little bit emotionally.  Honestly, I cried a couple of times, and you wouldn't think that the animation style here points toward a story like that, but it can and does.

It's going to take you more time to play through this than you think it might, but the good news is that you can save practically anywhere... and that reminds, the old adage is in effect here: save well, save often.  You will keep yourself from having to start way back somewhere when you realize that you are out of chances to make good decisions and need to reload.

Also, keep a good walkthrough handy on your cellphone.  While perhaps you aren't the type to skip ahead, there is the occasional place where you know what's going on, but you can't seem to present the right piece of evidence in the right place.  Or perhaps you can't move the story forward because you forgot one little important thing that wasn't obvious to you at the time.

If I haven't scared you away yet, please let me convince you that it is worth your hard-earned dollars to play PW:AAT.  Use your deduction skills to piece the real events together.  Enjoy every humorous moment.  Revel in the little easter eggs that the devs placed in the game.  Take in the nuance of each well-written story.  And enjoy some of the best characters that gaming has to offer.

After so long, I finally managed to finish all 14 incredible cases that make up the original Ace Attorney trilogy and all I can say is there's no objections I can give against purchasing this bundle for yourself.

For those who don't know, Ace Attorney is a visual novel series where you play as incredibly well-meaning yet bumbling DA Phoenix Wright who finds himself defending a menagerie of odd clients from false murder accusations and it's up to you to find the true culprit in order to save someone from an undeserved punishment. This takes the form of point-and-click investigation segments where you examine scenes for evidence and try to interrogate a huge number of unique, insanely diverse characters to get more information from them, as well as the famed courtroom segments where you have to use logical deductions to find contradictions in witness testimonies and then expose any lies with your stockpile of evidence. While this does not sound engaging to many, trust me when I say the 80+ hour playtime I had is from ONE playthrough of the three games minus some trial and error. The series' major strengths are its dynamic storytelling, excellent characters and presentation that still holds up despite these games originally being Game Boy Advance titles!

In terms of the "trilogy" aspect, this is a compilation of the first three games in the series with very minor changes. One complaint some have had is replacing the original games' sprite work with a more ink-and-paint style but I actually disagree. I think the new, polished look does a fantastic job maintaining the original likenesses and keeping the expressive animations while also looking cleaner and more refined. I will admit not putting an option to restore the original pixels was a minor mistake.

As for the games themselves? In each game, you play through a total of 14 cinematic stories that balance a running plot with the individual crimes that does a masterful job building the world, the characters and is all supplemented by the glossy presentation, magnificent music (all lifted directly from the original games) writing that somehow manages to balance amazing comedy, heart-wrenching suspense, genuine terror from the gruesome crimes (Even if the games are originally rated T, they do not shy away that these are MURDER cases) that amounts to such an immersive experience that will make you feel like you love the heroes, despise many of the villains, and wish to see more of this eccentric world full of objections and psyche-locks. 

In short, buy these games. $30 for a package like this is a crime in and of itself!

Ace Attorney is one of the highest rated visual novels out there, and it surpassed my expectations. Along with having an intriguing story, charming characters, and excellent music, AA is also among the few novels with extensive opportunity for gameplay engagement. You get to solve the mysteries yourself, and the trial system is particularly challenging compared to similar games like Danganronpa or Your Turn To Die. Even if you usually don't like to read a lot, I think that the point-and-click format of AA can really get new players into the genre, and they may have to practice or consult walkthroughs for difficult puzzles. 

In this collection, you get 3 games; all remade from the Nintendo handheld editions to have vastly improved art and animations. As complete products, they also come with the bonuses such as an extra episode in the first instalment. That said, each game is only about 10 hours or so, so it doesn't require a huge investment to see the entire original plot. Even if you choose to only play one or two, you'll receive great experiences as stand-alone titles, but each new edition stretches the limit of the genre and continues to innovate. I was amazed that even when I was doing "Trials and Tribulations," the third game, I was still shocked by the twists and how you have to use evidence and reasoning. The clues, foreshadowing, and rationality involved for each mystery rivals the quality of traditional novels, but it also presents things one step at a time so you don't get lost or have to figure everything out immediately. 

The real appeal, however, is that Ace Attorney is just a really cool series, with lots of memorable events and characters. Pretty much anyone who plays visual novels will recall every name from this series, and its style is entirely its own. If that wasn't enough, it's also really funny, and does a ton without needing voice accompaniment. I usually didn't find myself ever bored during the investigation period because every person I met in-game was immediately likeable in being wacky and hard to predict. This translated really well to the trials as well with deep prosecutor relationships and hilarious sections involving witness testimony and argument. Few books I've ever read had characters done this well, and it's an unforgettable experience. You really don't want to miss out on Ace Attorney, even if you're hesitant about getting into VNs for the first time.

This one gets a "Yes, but" ranking.

It is a visual novel / detective game. You alternate investigations with trials, and the story advances by asking people about the clues and spotting / confronting contradictions in the testimony. The trilogy provides good value for the money, with 14 cases over three games offering 90+ hours of reading/gameplay. 

Several minor / moderate criticisms give the "but" part of the rating. First, the characters (especially the judge) are obtuse enough that instead of a single contradiction [fictitious for this review] "Look at the date on this photo -- it's the day BEFORE the crime so this doesn't show the suspect fleeing the scene at all" we instead get a three way extended conversation about "Look at this photo" "what about it?" "Look at the date!" "January 6, so what?" "But don't you remember the date of the crime?" "That was January 7th, don't you remember?" ..............

Related to the above, there are some cases where I knew of the story the instant I was handed a clue (so continue the imaginary example above, suppose I immediately saw the photo date). But there is absolutely no game mechanic to express that fact until the appropriate point in the story. I have to wait for a witness to testify to something that I can present the photo as a contradiction. Even if other characters are directly referencing the bogus photo, I can't explain the clue I found until the appropriate place.

And something that bothered me more than perhaps it should -- this is the least accurate trial simulator on the planet. It's absolutely ridiculous that I prove a witness is lying about the their testimony 4 times in a row only to be told I must do it a fifth time or my client will be convicted. Several times when I'm sure the game was trying to for a "back against the wall last ditch effort" effect which instead came across as "You've GOT to be joking". 

And a final nitpick: If you binge all three games / 14 cases in a row like I did, then you start to see a bit too much of the formula. By the end of the game I wasn't even slightly surprised that --- yet again -- my clients fingerprints were on the murder weapom and a witness of impeccable integrity was prepared to swear they saw my client commit the crime. 

It seems like I've spent a lot of the review dwelling on the negatives. Truth be told there aren't very many games that attempt what this one does. If you can get past the "No court on Earth is run this way" aspects, and don't penalize it for including 14 episodes in one pack, the set does have interesting stories, and it was fun to play detective and scan the dozen+ clues again looking for the one thing that shows the witness could not possibly have seen what they just swore they did see.

This game is by far one of the best if not THE BEST, interactive VN I have ever played. Since the very beggining of the first of the three games, you devolep an strong attachment to every single one of the main characters, and you see them growing up with every case and every day that passes. 
 For sure, there is no perfect game and some of the investigations or some particular case can make you easily bored if you want to explore every single dialog option (yes, I'm seeing you, Max case), but aside from those few moments, every character, every dialog option, every optional interaction, helps you to understand better all the motives and feelings of each of the characters in the game. 
And then, you have the case 5 of the last game, the grand finale, the moment where every single character, every single choice from the past, and every interrogation left,  all comes together in the perfect case and the best ending anyone could ask for. I really really loved this game, 10/10 experience.

I picked up this trilogy after seeing some gameplay on YouTube. The cross-examination I watched was ridiculous (no spoilers) but I couldn't help but see if it was possible for me to play this game. Lo and behold I found out it was available on Steam.

Here we are two weeks later. I was hooked right from the beginning: the characters, the contradictions, the OBJECTION!s, it kept me so involved. I never thought I was one for puzzle types or visual novel type games, but Ace Attorney proved me wrong. Each time I found new evidence, met a new person, I HAD to keep playing. These games do an incredible job of leading you on in the cases: you learn more, little by little, and you can start to piece it together. And then when you finally realize the truth, it's an incredible sensation. 

Simply put: I recommend this trilogy. If you've ever heard anything at all from anyone you know saying Ace Attorney is worth a play, believe them. Like I said, I thought this genre wouldn't be for me, but I must say, that idea was thoroughly turned around on its head. I'm hoping that Capcom remasters and releases more of the past games so that folks like me can enjoy them for the first time. Playing the original trilogy for the first time was an incredible experience, I absolutely want to play more!

Originally released in 2001 for GBA, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is most definitely one, if not, the best game of visual novel genre. Story-wise, it's very enjoyable due to its mystery, comical, and fun nature. Not only from the reactions of the characters, the choices that can be picked is also hysterical, not mentioning some references used and Easter eggs inside of the game too. I highly recommend finishing the game completely since it will reveal many hilarious conversations. One thing that I would love to have in this game is the ability to use the microphone to press and object during the cross-examination, just like the DS version.

Also I did feel the merging of the Psyche-Locks and the Penalty bar from the second game onwards was a little odd as well.

Best game ever

I bought this because of some youthful memories of playing it on a gameboy. The concept is cool, the writing is awesome and the characters are fun. That being said, I'm a bit disappointed about how linear the game is. Cases can only be solved in one way, and it's not always possible to follow through on a logical line of questioning. Solutions are sometimes that you need to present evidence when there is no real reason for you to do so, while presented evidence that actually has bearing is sometimes dismissed by the judge because you presented it too early. When searching for evidence in investigations, I got stuck multiple times because I spoke to witnesses in the wrong order, which prevents other witnesses or events from appearing. 

Also, I pray to God that the justice system in de US doesn't actually work like this. Convicting a falsely accused defendant because the judge is annoyed with the defence attorney seems rather worrying.
I may have bought it in a sale but I'd buy it all over again at full price. One of the best games I've ever experienced.

I feel I should split this review into two parts:

[h2]As a game (or a trilogy of games), it gets a 7/10[/h2]

It has so much heart, funny moments, and genuinely satisfying detective-style puzzle moments that it's really a delightful experience overall. There are some minor inconsistencies which detract from the overall story a little bit, sometimes the player will figure something out before the character can, and it's setting is a little muddled by taking place in both Japan and America at the same time. There's also the ever-present issue in a lot of anime-inspired media I like to call "GOD DAMN IT JAPAN!" of having adult characters try to get in relationships (and even sometimes marry) underage characters, including one example where a 20 year old is in a relationship with a 14 year old, and another where a 30 year old and a 25 year old both propose to a 16 year old. The biggest issue, however, is that there are a lot of moments where the player may well know what's wrong but be unsure of how to communicate the issue in a way the game accepts, sometimes it pays to have a guide open just to figure out individual moments if you get stuck. Still, none of the issues are enough to detract from the game's joys in my eyes and it's still a very compelling story.

[h2]As a port, it gets a 5/10[/h2]

Don't get me wrong, this is absolutely the best way to play the game on PC, the art is high res and you get the full experience the developers intended, however, in the credits there was one person listed as a translator and one person listed as a proofreader. The translator did really well in most instances, with only a few moments seeming weak or poorly translated (for example, suddenly having a character snap to the "anger" pose even though nothing prompted it, and then a weak attempt to justify it by having Phoenix think "I don't even know what you're angry about"),  but the biggest critique is on the part of the proofreader. There are a lot of minor problems and two or three egregious grammatical typos that made no sense at all, which really shouldn't have even gotten past an automatic proofreader/spell checker. Furthermore there are a couple of major typos which make the hard to parse and interupt your flow (one notable example having the game say "on one" when they clearly meant "no one", it sounds just plausible enough that you have to re-read to make sure you're not misinterpreting what they're saying). There are also some signs that aren't translated at all and still show up in japanese, some sprites too, but I don't really fault them for that since it would be so difficult to make entirely new art just for those occasions. Still though, feels really sloppy to include mistakes that any professional spell-checking software could have pointed out to you, Capcom really dropping the ball on this one.



Overall I'm still going to give it a recommend since it's a pretty good time if you haven't played them before, just be warned it's 80% visual novel, 10% point-and-click, and 10% detective gameplay. Obviously if that isn't your style you might want to take a pass on this.

TLDR; amazing trilogy with amazing soundtrack, buy it.

An outstanding trilogy. Every game in it are absolutely masterpieces. 

The first one introducing us to the world, ending with an amazing final case. The bonus case is a bit mixed, although its still a really good case.

 The second game introducing us to pearl, maya's cousin. This game is considered the worst of the trilogy, but i still love it. Yes, turnabout big top is the worst case in the trilogy but still has an amazing story, with the final case of the game being a tense emotional suspense filled case, one of the best in the series.

The third game, considered the best, expands upon the world greatly introducing us to dahlia, the main villain of the game and phoenix's ex. The finale to the third game is an amazing send off to the series, as it was originally supposed to be the last game.

Theres also third case syndrome for each of these, where the third cases are considered filler, although i would entirety disagree for turnabout samurai as the steel samurai is a reoccurring thing in the series and set up case 4 of the second game.

The music for this is outstanding too, as much as i would like to go over each and every song i probably shouldn't.

This trilogy is amazing, 9/10 buy it

And for that purpose, you'll have to count on...

THE POWER OF THE ATTORNEY!!!

Imagine a game that is just the Sword Master fight in Moneky lsland, all the time.

I'm not very fond of narrative heavy games with no action or complex gameplay. But this is the exception that proves the rule for me. The perfect example of how less is more. That you can have a great game with just a handful of static backgrounds and a few very funny character animations. All you need are compelling (and a bit over-the-top) characters and stories, and a matching soundtrack. The battles of wits, when that music suddenly changes, really feel like trading blows in a Dark Soul boss fight, they will make your blood rush. 

If you enjoy detective stories or are old enough to have watched Perry Mason, this is the game.

PS: Now I got this strange habit of bowing with my arm at the front when I finish a presentation.

[h1] GOEY: Game Of Every Year [/h1]

A lawyer simulation that will take you on an unforgettable journey. It's got everything, weeb as fuck stuff for everyone, cool story, waifus, sexual jokes and innuendos all over the place, strong alpha male power and deep homosexual Naruto/Sasuke rivalry. Funny, driving, interesting gameplay,incredible and iconic soundtracks. It even has a iceberg theory of lore.

But enough with the less serious stuff.

For real, the Ace Attorney Collection is a PC port of the 3 Gyakuten Saiban games released on GBA then Nintendo DS (and Wii ect). 3 Games, over 50 hours of gameplay depending on how you play. Definitely worth the 30 bucks. 
It's a point and click game with puzzle solving and witness cracking. It might give you a weird desire to venture into a courtroom and just trial the shit out of a witness, why ? Simply because Ace Attorney teaches you the very basic rule about trials and justice: EVERYBODY LIES.
Anyway, as you can see, there's no way to talk about this game seriously, but we should, because it's a 10/10.
This game also acts as a weird cure if you're depressed.

It was only this year I discovered Ace Attorney, I had absolutely no idea what it was. The way I found about it was from memes on Youtube (Objection.lol) and was intrigued by the presentation, to which I discovered to be an anime series to then finally learning it was a game way back in the 2000s. It was only available with Nintendo systems like the Nintendo DS, but at that time and even today, I absolutely hate the company and the way they are, so any property of Nintendo I avoid like the plague and as far as I'm concerned doesn't exist, which is a shame because I'm sure I'm missing out on some great IPs. 

But here it is, on steam ready and available and on sale, with at this time of review of an 'overwhelmingly positive' review. The game is different from anything I've played before. Conduct an investigation, then fight with words in court, present evidence which contradicts what someone said, press for more information which could help your case. Roughly 70 hours and a couple of months it took me to beat this series, and I'm glad I did. Ace Attorney is a really special series and deserves to be popular. 

Now, if you play the game and plan to be a lawyer after this, don't. The realism level and how things actually are is almost non-existent in both terms of the cases themselves and how a court of law functions. It's more on the level of fantasy which is fine, but don't expect to become an Ace Attorney yourself. Enjoy it for what it is and it's amazing. 

*A small warning. Below there are minor spoilers about the game, but nothing about the plot itself* 

I did find near the end the game getting stale, it's a very similar format and structure with almost all the cases. First conduct investigation, then your a defence attorney, saving to client in what seems like an impossible task to then just putting just enough of a doubt to conduct another investigation finding more clues and new witness to then being a defence attorney again to then again put enough doubt to sometimes force another investigation then go back to court but this time turn your a prosecutor (while still being a defence attorney) against the last witness which typically is the one that ended up doing the crime. There were differences here and there but the overall format is pretty much the same, and near the end I was pretty much done with it. I'm never one to ask for less content in a game, but I feel with Ace Attorney, they very easily could have skipped a few cases and it would have been fine and would have had no recourse for the main plot. 

It did drive me nuts at times because I knew what was happening or going on, but yet, the game is look for very specific piece of evidence at very specific times of the conversation even though what I present was fine and would have work. I can't fault it too much obviously it is a game and has its limitations, but the game is very, very linear. I feel they could have at least opened it up just a tad more in terms of options. There is only one way to play. After completing the game, I have little desire to play anymore. Seen it, been there, done that, but very glad I had!

It's by no means a perfect game, it has -many- plot holes and flaws, but it's still very good and a breath of fresh air different kind of game. I'll take this over any modern FPS any day.

This is a good game, or pack of games. But it's very specific in its genre; it shows, because more than 90% of buyers have started the game, about 70% have finished the first chapter, about 60% finished the second chapter, and 55% of them finished the third chapter.

It's a kind of adventure based around "trial simulation" (yes, justice trials, if you haven't noticed) and there are also investigation stages that are mostly point and click and dialogue.

After playing Spirit of Justice on the 3DS, which is a really good game, I could play them all day, but you have to wonder if you would, too. It's a well-known franchise but it might not be for you. The pace is pretty slow, and you have to read a lot. So, you have to ascertain if you like the characters, the tone and the writing, all of which are very important to the franchise. If not sure, you could always watch some Let's Play.

I haven't even come close to finishing all 3 of these games, but I am so impressed at how everything in this game is made. The writing, the characters, the music, the artwork, everything is made SO meticulously. I even noticed that if you're spamming a button to skip through dialogue and then suddenly a decision pops up, your spamming won't register for about 2 seconds so you don't accidentally click the wrong option. Small things like that just make this game a 10/10 from me.

Plus this game actually requires some critical thinking and deductive skills, and watching the prosecution and witnesses squirm when you unravel their "airtight" alibi or evidence is so satisfying. If you haven't played this game yet then that is a foolish choice by a foolish fool who wishes to feel the foolish sadness of a sad fool.

10/10
The Ace Attorney games has survived the test of time for a reason; the mysterious characters, suspenseful trials and the Investigation that constantly has you change your guesses are what make this game a masterpiece. 

The abundance of characters armed with their own unique agendas and motives makes each case exhilarating to unravel, quality that is matched with the complex story lines that build on each other in a satisfying way (The third game in particular). The quirky characters and the interactions/dialogues shared between them is, for me, the highlight of the games that kept me engaged throughout. Apart from the obvious peaks of game-play found in the trials, finding out how certain characters feel about other characters or how they interpret certain scenarios made investigating not feel like such a chore. I won't go into any specifics but the mysteries and the explanations are top-notch to say the least; the game is not overly difficult- but every contradiction you find definitely gives you a great sense of accomplishment.

The Ace Attorney court is a place of amazing revelations, satisfying breakdowns, emotional conclusions and even some quality back and forth banter. I recommend this game to anyone with a functioning brain. :}

I did not expect the overly-meme'd defense attorney simulator to actually change my emotion so much. I found myself pointing my finger at my monitor almost jumping in excitement from the raw hit of dopamine you get when you figure out a clue or notice a contradiction in the testimonies. It's so masterfully written and the developers did a great job hiding information from you while at the same time making it obvious your client wasn't the murderer, making it all the more interesting when you find a new clue and connect the dots before even Phoenix figures it out.

Overall I had an absolute blast playing this and I see why it's still a popular series to this day. My only complaint is that in some of the cases, especially Turnabout Sisters, there are times where you're actually not supposed to be able to find the contradiction and instead some sort of plot armor happens to continue the trial. It felt out of my control and were the only times I felt a semblance of frustration. Otherwise, really fucking good.

[u]BUT NOT PERSONAL[/u] is the fact that is a unoptimized (and directx only) port, if your monitor runs more than 60Hz, you must disable the vsync for locking it at its 60fps, or you'll get constant framedrops in special animations, and you don't want to lose special characters' special animations, don't you?.(also at 60Hz I advise to not use it, but hey in 2020 who the hell uses vsync)

If you like this type of game try it, buy it, and continue playing to next chapters (Apollo Justice, Dual Destinies and Spirit of Justice), the two Miles Edgeworth spin-offs and DGS (ok its called Chronicles now)

[h2]Among The Finest Visual Novel/Point & Click Experience. Must Play Recommendation: 10/10[/h2]
[hr][/hr]
[i][b]For Linux & Steam Deck:[/b] Platinum experience. User verified with Proton 6.3-7[/i]
[hr][/hr]
The Phoenix Wright franchise isn’t just an outstanding game. Those that have never played a visual novel or a point and click game, this will prime you for what these genres of game have the potential to do, and has the capacity to change your opinion. 

The ultra-polished game play, switching between the visual novel court room battle and the point and click investigative is seamless and feels complete. But that’s not what draws you in, rather the richly engaging and thrilling story-telling as well as it’s memorable and impressive cast of characters are what ultimately makes this game adored by so many worldwide. 

But in my opinion, what makes this a 10 out of 10, is the entire Phoenix Wright compilation priced at a third of Capcom’s normal cost. This is unbeatable value for money for such a high quality game with 60 hours of total game time. 

Buy it. Must play recommendation. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What’s Excellent[/h3]
[table]
  [tr]
    [td]1. Thrilling and thoroughly engaging cases with twists and surprises[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]2. Memorable and charismatic cast of characters[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]3. Dramatic and action-oriented court room battle[/td]
  [/tr]
[/table]
The stories here are divided into cases and each case is an immaculate example of great detective stories rivaling anime and manga classics such as Detective Conan (Case Closed)de and Kosuke Kindaichi. The crime mystery is enthralling, always spurring your curiosity to keep searching and solving it. The best of these is definitely, the first 4 cases which in my opinion, also has the best cast of characters. There is an overarching main story that encompasses the entire trilogy, and the ending of that overarching story is appropriately epic even if it has some minor plot holes. 

And the cast of characters are all memorable, likeable and charismatic. Each character has their own arc and even the villains are impressive and imposing. Each cast are also designed uniquely and possess their own identity. Phoenix Wright is a relatable rookie defense attorney determined to prove his client innocence and his perseverance is infectious. The supporting casts, Miles Edgeworth, Mia & Maya Fey, Franziska Von Karma, are memorable as well with great character arcs that ties in to the overarching story line. 

Of course heroes are nothing without their villains and PWAA has a great cast of villains as well. I won’t name them here to avoid spoilers, but my favorite is the overarching villain of Trials & Tribulation. She is definitely among the most realistic depiction of a villain anywhere and her backstory while leans quite a bit towards day time soap opera, is cleverly written. 

The meat and potato of Phoenix Wright is definitely the court room battles. Catching the witness’ contradiction in their testimony by shouting “OBJECTION!” is downright addictive. When it comes down to it, the court room section is a puzzle game where you put together all the clues that you have during your investigation and try to catch any discrepancies in the witness’ testimony in an attempt to get to the truth and ultimately get a Not Guilty verdict for your client. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What’s Good[/h3]
[table]
  [tr]
    [td]1. Good artwork and graphics.[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]2. Catchy and theme-appropriate music.[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]3. Investigative point & click section is done very well[/td]
  [/tr]
[/table]

Each character and location is unique, distinct and easily identifiable. I can definitely recall each character, how they look like, what were their colors, their expression when they smile and when they grimace. This is also mostly true with most of the location design, from the Detention Center, Lake Gourd, Global Studios, the Court Room; each location have their own feel and look that will leave and impression on you. 

The music is very catchy, and they are all very appropriate to the scene whether if it’s during the actual crime, during an interview, during the reveal or during a lighthearted moment, it’s all very well composed and accentuate the scene even more. 

The investigative section of the game is essentially a point & click portion where you need to search the scene for clues and evidence. New mechanics where you are supplied with Luminol Spray to find blood splatter as well as Fingerprinting Dust to search for fingerprints as well as the Magatama, a spirit medium stone that can reveal if a person is holding secrets. The mechanics here are done very well without too much frustration. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What Could Be Better[/h3]
[table]
  [tr]
    [td]1. Some cases gets really long.[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]2. Some stories have pacing issues.[/td] 
  [/tr]
[/table]
Though not all cases, some of them have pacing issues and they can get very long. Specifically, Rise From the Ashes, take 7-8 hours to complete, as well as the trilogy’s finale Bridge To Turnabout which can take upwards of 10 hours. It’s very lengthy and very taxing, especially with all the information that you have to gather but the story makes it worth to push through. 

Especially in the investigative section, the game can suffer some pacing issues as you struggle to figure out which information you have to unlock/discover/acquire to trigger the next scene. This can be frustrating, especially when the game doesn’t signal to the player on exactly where to go or what to do. 
[hr][/hr]
[h3]What Makes This A Must Buy[/h3]

The entire compilation is priced at a third of what the usual Capcom game costs. With it’s high quality story-telling as well as 40-60 hours content, the value of this game is phenomenally good. Well worth the investment you put in. 

Even if you don’t like Point & Click game, or Visual Novel game, the value of this game with it’s relatively low price is enough to be the one game to give it the genres a fair chance. And most likely, you will come away with a positive experience and a new appreciation for the potential of Point & click and Visual Novel games. 

I did.

I'm a fan of few games and genres, whether it shooters, rpgs, etc. and games like these aren't usually up my alley, and while this game somewhat plays out like a visual novel, it is fantastic. It is probably going down as my favourite game that I've ever played so far, and if my steam profile isn't private when you're reading this, you'll see I've played too many games to the point that it's embarrassing. I've always been interested in law, and even though this game can make a mockery of some legal practices, it's still super fun to play. While the gameplay can get slow and annoying at times (specifically looking at you, Rise of the Ashes), such as investigations or just actual trials (which are the best part of the game), it's still worth it in the end. The writing and story telling in this game is top-notch. The narratives, plausibility, and twists in all of the cases are what kept dragging me in again and again. Every single case has such an intricate story line, it leaves you thinking about all the possible endings until you finally finish the case and uncover the truth. I can't say this enough, the writing in this game, while there are a few slip-ups, is fantastic. And since I said that it somewhat plays a visual novel, don't think it's easy! There were so many instances where I felt lost and felt I couldn't progress until I looked over everything in the court record multiple times. And even then there were I pretty much had to brute force it until i got the right answer, but once I did, I felt dumb (barring maybe 3 instances in the whole game). I can't recommend this game enough. Just remember to save before you do something risky (it will save you a lot of time)! This game has so much content in it, it's definitely worth your money if you're a person that compares cost of the game to how long it takes to finish. This game is basically a book, but even if you aren't someone who likes to read books, I guarantee you will love this game.

Great series brought to a modern system. It's really good to be able to play all the old cases without spending £50-£100+ on old systems which might be broken or using an emulator.

That being said, the only glaring issue this has is the artwork, in this I mean the character art during the game, it looks weird with no shading and it almost being "drawn over" the original pixel art, animations can look weird at times and sometimes rushed as well due to this. It's a bit weird considering there are fan-artists who produce PW:AA fanflicks with better looking pixels/sprites/art quality. I'm one of those who wish they had pushed the boat out a bit harder for better art and if they continue making PC remakes they make that decision to go for better visuals.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is an old but great trilogy of games to revisit. I have mostly stayed away from Phoenix Wright games my whole life but always being aware of them and checking for reviews. Now with some free time over the past year or two I decided it was finally time to take a toe-dip into the series.

If you enjoy detective visual novels with a puzzle-like mystery that needs to be solved you should have a blast with Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy. I enjoyed all of my time in the game and it will mostly likely make me a return buyer to future entries for the series released on PC. Literally my only qualm with the game (that is more of a preferential thing) is that it can sometimes be mentally taxing to solve a case so I found myself playing in 1-3 hours sessions and rarely solving the whole case in one sitting. Although I know this is why you want to play the game I really wouldn't mind more things to do during a case so I am not having to be at 100% the whole time I play. A bit weird for feedback I know but that is how I felt.

Regardless - definitely gets a thumbs up from me and definitely worth playing!

It's really well written, it gets you invested and the cases connect with each other brilliantly. The animations might seem to be lacking to someone who hasn't played it but each character's sprites are well thought and presented at all the right moments despite being limited. They give away a lot of their character and thoughts which keeps things interesting and even exciting at times when things get out of hand for criminals. Cue sounds, music and the few times we hear voice lines are also so well placed that the game feels complete as it is, it could have more but it absolutely doesn't need it. I enjoyed the whole trilogy immensely (yes there's some inconsistencies but they are easy to ignore and yes sometimes having to present the exact evidence the game needs to progress is frustrating but you can always save often and try again)

Honestly I'm not typically a fan of most Japanese titles, but Phoenix Wright is absolutely the exception. If you go into it expecting a 100% realistic lawyer courtroom simulation, then you're going to be disappointed. But what it does offer is a very smart, funny and unique experience with great characters and fantastic writing. For a game that was entirely translated, it's absolutely hilarious at times and almost tear jerking in others, the jokes hit and although one or two characters can be annoying, each has an interesting personality and background that it's fun to learn more about and discover.

The game does a great job of really getting you involved in each case trying to piece it together and crack it wide open. Each case is varied and unique; I never once felt anything was copied or recycled. They take quite a while to solve too, the early couple of cases you can complete in an hour or two but later cases require several days of investigation and gathering evidence before you then go to trial (maybe 5-10 hours of gameplay?). It then feels so satisfying when you've got that douchebag on the stand and you catch them perfectly in a lie with some evidence you found earlier!

Absolutely recommend, it's a clever game that'll have you genuinely thinking with every case and it makes you feel like you're literal Einstein when you crack it.

Having finished the first game of the trilogy, I feel like i have enough to drop a review on this bad boy.
Ace Attorney's all aspects contribute to a very amusing and neat little package. From the banger music, through the goofy dialogues all the way to the fantasticly built stories. 
The characters are lovely and flexible. They can feel like real people, but also larger than life at the same time, and the dialogues are also able to be funny, and extremely tense when it has to.
The game is really well paced, slowly opening up the more and more complicated murder cases. Solving the cases by myself is one of the greatest satisfactions I've felt in gaming, really making the player feel like a gigabrain.
Unfortunately I can't end the review here, the game also has some nuisances, originating from the latter pro. Though I love to get my mind blown by the twisty murder cases, and I don't mind a challange either, the game, it seems, cannot really handle it, and it kind of collapsing into itself, resulting in some really frustrating moments. 
A quick run down on the gameplay before I get into that: once you hear about the murder and you have your defendant, you collect clues. Then you go to the court, where you search for contradictions in the witnesses statements, summoned by the prosecution.  You press them to make them give more information. The more they talk, the more inconsistencies surface, which you can point out by presenting the evidences.
So here are the issues that exist thanks to the (sometimes) overly complicated murder cases, all of which I've encountered in Episode 5, and I fear I haven't seen the last of them:
-The contradiction can be pointed out in multiple statements of the witness, with multiple evidences, but the game only accepts one. So even though you have it all figured it out, you have shoot in the dark.
-There are multiple different contradictions in one testimony, but only one progresses the story, so if you point out the one that the game doesn't think is right, you still get penalty, even though it's obviously a contradiction.
-Instead of presenting the contradicting evidence, in which way you had to prove the witnesses wrong in the past 4 episodes, you have to press the statement, so that then the game can present the evidence automaticly instead of you, after a pointless conversation. When this happened, I first thought that I had to present a different evidence, since I had multiple evidences that could contradict the statement. After that didn't work out,  I spent a good 6-7 minutes reading the other statements over and over again, thinking I got it wrong, until I looked a guide up just to find out that I was originally right, the game just wanted to do it in an unorthodox way... 

The game is an amazing experience other than that, absolutely recommend it.
Add some voice acting and it would be okay. Until then, I'll just watch others do this on YouTube.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney is a classic for a reason. It's great fun, and you should get it, especially on sale.

Just be warned, the game isn't particularly logical. The focus is very much on the enjoyable narrative than on careful deductive reasoning. Don't expect the choices you have to make to always make sense. If in any doubt at all, play with a walk-through open in your browser, refer to it liberally, and enjoy the experience.

The final case in each of JFA and T&T are true narrative peaks of the series. You need to have played through all of the preceding cases, in order, to appreciate them, but they're well worth it.

The great three first Ace Attorney games, packed into one wholesame package at a decent price (especially when on sale). If you like serious court cases full of goofy characters and sometimes very silly dialogue/plot points it is definitely worth picking up, as there really is nothing else that captures the beauty of these games.

Do keep in mind though that the original games are very old DS games and these are them exactly as they were back then but in HD, so the gameplay and game design aren't very crazy and sometimes the age can show quite visibly.

One of my favorite games of all time. Even made me buy the entire series on the Nintendo DS.
First of all, you get to shout "Objection" a lot and point your finger at witnesses.
But if that doesn't convince you, for unexplicable reason, here is a short summary.

Basically it's a visual novel with the feeling & art style of an anime, including both the strong emotions and the typical sillyness.
You play as Phoenix Wright, a newbie defense attorney, with Maya Fey, a spirit medium at your side. 

Every case first contains an investigative part, where you look for clues and gain information by searching the place, talking to people and uncovering their dark secrets with a little assistance by your spirit sidekick (can't tell any details without a spoiler). 

The second part is the actual court trial and this is where the real fun begins. Question witnesses, find holes in their testimonies and confront them, by pressing on statements and using the clues gained in the first part. 

Every case plays out differently and I didn't see all the twists coming. The overall story is pretty enjoyable and ties everything together nicely, with recurring characters and their individual quirks, which will grow on you.

The difficulty is quite moderate. Finding the right answer can be anything inbetween way too hard and sometimes on the nose easy. All in all it is a tough but rewarding experience, once you start seeing the whole picture in every case.

As far as achievements go, most of them are manageable, but I gotta admit that I needed a guide for the lunchbox achievement.

Music is pretty cool, by the way. Got me pumped every time and I keep on listening to it even after closing the game.

I recommend the trilogy, if you:
- don't mind reading a lot
- enjoy anime/manga and the typical style elements that come with it (sometimes goofy humor; deep emotions, physical reactions to the dialogue, etc.)
- like investigative games, where you can play detective
- always wanted to play a non realistic over the top attorney
- enjoy yelling "Objection". Seriously. I love it.
- came here for the "You are not a clown..." meme

Masterpiece. The characters are relatively simple based around a quirk or two, but they're well-done and have excellent dynamics and banter/interactions. The art is solid, unique designs and excellent backgrounds. The music is amazing, I'll even add a few songs to my playlist (which I'm rarely inspired to do from video games). The plot is pretty good with plenty of mystery.

The gameplay itself is both easy and difficult. It's easy in the sense that it's usually not hard to figure out whodunnit and how the evidence relates together (aside from some details), but the game wants you to present the evidence in a specific way, so often times it's hard to figure out not what the answer is but how the game wants you to answer. 

Worth full price! I would be sooo happy if I ever had a daughter as adorable as Pearls! <3

This is my favorite video games ever. It might not mean much, considering the only games I play are Mario ones, Animal Crossing and a few others, but holy crap this is amazing. I was watching a stream one day when they switched to this game, (the Samurai trial) and I got hooked. I begged my mom to buy me this, and she did. And then I got even more hooked. Amidst all the games, this is most probably my favorite. It has humor, mystery, and is actually a game that plays with your head. You feel as if you're actually Phoenix (unless you search up a tutorial/walk-through), going through all these challenges. The only negative comment I have is that it's kind of difficult through the first two trials, because if you start with this game (which I did) then it'll be hard to get used to the controls and stuff. It doesn't tell you what to do, you just figure out yourself. Which just has a whole bunch of other pros and cons I won't get into. Other than that, I love this game so much, and the characters as well. I enjoy writing a lot, and making interesting characters is more difficult than you think. I was completely taken aback by how much I loved these characters, and how easy it was for me to love them. Props to the people who just made these in general. There are characters the game will make you hate and love, and I'm a picky person and usually isn't persuaded by the attempts. But this game somehow convinced me- it was like it took control of my emotions with mere text boxes and repeating game sprites to love them. I'm still shocked of how amazing this game is. It contains mild language (hell, crap, etc) and use of tobacco, but only in one trial, where a woman is smoking it. (At least, that's what I assume they mean. I haven't finished the game yet- don't quote me.) It doesn't show gore or graphic scenes, which I love, because I'm extremely sensitive to them. The murder scenes are just 5 - 7 frames of drawings usually, and there's barely animation/walking around or anything. This may sound disappointing to you, but frankly, I think it's better. Watching trailers and tips (without spoiling anything) would help before you purchase this game. All in all, 10/10. Please, please, PLEASE buy if you can.

I normally don't go for visual novel type games, but this one had enough of a reputation that I bought it anyway.

Basically, you are (usually) defense attorney Phoenix Wright, and you have to navigate this world's crazy legal system in order to prove your clients innocent. You start by investigating the crime scene, then during court you point out when witnesses are lying or mistaken, by showing the relevant evidence.

My only complaint is that sometimes you'll know a piece of evidence contradicts the witnesses testimony, but it's not clear which piece of the testimony is the one you're supposed to object to. Sometimes I found that the piece of the testimony I thought was the most obvious one for a given piece of evidence was actually the wrong one, and in a few of the cases, I had multiple pieces of evidence that contradicted a testimony, but I wouldn't get to object to the part I wanted until later.

For that reason, I say there's no shame in using a walkthrough to check your work.

Otherwise, it was a lot of fun, and I look forward to trying out Ace Attorney Chronicles next. Hopefully, I'll like that one just as well.

I haven't played JFA or T&T. This is just for the first game.

Alright, let's get into it.

1) Witnesses are stupid when they lie. So many times throughout the first game it's just witnesses who have contradictions because they were stupid enough not to craft their lies around things they can blatantly see (In Turnabout Sisters [spoiler] April May tapped into Mia's phone call with Maya and during the phone call she also heard that the clock wasn't working, and yet she lied saying the clock was working when even she would have known it wasn't working [/spoiler]). Or the logic is legitimately flawed (JFA first trial, [spoiler] man can't tell the difference between bananas and a baseball glove from the defense stand but he can tell that those glasses were his? [/spoiler]). I know that the first two trials are beginner trials and so they aren't meant to be the hardest but even throughout the other trials there are many times where a witness should not have messed up the way they did but they still did. I know this game is built around objecting to contradictions in the witness's testimony and so they have to make a testimony, but it's excruciating how stupid these characters have to be just so this works.

It's not all bad though, there are many times where you press all the statements and there isn't a contradiction, and so the testimony ends Wright has to really try and bluff his way out of it. There's a sense of "Oh no, this is getting worse and worse for our case" similar to the feeling you get from Great Pretender case 1 (if you ever watched it, I greatly recommend the first case, the other cases are fine but none match up to the first one).

2) Not only that but most of the time it's very obvious who the culprit is. Why is this? Because for some reason you have to prove someone else did it. This boils every case (At least in the first game) to a closed room mystery. Who out of all these witnesses and people we know could have done it? I know it's done to increase enjoyability, but after a while it's a really, really tiring trope. It would be much more interesting if, just for example I suppose, we got a client off and didn't find the killer, only for the killer to show up again and our client was accused again, causing a rift between Wright, the rest of the court, and deepen distrust between the client and Wright. Or maybe the killer shows up in another case as a victim, or a witness. Just anything other than "Wow, [spoiler] Redd White/boat man/Gant [/spoiler] is definitely the killer."

3) The investigations are grueling. Usually they are pretty explanatory with what you have to do but sometimes I go have to go through many areas over and over again because I don't know where to go to progress the story or because I missed presenting something to someone. It's not that big of a deal though, just annoying.

I can admire what this game did for its time when these types of games didn't exist, but there's a lot of flaws that make it cumbersome to play, especially since most of it is reading. I can't wait to play JFA and T&T and see if they improve on the original concept of the first game.

So as you all know, Ace Attorney is a game about you being a defense attorney. You need to investigate, collect evidences, and all that before you compete in a trial against the prosecutor.

This game is very good from every aspects; gameplay, art styles, dialogue, and story. It's also more interesting that the game got twists which make the game more intriguing. Every choices you make will decide the verdict of the judge, it's either [b]Guilty![/b] or [b]Not Guilty[/b]. 

Overall, I really recommended it! There are also many achievements to complete, but I'm not a "completionist", so I didn't bother completing all the achievements. If I may give you a tip: Never give up on your clients/defendants, always believe that they're NOT GUILTY no matter what!

I normally get into games after seeing a big youtuber play them, or if I hear about them in big game presentations. However, I went into this game completely blind, knowing only the basic concept of the game. I didn't expect much more than a visual novel about a lawyer, but damn the stories are fantastic. Not only that, but this is a visual novel to actually have gameplay alongside it. The characters all feel fleshed out and the mysteries always make me gasp and make me feel like I'm actually smart. Something about the game that I haven't seen mentioned too much is the amazing soundtrack. When it kicks in right after you find a lie in a testimony, it slaps so hard. I literally jump out of my chair in excitement sometimes. The single problem I had with the game was how for some chapters it shows you who the killer is in a little cutscene, which (especially in chapter two of the first game) greatly lowered the surprise for me. All in all, I'd give this game a 9/10.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a collection of the first three entries in the series that are DS games with HD textures. This game plays as a visual novel with a mixture of the American and Japanese criminal justice system. Very non-realistic for those who are studying law lol. 

The core basics in the Phoenix Wright games are divided into 2 categories in gameplay: investigations and Court Trials. Investigations take place where the player must gather clues/evidence from NPCs that are witnesses/somehow involved in the case. These are needed to continue onto the Court Trials, since the games are a visual novel. Progression will only be continued until the player has gather all of the clues and it's a segmental system. Each entry has added more gameplay elements in the previous games, so investigation does improve.

Court Trials is where this series truly shines! Now that the player has gathered all of the evidence/clues, its time to present why the client we're defending isn't guilty! Pressing on statements, presenting evidence, and making decisions are the main  gameplay elements; however do note that it's a segmental system for progression. Not to mention the catchy VGM that plays when you catch someone BS ing!

Overall, I enjoyed my time with the Ace Attorney Trilogy collection. Great games that must be played in numerical order, amazing VGM, interesting writing, and of course great characters. It's a great series to try out the visual novel genre although I do much prefer Danganronpa.
Great game play, a few cases are pretty predictable but then again there are still a few more difficult ones.

This game was a fun experience. I recommend this to anyone that enjoys visual novels. A lot of the characters in this series are memorable and charming. There are times where it feels as if the story drags on for too long since you, as the player, already have everything figured out hours before. There's also some times where you have to present evidence in a certain order to progress, so I sometimes got stuck for hours figuring out what I had to do next to continue the story. Other than that, this game was definitely worth my time.
I hope more games from the Ace Attorney series get ported on PC.

If you're expecting an accurate "court simulator" type of game, this ain't it. It's a parody on the American/Japanese law and court system, so a lot of things might seem absurd if you're looking at it as someone who knows how it actually works.

Even so, the AA trilogy is definitely worth playing.

The characters are all very fun and unique, the story is engaging and the satisfaction of being correct when solving a case is unparalleled. Despite the humor in this game being a tad outdated, it's actually really entertaining nonetheless. The gameplay can sometimes get a bit repetitive, but you start getting into it when you get closer to solving a case. My favorite chapter was probably the 5th case in the 1st game (PW:AA - Rise From The Ashes) because of Ema Skye and the new game mechanic that came with this character's appearance. Sadly though, it was the first and last time we got to experience it in this trilogy.

So, in summary, I think everyone should play this game. At least for the meme culture. I'd recommend buying the game on sale, though the price is alright if you've money to spare (or if you want to play it that bad).

Despite this being my first foray into the world of visual novels, I still found it to be very enjoyable. Lovable characters, engaging plot lines, smart puzzles. and wacky courtroom antics lend a unique identity to these games, one that I and many others love. There are a few amazing cases here that I’m not going to spoil, but you’re gonna know what I mean once you beat the game. Not every case is perfect, though.  Some cross-examination segments feel a bit obtuse. Investigations, while helpful in helping the player develop preconceptions of what happened before taking the battle to court, can overstay their welcome. These issues, however, do not affect every case and act as an exception to the rule. Overall, this collection provided a unique and fun experience that I can wholeheartedly recommend, and I can’t wait to see how The Great Ace Attorney Chronicles will evolve the series in terms of gameplay and storytelling.

Side note ~ There is a music mod by JTPaper that completely remasters every single track in each game. I would highly recommend checking it out!
Story and the game style

If there's one game I absolutely recommend, it's this one. I only recently discovered Ace Attorney and the trilogy itself a little while back, and it has just seeped into my brain with its incredible story and characters. 

Had one issue where my save files were deleted for both the first and second game, but thankfully since I've played it again recently, they've stayed untouched. It would have been nice to fully recover my files, but since the endings aren't choice-based, I don't mind going through the game again. (I'd advise making sure your computer/steam is fully updated before you play just in case!) 

The entire premise of a courtroom setting where you have to confront the evidence given by the prosecution seems simple, but it captures your attention with great mystery and very entertaining storytelling. Some cases are better than others, If you do get stuck somewhere don't be afraid to use a guide as they can be a bit tricky, but the ending cases are just flat-out brilliant and worth the purchase for them alone.

It's an excellent, thorough and hilarious game well worth the money I spent on it. For the number of hours I've spent on it without even finishing all the episodes yet (11/15 so far) and the game at its full price, I've paid about $.50 for every hour of gameplay. Just that alone makes it well worth the investment. I love the game, too. It's funny and lighthearted and isn't afraid to satire or parody even itself or take itself too seriously, but it also has deeply touching narratives and asks you to consider very deep concepts about the ethics of justice and what it means to advocate for a client that might be guilty or against a client that must be innocent. The characters are lovable and never boring or tiresome and you root for them all. 10/10 would recommend this game to anyone.

To be completely honest I could just use a quote from the game for this review and it would work perfectly. After all, it's the truth!

"Spine tingling legal action! Mind numbing legalese! You will say 'wow'!"

And if you think the description looks interesting, then, oh boy, you are not ready for the game.  It's genuinely incredible, absolutely brilliant - divided into two modes - investigation and trial. You gather the clues and talk to witnesses to aid yourself in the trial. There are so many different characters, each one even funnier than the last one. The humour in the game is one of my favourite things about it, the jokes you hear and the characters' reaction will truly make you laugh.

Some cases are definitely easier and you will be able to guess what item to show the prosecution before the game gives you a chance but in some cases, you will truly need to think hard to figure out what crime has truly transpired. You have to keep in mind that your mistakes will end up giving you a "Game Over", so you have to focus!

I currently have 65 hours on record and I am pretty sure this number will continue growing and growing because I just cannot get enough. I have already played the first game and the Justice For All, the second game twice because I really love the cases. I have yet to play Trials&Tribulations but with how much I have been enjoying those two, I'm absolutely sure it will continue being so good.

The soundtrack is also incredibly good, I genuinely can't stop listening to it.

So many fun filled and crazy cases to play through... Although there were some cases that were a bit lacking, overall, I loved playing this game. It's easy to fall in love with each and every character and when I got to the end of the third game, I was left with a bittersweet feeling as though I was saying goodbye to these characters that I came to know and love. I highly recommend playing through the trilogy for anyone who loves visual novels combined with some critical thinking to solve the mystery behind each bizarre case.

A fantastic trilogy of games that makes me regret not getting into the franchise sooner. I remember borrowing the 1st game on the nintendo ds years ago from a friend to try it out but it didn't stick at the time. Despite that, my friends raved about it for years to come afterwards until I finally decided to revisit the franchise with the trilogy years later. This cheesy and wacky set of games was so charming I was speechless. The characters are really fun and the cases and investigating really grabbed me in wanting to know what happened next. The only downside was a few cases in the trilogy where connecting some clues as evidence were really questionably reaching in terms of logic. Besides that, most cases made sense and had a good flow of story telling without feeling dragged out. It took me about 22-24 hours per game so you get a lot of play time  to finish all 3 games for the value of what you're paying. 

Now that I'm hooked on the franchise, I need to find and play the other games / spinoffs that have come out over the years and am looking forward to the localization of the Great Ace Attorney Chronicles coming soon!
