Game's pretty solid.

There are 3 things I like the most in this game. The story, characters and music.

Every cases in this game is like a bunch of tiny little puzzles that seems like they don't connect to each other, but when you finished the puzzle and the whole picture is shown, you would realize every piece of puzzles have their meanings in the picture. Although there are flaws in terms of logic in some cases, that is still enjoyable to playthrough.

The design and the development of characters is amazing. There are lots of characters are named with puns, like phoenix wright (Right, Wright?) himself. This makes the player remember those characters very well. Apart from their name, each characters in this game have wide range of 'phase' when encounter different situations. A prosecutor can proudly shake his head with his smug face and update the autopsy report from the court record, and next minute he punch his desk angrily and cut a detective's salary. This makes the emotions of each characters more visible and 'feels like more human'.

Finally, the music. I believe a game (In any genre) (Just my opinion) without a descent music would not be a great game. The music in this game is outstanding and suits the genre of the game. When you are in court cross-examining a witnesses and you find out a contradiction, the game reward you with a energetic and hopeful music with phoenix wright pointing towards the witnesses. When phoenix discovered that the witnesses on the stand is lying and potentially be the killer, the game starts playing a fast pace and thrilling music, encouraging the player to discover the whole truth. When you have won the 'Not guilty' verdict, the game plays a relaxing and happy music, telling you that you have won.

Overall: Very good game, definitely not regret buying this game

It has been years since I last played the original trilogy, and my god I'm amazed by how much quality is packed into here that I've forgotten about. You should definitely play the games in order as each game has its own, self contained overarching story, but they build into the next game and get developed on further.

By the third game you have so many small questions looming in the background that they build on and resolve within that one game that you'd be doing a disservice to JUST play Trials & Tribulations, although, you can and the game will still make sense. Every game is careful to give you all the required information for things to make sense, so if you ONLY had to play one, I'd play T&T.

However, that's not what you're getting here. You're getting the whole trilogy. And my god is it good.

The first game is a bit of an odd one since the trials are shorter than in the games released after it, and the investigation phases are simpler as well. On top of that, the trials in the first game are all fairly easy - the evidence all easily connects and you probably won't have any problems with it. This makes sense since it's the first game, so they didn't have the format nailed yet - but it also makes it a perfect introduction to the series.

It's not hard and it's not very long, plus the story is compelling enough and keeps throwing enough questions at you to keep you wanting the answers. When you get to episode 5, things change a little bit though...

Episode 5 was originally added as part of the DS port, AFTER the entire trilogy had already been released on GBA in Japan. This means that it contains references to future games, and the gameplay structure is more like the later games. On top of this it doesn't hold your hand, and it has some unique features that are only used in episode 5 of the first game (inspecting evidence, forensics, etc). The story in episode 5 isn't really important either, since it somewhat conflicts with the story of the second game (Justice For All) and feels more like an afterthought than anything else.

Don't feel obligated to play episode 5 of the first game once you've finished episode 4 is what I'm trying to say, it's really not necessary to your understanding or enjoyment of the rest of the games.

The second game (Justice For All) introduces some new gameplay mechanics (the magatama and the health bar system), as well as extends and expands the trials to take place over two parts. Overall though, JFA just isn't very interesting to me - I don't find episode 1 or 3 very interesting, and I don't even find episode 2 that interesting, outside of its story implications.

No, the real star of Justice For All is episode 4. Holy shit, episode 4. It makes the rest of the game worth playing through, even if you're not as engaged with it as the first game. It's worth mentioning as well that JFA doesn't feature an overarching story like the first or second game, so there's no real looming mysteries to wonder about. Just standalone cases to solve, which I'm sure is fine for some people but is a bit boring to me.

Finally, Trials & Tribulations. The third game. In my opinion, the best game in the trilogy. It takes all the information you've learned over the first two games, throws in some new characters, some new information, and builds on it for five solid episodes. From beginning to end, Trials & Tribulations is just completely solid. Especially once you get to episode 5, the final case of the entire trilogy - all the final mysteries, all the little tiny questions that still are unresolved, finally get answered, and it feels like the grandest love letter to a franchise in a while.

Pretty much every important character makes a return at some point in T&T, and in some really cool and unique ways. T&T was my favourite game in the trilogy back when I first played it, and after replaying it, has reaffirmed that it always will be.

Just an absolutely incredible trio of games, and I highly recommend playing them if you're even slightly interested.

It's kind of a shame that Apollo Justice took a small shit on Phoenix's character, and they never brought him back in the same way after... but if you're looking for more Ace Attorney, it's still a solid game if you can mentally disconnect it from this trilogy. Same goes for Dual Destinies, and while I've never played Spirit of Justice, I imagine that game also took some weird liberties with the series but it's probably still fun.

If you want another Ace Attorney game that doesn't go against the original trilogy, I'd highly recommend Ace Attorney Investigations. It's quite a bit different from the original games, but just as fun and takes liberties without feeling strange due to its design. You'd either need to emulate it or buy a DS copy though, as I don't think its ever been ported. There's also Investigations 2 which requires a fan patch because it was only released in Japan, if you want to go even further.

A huge amount of the reviews here assume everyone & their grandma has played this game. I hadnt. This  was my first playthrough. So my review isnt based off of any nostalgic feelings, rather a completely new experience based entirely on the this version.

TLDR: I absolutely loved the game, it was a unique experience and I absolutely recommend it. However, there are some minor things that bugged me throughout the series.

You are a defense attorney, tasked with proving your clients innocence. Each case you have to investigate the crime scenes, question people, etc and do your best to piece together the truth and then prove it in court through presenting evidence and pressing witnesses on the stand. Most of the time you will go into court with only a vague idea that something is off about the current version of the story the court is wanting to pass judgement on and then the truth is slowly uncovered between you and the prosecutor throughout the trial.

Speaking of the prosecutor... that is perhaps one of the best things about the game. Over the course of the series you develop a relationship with him. B the time you get to the last couple of cases, while you're still on opposing sides, you are working together to get to the truth rather than get a petty win despite the actual truth.

The cases are all extremely complex and not even slightly obvious in the beginning. And they take some serious thought to figure out. The evidence almost always holds multiple clues that you can piece together. The most seemingly irrelevant of details, are enough to change everything about a trial. Awesome game for people that like mystery and piecing together clues to find the truth.

While the game was great there were some minor things that just bugged me about it here and there. The keyboard mapping for a lot of things was just not intuitive and just downright weird. Its like they just "eeny meeny miny moed" which keys to use on a lot of things. For instance, rotating objects you're inspecting was mapped to H,N,B,M, Q, & R... Then E would "present" the object in court which of course when you're using Q & R to rotate an object.. Its really easy to tap E instead of R. Which leads to possibly taking a hit(You have a little health meter during a trial, you have to be careful not to present the wrong stuff too much or you'll lose the trial.) And/or you have to sit through long winded dialogue just to get back to inspecting the item.

And that brings me to another note and honestly this was perhaps the thing that annoyed me more than anything else in this game... being forced to click through the same dialogue over and over and over and over again when you go back to double check something or you accidentally click on it or accidentally present it...etc. And often its not just a quick one & done dialogue.. no, its a whole dang conversation that you're forced to just spam click to get through it all as fast as possible. Would have been really nice if they gave some kind of hotkey or option to completely skip the dialogue or exit it. Or simply had the long winded dialogue only shown for the first time then a quick piece of dialogue to easily dismiss after that one. Given the investigative &  mystery solving nature of the game, you find yourself stumped often and rechecking areas & items many times over trying to figure out what you missed and you will spend a great deal of time just trying to skip dialogue. One of the worst is when you're trying to present an item to a character to see if they have anything to say about it. Often times they wont.. Would be nice if they just said "Sorry, dont know anything about it." But no... most of the time this initiates a whole conversation between multiple characters.. And when they're done and you try to present something else to see if they know anything about it.. you have to click through that exact same entire conversation again if they dont. Which was just annoying to say the least.


Another thing that was kind of tough, was trying to figure out how to present things in court. You may have pieced together everything right from the get go, but presenting it in a controlled game at the right time where you dont have an actual voice to speak whats on your mind is an ordeal. So you have to press a witness on their statements to open up new dialogue options and then present the right piece of evidence towards the right statements. I found myself looking up walkthroughs on many things to figure this out. As I took many "hits" trying to present things to the wrong statements even though it made perfect sense in my mind why I may have presented something there, the game cant see that.

The judge is not the brightest bulb and the game is not based in any type of realism. The judges opinion is swayed with the blowing of the wind. And the judge is ready to pass judgement based on whatever conclusion he has on his mind at that specific moment. At first I found this kind of silly. But thats the mechanics of the game and after a while you realize his incompetency as a judge, only adds to the charm of the game and the verdict is essentially just left up to you and the prosecutor. 

All in all the game was wonderful. And I absolutely recommend it despite the minor inconveniences.

TL:DR: If you've played any PWAA game before these three, you'll still like them. Doesn't hurt to play at all.

So I started my Ace Attorney journey with Dual Destinies and immediately fell in love with the entire series after finishing Spirit of Justice. I've even seen the anime adaptation of the first game. But, I never played the original trilogy. 

Until now.

I remember reading somewhere that in the first release, you couldn't go backward in testimony. I'm glad that that was fixed in the port, but I think that takes away from how the game used to run. Something really frustrating, though, was how frequently you needed to save in the case that you messed up too often. In the newer games, once you failed a trial, you could pick it back up from where you failed. None of that was present in this trilogy, making the trial system a bit unforgiving for things not completely obvious or accidental selections. I'll say though that it's gotten me into a habit of saving my things more often. 

Port and logistics aside, the first three games that jumpstart the series following the well-known attorney were a rollercoaster. The amount of drama, comedy, and suspense was just right. Personally, I'm not quite a 2D fan, but understanding wanting to preserve nostalgia, I worked through. After about two cases, the problem of playing in 2D was immediately thrown out the window, as it became a massive interest to follow along with the story. The OST was wonderful as always, and yeah some of the character audio sounded weird, but I can't expect them to rerecord all of the character voice lines just to sound better. 

Now for just personal opinions that don't really have any bearing on the review. Out of all three, I think my favorite in the trilogy had to be Trials and Tribulations. It really felt like all of the cases were interconnected and really led back up to one person throughout the game. Dual Destinies and Spirit of Justice, along with Apollo Justice Ace Attorney do the same thing, which I love. All of the cases being interconnected by one overarching character or event just made the game feel more complete and unified. I can't really say that I hate the first game, because this is the first time that we are exposed to the characters of the series, so it should focus more on developing the characters to be seen throughout the series rather than a story. My least favorite in the trilogy, which I guess you can guess by now, was Justice for All. I just felt that there was no cohesion between the cases, and that there were just random scenarios put into place. The continuity was a nice touch, but it just didn't feel like there was anything built-upon from the first game. Also the introduction of presenting profiles as evidence in trials just made the game harder, which is a good thing, but at times became very confusing and tricky to figure out when to present them.

I've played this trilogy since the DS days many times now and it never gets old. If you're a new fan and haven't played a single Ace Attorney game yet, this is a great version to play on!

This Game is Fantastic. I loved everything about this trilogy. The plot was amazing, especially in the third game, where it wrapped everything up very nicely. The Gameplay only adds to the experience. It is fun trying to use your clues to point out contradictions and it offers a different experience than most visual novel games. The puzzles are mostly good, but sometimes the solution is too specific so even if you know the answer or what happened, it feels like you're fighting the game to progress. There are also very little hints as to what you need to do next in certain parts so often guides are needed. Those are mostly nitpicks, though, because everything else about this game is fantastic. Give this game a shot even if you aren't a big fan of visual novels, it is a lot more fun than it may first look like.

I wasn't originally going to give this game a review because I figured "it's Ace Attorney, everyone's already heard of it", but after playing through the final case (episode 5 of Trials and Tribulations), I felt compelled to give it a positive review. That episode has probably the best writing I have ever seen in a detective game, and it doesn't hold the player's hand either, you have to actually figure it out. Somehow they made a trial that is the culmination of everything the game was building up to and included a bunch of details and characters from the previous two games as well. Every episode in this series is good, but that last one is the best by far, and it was so rewarding to finally reach it after 65 hours and watch it unfold. This is a great game because it both starts strong and gets better as it goes. If you are a fan of detective games and solving puzzles, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a must have, especially if you can get it on sale.

Still an amazing series to this day. In fact, this version improves on several flaws from the original DS versions:  

-When you examine things, now they'll permanently tick things off that you've already examined so you don't end up wasting time examining the same thing over and over.  

-You can skip forward over text.  So if you've already beaten these games on the DS, you don't have to wait tediously for every text message to go by.  

One small criticism over the original, time played is tracked.  So if you are tired of a case and wanna AFK you can't just set it aside without having the game record you as having some ridiculous amount of hours played.  

If you haven't played this game before, you should.  It absolutely holds up to time.  Nothing really compares to this game.  There are games that tried to make something similar, but I'd easily say PW is the king of the genre.  

Graphics aren't a problem at all.  If you like anime graphics, then there shouldn't be an issue.  

There's actually some really great money value here.  Normally a new Ace Attorney game would cost $50.  So you are getting three of those for less than what a new release of the game costs.  

And don't worry, these oldest three games of the series, are IMO the best of the series.  Especially the first game, I mean OMG every case was amazing in the first game.  The newer games had to bend over backwards to create a mainline story however.  And the gameplay is pretty much the same with some slight exceptions.  

Like Dual Destinies used really bad 3D videos with terrible voice acting.  Apollo Justice had some less enjoyable protagonists with gimmicky abilities.  

I much prefer the first three games with NO voice acting and no gimmicks and a strong main storyline.  That's what you get here.

I bought it because I heard such rave reviews from everyone, including online and from friends. But... it's just totally unenjoyable. The entire game consists of repeatedly pressing the Enter button to walk through lengthy scenes of dialogue. The murder mysteries are vaguely compelling, but there's not enough player interaction to push them over the line into fascinating. 

The games are hopelessly linear; there's no way to distinguish oneself by playing "better" or "worse". The bits that ARE interactive - finding contradictions between evidence and testimony - fall in one of two buckets: either the answer is painfully obvious and it's boring, or the answer is impossible to get and you have to walk through all the options in order like a robot. And if you get a certain number wrong, it's back to the last save point, and more tedium as you click through what you've already read. It's also pretty annoying that when there's a revelation, the writer takes about 60 seconds longer than necessary to catch up to what the reader has already recognized, explaining the punchline in laborious detail. 

It's SO. BORING. Why did I keep playing?! I guess I kept waiting for it to get good? It's basically a poorly-written mystery novel with one-dimensional characters ("science girl"? "cowboy dude"... "frenetic patrolman") told in press-button-now-for-next-line format. So poorly written - basic, fundamental absurdities in the legal case. Who would conclude someone was "murdered in two places at once" if the body is at location A and there's no body at location B? Obviously they were murdered at location A. Christ. I genuinely don't understand the appeal. I don't find it funny, touching, shocking, or any of the other emotions people seem to be getting out of it. I don't get it.

So let me preface this by saying, I have no completed these games on steam, but throughout my life I have completed all the games in this series on the DS and 3DS. These games, alongside Professor Layton, were a huge part of my childhood. The soundtracks especially have stuck with me into adulthood and I still listen to them somewhat regularly. While these games aren't exactly riveting in the gameplay or graphics department, the story is the entire point of the game. This is one series I wish I could go back and experience for the first time again, as the story kept me engaged and shocked even in the filler cases.

If you're looking for a good story driven game, this is for you. Wholeheartedly recommend.

A classic! The game took be about 70 hours to complete one full playthrough of it. I'd like to make some points about the game.

First off I'd like to start off with the gameplay and story. This game is a Visual Novel, so the gameplay experience isn't super riveting, most of the time you're reading through character dialogue. This being said, you play this game for the story, not the gameplay. As for story, this game delivers a good story. It includes the original trilogy, each game has it's own individual story but builds to the main overarching story that becomes apparent in the third game in the trilogy. The final case incorporates things that you learned about the plot from all across the trilogy and is a good finale.

For all of you who love to get 100% of the achievements, this game includes 30 and it is very easy to get all of them in one playthrough. About half of the achievements are just clearing sections of the game. There are a few achievements you can miss but they're easy enough to get without much hassle.

No game is perfect, I do have a few complaints about the game. The trials can be a bit frustrating and drawn out. A lot of times there will be multiple pieces of evidence that can contradict something but the game will only accept one or two as valid. Other times it can be confusing about what the game actually wants you to do/present in the trial which can be a real pain.

I would recommend to use a controller if you have one, it allows a more relaxed experience. I'd also recommend to prepare to pay attention to very small and seemingly insignificant facts and details about evidence/cases as more often than not they come into play during the trials.

Overall, a good game. Memorable characters and a memorable story!

Good game. Good Characters. Good Cases (mostly). Good Gaffs.

"The only time a lawyer can cry is when it's all over,"
Objection if you don't like this game!

When the game works well, it's a blast. [b]However, I had to take regular breaks between the included chapters ("games"), and occasionally between cases because it was regularly infuriating[/b] (see "The Bad" below). I'd recommend keeping a walkthrough handy to avoid the frustrating bit of moon logic that exists in all three games. In the absence of a middling review option, I'm giving this a bad review, just because it won't ding the overall hype train score and may show up more to potential buyers.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Lengthy game (50-80 hours?) if you're playing blind. I had a lot of paused time.
+Humorous, and improved localization text as games progress.
+Colorful artwork.
+Simple, clear interface.

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Some Japanese culture that is out of place/unfamiliar in the West.
~Game can go full-anime (never go full anime) at times, which may be a little silly/over-the-top for non-weebs.
~Some annoying characters that keep coming back.
~Music tracks are catchy, but often short, which becomes annoying when stuck.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Game absolutely requires save scumming and occasionally looking up a guide, bringing immersion, momentum and fun to a grinding halt.
-The game often gives instant game overs for penalties, which doesn't mesh well with the next issue.
-Evidence selection is THE most frustrating part about this game:

1. There are often multiple valid pieces of evidence for a situation, but the game only wants ONE. Read its mind or be penalized.

2. You have to follow the game's path of exposing contradictions. If you try to expose another, bigger, more obvious contradiction, you'll be penalized. If you try to expose the expected contradiction via different (usually more simple) methods, you'll be penalized. Read its mind or be penalized.

3. Old evidence isn't removed from your inventory, and in larger cases may amount to dozens of items. However, the game's very inconsistent on when ancient evidence may be used a second time, adding to the frustration on when you get stuck (see #1 and 2). 

4. Game is very inconsisent on the level of cleverness/perception required of you. Spotting tiny inconsistencies is critical in some areas, and yet punished in others (see #2). The dev said he wanted the game to be simple enough for his mother to play. I'm fine with casual mother- or OCD sleuth-level difficulty. Just pick one and stick to it, or ramp it up. The "difficulty" is a roller coaster (see #2).

[u]Example:[/u]
Let's say your disabled miltary veteran client is accused of shooting someone with a rifle at a range of 200 yards. The court asks you to prove your client could not have shot the victim. Pertinent evidence belonging to your client is as follows: a pair of glasses with an incorrect prescription, medical documentation of their crippled right arm and shoulder and their glass right eye.

Which piece do you present?
A. The glasses that show your client would not have been able to see clearly.
B. The medical documentation that shows your client could no longer hold a rifle.
C. The glass eye that shows your client has no depth perception and little ability to use a sight/scope.

Your choice?
A? Wrong, penalty.
Ok, B? Wrong, penalty.
Fine! C! Wrong, penalty.

Save scum and find out the answer was:
D. You needed to present a photo of your client, which will bring up the fact that when being sworn-in earlier, your client raised his left hand, proving that he could not use his right arm, and thus, could not have held a gun properly.
WTF?

The prosecutor will then object, stating that your client could have held a gun in his left hand. Aaaand, now we're back to a 33% guess at picking A, B or C. Except you won't be able to present any of those until you go through two passes of the same cross-examination, pressing for additional information on EACH pass. The game won't accept its expected evidence until AFTER you do that. If you try beforehand, you'll be penalized.
---------------

This sort of situation happens at least once on every case...and sometimes even during evidence collection. I eventually learned to keep a guide handy, just to peek at a single line of what to do or say next to get past the hare-brained game logic. It was always pleasant and smooth sailing between logic walls.

Simply put, these games are all flair with no actual meaningful usage of its systems. Linear and boring because of it, scripted with nothing of actual value to the player, to make the player actually be smart. Instead It's the opposite "Oh damn Phoenix is so funny and smart". In short, a very polarizing experience when viewed through a particular angle, which is unfortunately my angle.

[h1] The Problems [/h1]

The main problem with this game, for me personally, is that there is no attachment to the people you're supposed to defend. These cases just get dropped on you, and while yes, their personalty is always ( in my case since I didn't finish the game ) eccentric and "fun". There is no tangible goal, there is no actual connection that makes me care if they get put in fucking jail or if I can save their life with my incredibly funny and witty dialogue.

The other problem I have is that the game is too fucking linear. First lets dissect the portion of gameplay which is used before the case begins in court. I like to call this the "Follow the obvious" part of the game. At first this was actually quite fast paced, and didn't hinder my experience that much with the series. But at episode 3 titled "Turnabout Samurai" this problem just become a tedious mess. For a bit over 1,5  maybe even 2  hours, I was stuck, because the game can bug >IF YOU DON'T GO THE WAY IT WAS SCRIPTED AND INSTEAD GO ANOTHER WAY<. I would literally not have been able to pass through this section if I didn't end up going on a forum for  a >STEP BY STEP< guide on how to progress. Apart from this, these sections are quite shallow, and get boring far too easy because they overstay their welcome and It's easy to get all the evidence, because the game throws that shit in your face, you can't fucking miss it.

Now for the other problem, which is the main case itself, or rather, when you actually get into the court room. Now I'm not gonna lie and say that these sections aren't exhilarating, well paced, and well written. But again the problem here isn't with that, the problem is that they are simply too fucking easy. You again follow a >linear story< that makes it obvious what you need to do to progress it. And at points it actually fails to do even that. Not in a good way tho, where you are supposed to actually use your brain, it's a confusing mess and you're basically left with a guessing game of >Is this what I'm "SUPPOSED" to pick?<. Imagine what kind of a failure as a game this is, if it can't even make you use your brain effectively to solve a court case.

This is also one of the things that made me so mad, and almost had me put the game down. If I'm not mistaken its the final portion of the case in episode 2, where you're supposed to cross examine some dude's statement. And I was sitting there, for 20 minutes, thinking what the fuck I'm supposed to do. I cross examined his EVERY, SINGLE, FUCKING, WORD only to not progress. Turns out right...stay with me now...you're supposed to not do anything, and just read through it 2 times. After that your dead mentor, comes back from the dead, in the body of her sister, and gives you some evidence with which you win the case? Hello? What? The? Fuck?

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

This game is only a recommendation for people that want a "feels good game", something that is entertaining on the surface level. Because at that, this game excels, the witty and fun dialogue, the fast paced court "battles" with Edgeworth make for some of the most exciting moments here. But if you were looking for something that will make you think about solving the case, something more grounded and complex, this simply isn't that. In that case, I say stray far away from this franchise and don't listen to everyone who sucks it's dick.

I originally got this game as I was looking for a visual novel to pass the time while I was living abroad for a while. To be honest, I wasn't expecting too much - I had played some similar games before and was looking for something where I get to use my own logic and think things through instead of just mindlessly clicking to pass the story. But it turned out to be much more than just that.

To begin with, it was exactly what I had expected - a solid visual novel with a compelling setting that really made you use your brain and seem like you are in control of the story, even when there is no real choice or multiple story paths. Having the choice of moving around, investigating and talking to characters somewhat freely gives the game a more active feel than many other visual novels. And, above all, it really gives you a sense of accomplishment when you're able to find a well hidden contradiction and crack the case.

Sure, the game has its quirks and annoyances. Occasionally I spent 20 minutes stuck in a cross-examination having not realized that you might, in fact, need to press some statements twice to get all the information. Or I figured out a key point or a contradiction during the investigation, and then frustratedly tried sixteen different combinations of witness statements and evidence to bring that contradiction out in court, before realizing there was something else I had to point out before I could do that. Or I could not progress the investigation by talking to a witness because I had not presented the victim's profile to Detective Gumshoe to get more details. I get that sometimes the story needs to progress in a certain order, but when you get no pointers as to what is missing for you to proceed, it can cause occasional spikes in blood pressure.

But what got me hooked was the story. Although it felt in the beginning that each case was a separate entity along Phoenix's path, the further the games progressed, the more everything began to link up. Especially the third game of the trilogy brought everything together in ways I could have never predicted, making sense of plot points I had not even thought were plot points to begin with. The characters are well-written and interesting, with personality quirks and witty remarks that make you laugh and feel for them (and, occasionally, groan and roll your eyes). In the end, I noticed I truly cared about these characters, who - let's face it - are nothing but pixels on my screen and words in the game files. If that's not the sign of a good story and excellent writing, I don't know what is. And when the truth came out at the end of the game, there may have been a few tears shed. But I guess that's okay - a lawyer only cries when it's all over, anyway.

Now I'm just really bummed that [spoiler]Phoenix and Iris never got (back?) together in any of the following games of the series[/spoiler].

At this point, if anyone is still thinking this game is not worth it, all I can say is...

OBJECTION!

[h1] Overview [/h1]
Where there's a Wright, you can't be wrong. This gem of a series captures every suspense and comedy a visual novel has to offer as you step into the shoes of the beloved defense attorney, Phoenix Wright. While there are other instances for you take the roles of various characters in the series, you are mainly playing as Wright.

[h1] Gameplay and Mechanics [/h1]
The concept of the game is straightforward. To summarize the life of a lawyer quoted by me, a non-lawyer, it can be broken down into case investigations, witness cross-examinations, contradiction exposure within witness testimonies, and evidential arguments.

[h1] Design and Visual [/h1]
If you grew up playing Ace Attorney on Game Boy Advance or Nintendo DS, the visuals just look more crisp now. The art style, together with the stereoscopic 3D, makes the Ace Attorney trilogy look even more like a graphic novel than before.

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]
What can I say? It's classic stuff. Nothing I love more than a mix between orchestrated instruments and synthesizers to take me back to my childhood.

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]
Despite the game being a lawyer's parody and satire with its light-hearted absurdities, it does a fine work of balancing those with darker scenarios to build up a satisfying finale. You can't help but to adore Phoenix as his character develops throughout the conversations in-game. Also, Miles Edgeworth is possibly one whose character arc I found most compelling in the series. Goes to show 'You can't judge a book by its cover' by playing Ace Attorney.

Likeable characters, memorable court room battles and a very well localised script. This is a compelling 40+ hours of gaming which you can drop in and out of at your leisure thanks to generous save points.

My only gripe is some court cases feel very inflexible with the sequence the plot forces you to present evidence - sometimes it's obvious what you need to present, but it's not clear which line of testimony needs the rebuttal. 

The series would really benefit from a 'key phrases' journal to help you refresh on important spoken lines that are easily forgotten between play sessions.

This is very minor though, and most cases present a fair challenge if you just read your court record thoroughly and think what's been said through logically.

A unique gaming experience, and worth it for the memes it opens up to you.
way to fucing addicting
I absolutely adore the game. It has unique characters and an amazing story!

What an experience! Starting with the strongest features:
The sound design is truly incredible. A great soundtrack used impeccably to present a compelling narrative.
Characters in these games are amazingly well-structured and multi-faceted individuals with their own motives and personalities. The Japanese designers are not afraid of cliches, yet this has allowed their crime stories to be much more believable. 
The overall pacing and storytelling of each narrative is superb, largely because of the two factors explained above. This series WILL get you invested in the storylines and you will want to figure out exactly what's going on. The twists and turns are well disguised when appropriate.

The general worldbuilding follows the same quality standard, being very coherent, yet simplified to fit within the context of one court case at a time.
Graphically, these games are certainly a product of their time - however, their quality standards are simply perfect. There are no compromises in quality, no shortcuts taken - all character models and poses, all backgrounds and evidence - all the graphical models meet a consistent and stylistic theme that stays on-point for all three games. I have never seen this accomplished in other series to such a degree as it is here. Japanese developers clearly made this game and their craftsmanship is wonderful.

Now for the meat. In somewhat predictable fashion, there are major flaws. Some of the cases presented have obvious logical flaws, especially those numbered 3 or 4 in their respective games. 
Often, there are rounds of questioning where some evidence leads to an obvious verdict, yet that evidence cannot be presented yet as the writers simply chose to write the story in a different direction. Again, this is much more common in certain chapters (2 and 3) rather than in others, across the 3 games.
The actual "lawyering" of this game is very stylised to the fictitious world of the series, and you're not really going to learn anything about process or proper practice. Come into this game world expecting a corrupt, inconsistent, illiberal, nonchalant judge and court system in general or you WILL be disappointed.

So in summary, my praise lies in the relatively superficial elements of the games and my criticism is steeped in the gameplay and progression itself. Normally, this would condemn a title to a poor rating. However, in this case the aforementioned good points far outweigh the negatives, even if they lie in seemingly less important areas. It simply changes the nature of the games. Don't expect a puzzle game, or an exercise in logic. To clarify, you will need to think hard at points to solve the logic puzzles and complete the cases without a walkthrough, but these games shine far more brightly as interactive novels. You're paying to feel like a part of many different stories spanning half a dozen hours each, and a greater overarching narrative. And these are some of the greatest stories you've ever heard.

The game is a really good detective visual novel. Since VNs are heavy on the dialogue, the game makes the most of it by having the dialogues a core part of the game mechanics. Reading through witness accounts, police reports, etc. to find a inconsistency which you can use to break down small lies as well as bigger lies to find the truth. It's overall very rewarding to find the tiniest hole in someone's testimony and watch it all fall down. 

Unfortunately, the nature of a mystery game is that it can only be fully enjoyed. Once you know the twists and reveals, the game loses all of its surprises. You know who the criminal is, you know how he did it, why he did it, and subsequent playthroughs will become simple connect the dots game. 

One small thing I dislike about this game would be how exact you sometimes have to be in order to proceed even if you manage to pinpoint the contradiction. 
For example, evidence A and evidence B enter in contradiction. But you can't raise an objection beforehand until either of them is mentioned in someone's testimony. 
And it can be really arbitrary which one you should pick as well. If the witness mentions evidence A and you bring up evidence B to show the contradiction, the game does a brain fart and doesn't allow it despite having done so in prior levels.  Instead, you have to present evidence A, which then gives you the chance to also bring up evidence B.

Besides that one small annoyance that happens maybe twice in the whole game, I'd wholeheartedly recommend it to people who enjoy Visual Novels and/or Detective Mysteries. It's probably one of the games I'll miss the 1st experience the most.

Two things I'd like to mention:

1. Witness testimonies will often include SEVERAL contradictions with the evidence, but the game will only consider ONE of them to be the correct "answer." To add insult to injury, once you present an actual contradiction that the game deems as "wrong," you get penalized and basically lose health. Pretty much, you're forced to use save states to counter the game's way of handing you penalties for incredibly stupid reasons. 

Here are some fantastic examples:

A witness heard TWO gunshots. The murder weapon fired THREE bullets. Contradiction? ABSOLUTELY. Contradiction that the game wants you to find/deems as the only correct answer? NOPE.

A witness claims to have seen the defendant stabbing a victim with their right hand. No fingerprints were found on the murder weapon. No explanation is currently available. Yes, it's explained later, but only later, and is still a contradiction with the current testimony and evidence. Now, it wouldn't be so bad if the witness just said "they were wearing gloves dumbass," but they didn't say that. Instead, the judge penalizes your ass and back to the menu to load a save state you go.

Basically, you can find something with the current testimony and evidence, but unless it's the ONE correct answer, the game offers no explanation and no progression, just a penalty and a trip to the save/load data menu.

If there is one thing I absolutely despise in any video game, it's losing for bullshit reasons. As proven by the two examples above, this game can and will have you lose for bullshit reasons if you don't counter the bullshit with save states. Please, do not come to me with "sAvE sTaTeS aRe cHeAtInG" because I'd like to see YOU somehow navigate around all the """"wrong"""" contradictions in this game, especially with shit like the first example, on your first try.

2. For this second thing, let me give you a sequence of events:
-The witness claims to have seen the defendant performing a sequence of actions
-The game even provides a slideshow of the witness and defendant on the map when the witness claims to have seen the defendant
-There is an OBVIOUS, and I mean OBVIOUS problem: the witness is claiming to have seen the defendant through a fucking wall. 
-I present the map to prove that the witness cannot have seen the defendant. Why? Because of the fucking wall blocking the line of sight!
-Penalty!
-I look up TWO different guides for the case. TWO. What do they both tell me? That I did it correctly! I was supposed to present the map as evidence! I did everything correctly! The witness couldn't have seen the defendant! The witness was lying and I uncovered it correctly the first time!
-What is my conclusion? The game somehow broke and blocked off all further progression, despite being a fucking point and click adventure!

How, how, how, how, how!? How can a FUCKING POINT AND CLICK ADVENTURE break like this? 

Not only is the gameplay questionable with all the """"incorrect"""" contradictions, but the game managed to fucking break and block off all further progression.

Story for the cases? Fantastic. The murder plots, uncovering of the murder plots, and how everything seems to make sense when the truth is revealed? Fantastic. The """"incorrect"""" contradictions? Gameplay ruining. The fact that a point and click adventure managed to break and block off all further progression? Astounding.

Please don't bother with this shit. Just watch a playthrough on youtube or watch the anime.

I didn't play this game until it was on sale for 50% off, but after playing it I would have paid full price for it. It's one of my favorite gaming experiences I've ever had.
This game has it all. The beginning cases aren't as compelling as the later ones, but I still enjoyed every case and I couldn't have expected how amazing the finale turned out to be. The third game ties up every loose end in such a satisfying way. 
There is plenty of humor in the dialogue. I found myself laughing hard many times. The character interactions are fantastic. Despite the large number of silly moments, the serious ones still have massive impact. The plot twists are sometimes predictable, and sometimes not. Most of the writing is incredible and I fell in love with all the characters. Their motivations make sense and their backstories are colorful.
I was shocked at how well the cases were put together. The games should definitely be played in order, because plenty of characters and ideas are brought over from the preceding cases.
I know it isn't for everyone, but I love the soundtracks. I enjoy how they mixed up the music so it wasn't all the same. For example, some tracks come back from the first and second games in the third one, but there are also new themes and remixes of old ones. The soundtrack has an important role in gameplay for highlighting impactful scenes or sets of dialogue, or just adding emphasis to court cases (you'll see).
I teared up multiple times while playing, especially in the more important cases. I've seen multiple people say they wish they could forget playing the games just so they could experience them again, and I echo that sentiment. I haven't had the chance to play the other games in the franchise yet (and I'm not sure they could touch the majesty of this original trilogy) but I plan to as soon as I get the chance.
I couldn't recommend this game enough. It's worth the money.

[b]Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy[/b] is superb. Definitely one of the best experiences that gaming has to offer.
Let me preface the review by saying that this game is not suited for childs. Some people have the misconception that this game is childish, nothing farther from the truth. This game deals with murder, lies, betrayal, and sociopathy.

You are [b]Phoenix Wright[/b], a defense attorney whose job is to prove that your clients are innocent in the court of law; to do so, you will have to investigate the area of the crime, dialogue with diverse people, find witnesses, and show exactly why your client did not commit the crime they're being charged with.

There are two different phases in this game; the investigative section, and the court of law section. Each plays completely different, and the court of law marks the end of each chapter. And each chapter, is a different story, which makes for great 2 hours playthroughs.

It plays very much like a visual novel, with so many unique and likable characters that it absorbs you, in the same vein of watching a fantastic show. There are also great antagonists and villains, Edgeworth being one of the most famous in the gaming scene, who has remarkable animations and dialogues. Guaranteed to make your blood boil.

In my humble opinion, I recommend getting the game and playing it without knowing anything about it, and trying it out for 2 hours (this is the refund policy of Steam), if you remotely like or feel entertained in these 2 hours, it only [b]gets better[/b], so you'll make a safe bet. If you dislike how it is, then no worries, maybe try it later on. 

I recommend this game to everyone, honestly, you can dislike Visual Novels and still get a kick out of this saga. There's a reason why it's one of the most famous detective games. It'll stay in your memories forever.

I completely understand why this is such a classic. At the end of the day it still has issues with the fact that it's a point and click game with a nice coat of paint, and as such has pitfalls where you simply get stuck until you click on the right thing or use the obscure item in the right place, and I definitely feel that element hasn't aged too well when compared to an adventure series like Danganronpa or Zero Escape. But what this brought to the table was its charm, world, and characters. It took until late into the first game and after the characters were really grounded for me to get hooked, but once I was this didn't let up. There's nothing quite like figuring out the case right when you're in the thick of it alongside the blunders of the rest of the cast. Not every case is amazing and some things can be quite predictable, but the cases with lasting impact absolutely shine.

To put it simply, I'm not someone who often puts 50 hours into a game but this was fun as hell, even with the jank of the gameplay . Classic cast of characters, great progression, great at just having you care and putting you on the spot. If you're like visual novels, travesties of the court system, or a good fun rollercoaster of a story, you gotta play it. It takes some time to get its footing and its gameplay can have frustrations, but those are small hiccups in the overall excellent experience.

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy masters character building in a way no other game does. Thanks to peculiar habits (which are very well depicted in even the shortest dialogs and animations) and telling visual characteristics, it takes but a short time until you get to hold a character dear or hated. That's when the game starts playing with your feelings, all while presenting flashbacks, creative twists, and facts that might change your opinions on each of them.

It gets even better if you play Dai Gyakuten Kenji, as you get to learn how much some of the characters matured since their first cases. I wish I could give some examples, but that'd spoil the surprise. For now, go ahead, gather evidence, and prepare yourself to yell Objection!

The fact  these games were released on the GBA, DS, 3DS, Mobile, and now Steam should give you a good enough impression to begin with. That is the reason I gave the Phoenix Wright a chance on my old DSi, despite the bland cover art. This series' two biggest pulls are  the sound and character design. From the moment the iconic 'Pursuit ~ Cornered' theme was blasted through my DSi's speakers, I was hooked. I felt like a genius. I felt like a badass. From that moment I knew I'd be playing the whole series through, and when I finally ran out of games to consume, I felt a sad emptiness. Fortunately with  a year or two away from it, one may return and enjoy the experience once again, although with a bit less difficulty than the first time around.

The characters are the game's second big positive. Each is unique in design, often with a pun for a name that describes what kind of person they are, You'll either fall in love with them, and become engrossed in their backstories, always rooting for them to win, or hate them, and enjoy watching their meltdown in court as you peel apart their lies and lay the pressure on. 

With each subsequent game, new features are added to keep things fresh, while maintaining the same core system, as well as recurring fan favorite characters.

It really is a must buy.

This is truly a nice game to play. It actually contains three somewhat short games meant for a Nintendo, but upgraded to work in a computer. I won't comment on what this game exactly is, others here will cover that for.
Pros:
+ Likeable characters: most characters are likeable, a big plus.
+ First game contains some really cool cases, third game all of them were quite interesting.
+ Lazy controls: only need your mouse.
+ Price: this is a difficult aspect for story games with no replayability, but this game is probably priced just right. Especially when on sale, this game is more than worth it.
+ The game grows better. The first cases won't be much special, but after those, cases will become
+ Game signals people well when to save and when something new is possible.
+ The game won't let you proceed unless you have everything. So no fear that you missed clues before going to a trial.

Minor negatives:
- You will play three not so difficult tutorial cases.
- Sometimes it's really obscure on how to advance. Fortunately, good guides exist.
- The stories don't always make sense. And people lie too much for little good reason. Game overs also don't always make sense. Like, you try to get someone a guilty verdict, but game over (because of mistakes) with a guilty verdict, which is exactly how you will end. The plot twists are great in this game, but the stories aren't of that level.
- The pool of culprits is usually so small, that there is little suspense about who did it. The game is much more about puzzling how it happened and how it ties to a person.

Major negatives:
- !!! Contains lots of white flashing !!! If you're sensitive to that, don't buy this! Especially the first game contained so much flashing I was getting annoyed by it.
- Second game was honestly lackluster compared to the other two.
- This game demanded all of my GPU, for some reason. If you're on an average computer, don't expect to run this game alongside something else.
- The game isn't always watertight. I won't forget the one time I pointed out this contradiction:
witness: "They got stabbed in the chest"
me: "Objection! The autopsy says they got stabbed in the back!"
judge: "I see no contradiction. Here, get a penalty."
There will be times where a certain testimony or evidence might get you to correct conclusions, but the game won't allow you.

Even though I suck at logic and building arguments, I really enjoyed playing this. Most of the game's logic is pretty well thought out and it doesn't really include moon logic. However, it's not the puzzles that make this trilogy good but the presentation. It's when the music stops to leave you in suspense and then the pursuit music starts playing. That's around the moment where you go "Ha! I got you now!" That to me is what the best part of the game is.

As much as I love this trilogy, some of the characters in the final game just don't hold a light to the old ones. The prosecutors are the best example of this. In the third game, Godot isn't anywhere near as fun and interesting to fight against as both von Karmas. I freaking love how over the top both of them are but Godot just didn't cut it for me.

Anyways, this trilogy is really good and I recommend it to anyone. I would also not worry about being ashamed of using a walkthrough for this. You can still enjoy the game with the answers revealed to you.

Can i just say. This is awesome. 11/10 would play a second trilogy.
Like, YES, there are a few characters who are really annoying, but it seems like that's kinda the point... so it's okay. Besides, the cast is hardly the best thing about the series.
The twists are intense. You think 'oh, i see this twist coming from a mile away' but then you find out that the entire thing was completely different AND HERE'S WHY. Each crime makes sense from an overview point at the end and it pieces together nicely.
The absurdity of the cases strain belief, but that's a good thing. There's no way that a case would be solved by EXACTLY ONE piece of evidence that suddenly clears everything up, and in just about every real case, there's much unused evidence or evidence that's more significant, whereas in ace attorney, if a piece of evidence is used once, you can be fairly sure it won't be used again. And that's putting aside the fact that the cases made by both sides would NOT stand in any reasonable court.
BUT that's THE REASON that it works. Any logical case in the real world is generally solved with minimal evidence and 'the truth' is not the primary focus. You're not gonna find out exactly what happened, but Ace Attorney cases are different. They are SATISFYING. You KNOW WITHOUT A SHADOW OF A DOUBT that THAT GUY was the guilty party and EXACTLY HOW THEY COMMITED THE CRIME.
BOOM. 11/10 would play a second trilogy

If you like games like Danganronpa, then this title is perfect for you.

You play as a defense attorney, whose purpose is to prove the truth behind every case that he's involved in.
The game mechanics are made out of two elements:
-trials
	find clues that might help you solve the case
 -investigation
	 spot all the contradiction

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy are an "Attorney" (detective) visual novel with point-and-click element when you are investigating cases for your trial. Set in a country (which based on the game translation is supposed to be in USA) with dystopia legal system which you have to finish your case in three days after it is on the court.

You are playing to investigate facts outside of the court; and gave defense as an attorney by finding contradiction on the court room so you can unveil the truth. You have to pay attention to the details on the game to find those contradiction and that is what make this game interesting, which is when you actually find lies and bring out the truth in the court room.

This game seems ok at the beginning but becomes really tedious and boring. You'll be doing the same exact thing over and over again. The testimony will be changed a few times per witness, the court will be adjourned a few times, you'll have to visit every location again, talk to the same people again. Presenting evidence sometimes makes little sense. Also the non-case related dialogues are boring too. So that's it, if you want to play this game, prepare for doing the same thing over and over and over...

What can I say, as a novice to this entire series it completely blew past all of my hopes and ideas.
Overall a really fun, witty, hilarious, and cute game. Spent a lot of time just trying to learn more about the characters and being completely blown away by the ways in which the cases would always end up connecting everyone in the universe to one another time and time again.

+ excellent artwork, with limited but awesome animation
+ each case takes about 3-5 hours to complete, especially if you don't look at a guide. Its perfectly satisfying, even the worst of the cases was super entertaining
+everything comes together at the end SUPER well. Each trilogy has an arc, and so does the whole trilogy, in really unexpected ways. Especially the final 2 cases in each series is incredible, more than all, the finale!
+ the characters are all super quirky and fun - even the side characters. Maybe not PC enough for this day and age (the gay french chef anyone?) but i loved it

+ OBJECTION!! HOLD IT!! BUY IT!!

[u]2020 Speedy Review Cleanup[/u]

If I was voting based on the first [i]Phoenix Wright[/i] game in this trilogy, I'd give a "Yes." However, the 2nd game completely killed my interest in the middle of it. I took a break to see if I'd return to the 3rd one, but there's other things I'd rather do with my time.

That being said, the first game isn't flawless either.

If I had to summarize my biggest issue, it would be that the games become very tedious. I understand that law work would be tedious in real life; but these games obviously aren't going for "realistic" law work anyway. They're tedious in the way they design the investigations with weird loopholes, nonsense reasons that you can't use sensible evidence, the fact that you have to press people on one statement versus another that should have lead to the same thing, confusing ways to find certain evidence, and so on. The longer I played, the less intuitive things were.

Nevertheless, I overall enjoyed every case in the first game, plot-wise. Miles Edgeworth could be frustrating but he's a well-rounded character when the game shows his story. That said, old Manfred von Karma bothered me during his case in the first game. And little did I know, his relative Franziska would become one of my most-hated characters of all time during the second game.

As the games went on, I felt like there was way too much useless text and it only got worse in the second game, especially when the cases seemed to be of a larger scale. It's worse when you could essentially prove something did or didn't happen, but then the game would bring something up that "invalidated" it, even though logically it doesn't invalidate anything. Between Franziska's most annoying interruptions and whip-cracking (I absolutely [i]hated[/i] her for that) and doing stupid mechanics to completely overturn the cases, and my distaste for the the psychic case and the bigger mess of the circus case, I stopped playing.

And well, I just haven't gone back, nor do I feel like I'm missing much. I probably should have stopped when I completed the first game.

[b]The final major game I want to review this year is one [u]I haven’t even finished yet…[/u] or well, I haven’t finished [u]all three[/u] anyway. And I think this is kind of the biggest compliment that I can give Ace Attorney. Ace Attorney is [i]lots[/i] of fun. And for a guy who doesn’t really get into visual novels, I am thoroughly enjoying this trilogy. A lack of impactful decision-making and consistency issues may leave some disappointed, but the [u]sheer amount[/u] of absurdity and hilarity in each installment is reason alone to buy this.[/b]

The Ace Attorney Trilogy is a [i]really interesting[/i] bundle to review because not only is it three games in one, it’s three games which are (mostly) anthologies, several episodes of disconnected works that are grouped together. On top of that, the first game includes a DLC chapter that was written and produced after all three of the games in this set had been produced. What this means is that: 1) The quality of any episode in a particular installment can vary greatly and 2) the trilogy itself can vary greatly depending on the quality of each game. But these two reasons are why I’m reviewing the trilogy right here and now. I am about halfway through game 3, and I can certifiably tell you Ace Attorney trilogy is without a doubt worth its [u]full price, even if you only play the first game,[/u] which I think is the best game I’ve played so far.

Ace Attorney, being a visual novel, is all about the characters. And while there are some characters I love, and some characters I hate, almost all of them I [u]enjoy[/u]. You know the saying, [i]“I love to hate”?[/i] That’s how I feel about [i]almost all[/i] of the characters in Ace Attorney. Save for a select few, I really enjoy every character in the series and I’m almost done with all three games. The characters are quite distinct, well animated, and super memorable with the way they talk. That is to say, each character’s writing is [i]expertly done[/i] and this is the greatest strength of the development team of Ace Attorney. You reach a point in the series where you can pretty reliably predict what many characters will say at any given time, and that provides a lot of enjoyment.

A weakness, however, is consistency between chapters and between games. This consistency issue is multi-fold, too. For example, near the end of game 1, Phoenix and Gumshoe sort of work together for a very special case, and despite connecting in this time, at the beginning of game 2, the dialogue heavily implies some kind of rivalry or animosity between them. It makes almost no sense given the results of game 1, but alas. These types of strange relationships and inconsistencies run amuck in Ace Attorney, and they damage the amount of fun you get out of the series as a whole. The games are separated into episodes, yes, but you can clearly see the developers try to link relationships and storylines between them, something they get better at doing the further along you get in the series (perhaps this was because they didn’t know they would get a 2nd installment on release of the original?), so it ruins enjoyment when there are inconsistencies in the way characters interact between episodes. Either Ace Attorney needs total disconnection between episodes and games [i](thus requiring all new characters for each episode (this would be a mistake))[/i] or it needs more threads linking chapters together [i](the right choice).[/i] In the end it stands somewhere in the middle, and takes a huge hit because of this.

In this same vein, there is a lack of frontloading which cuts into overall game impact. Many characters are introduced to be big names in the world of Ace Attorney, major characters that [i]Phoenix[/i] is aware of and has pre-established opinions on. Despite this, there’s little effort in the writing and world-building to lay the groundwork for how [i]we as the player[/i] should feel when we meet said characters. For example, the incredible prowess of Edgeworth and his ability as a prosecutor is supposed to be something we fear and are in awe of, but there’s little in the game to help establish this feeling, so the first showdown against him in the courtroom is less impactful than it should be. This is something (funnily enough) the [i]anime[/i] does a lot better, which undoubtedly is because it was produced years after the games, and a reflection that many were dissatisfied with the lack of frontloading. This is a reoccurring issue in Ace Attorney, particularly with rival prosecutors!

One major success of Ace Attorney though is the internal logic of the game. [u]This isn’t to say that the game makes a lot of sense in the real world or even slightly resembles what a courtroom is like in real life.[/u] Ace Attorney is a wildly stupid game in terms of its attempts to replicate anything close to a normal court setting and trials. But Ace Attorney [i]is[/i] consistent with its game logic. That is to say, once you start to understand how the game works, you can follow the flow pretty well. You learn [u]how Ace Attorney wants you to think[/u], but despite this, the writers still manage to pull the rug out from under your feet time and time again with total hilarity and absurdity. This is how Ace Attorney avoids being a frustrating experience. This position is supported by the fact that when I looked up hints on walkthrough sites I often said, [i]“Oh! I should’ve known that!”[/i] as opposed to, [i]”How the heck would I have guessed that?”[/i]

There is also a good sense of expansion and development between each installment. Game one is quite limited in terms of the game features. You talk to people, search for clues during investigation periods, and press witnesses and highlight contradictions in the courtroom. In game two, however, you have the [i]psyche-lock[/i] system which provides more of the interrogation part of the game that is so fun and provides a lot more frequent switch between the two typed of gameplay that help improve the sometimes slow and drawn-out parts of the games.

On that note though, this makes the DLC chapter in game 1 particularly weird. As it was developed years after the release of game 1 originally, it feels [i]extremely[/i] out of place with few recurring characters, several new systems for a singular chapter, and a totally different kind of internal logic to that which you had experienced up until that point. Again, Ace Attorney’s biggest failure is its consistency.

One way Ace Attorney [u]is[/u] superbly consistent however, is its soundtrack. [i]Holy moly,[/i] these soundtracks are [u]absolute bops.[/u] Game 1 has one of the most fitting soundtracks I’ve ever heard for any game ever, and the sound [i]effects[/i] are all top notch, too. I started off not loving the soundtrack to game 2, but then it really grew on me, and I find myself feeling the same way about game 3’s sounds, too. They’re really satisfying and contribute greatly to the enjoyment of every moment.

Here you have a trilogy that is not flawless [i]by any stretch of the imagination[/i]. There are weird consistency issues between character relationships, story threads, chapter quality, and so on. Despite these shortcomings, when Ace Attorney is at its best, which is more often than not, it’s a hell of a series and can be a really enthralling experience to even the folks like myself who are not typically fans of visual novels. Incredibly memorable characters, hilarious animations, and tons of wacky moments provide a fun and [i]lengthy[/i] experience. Game 1 alone is so good and [i]long[/i] that it makes buying this at full price a worthwhile investment. At that point, you can consider the two other games icing on the ridiculous cake that is Ace Attorney.

[b]8/10[/b]

Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney is a great series, I love the games to bits. Haven't ever had the chance to play Justice For All or Trials and Tribulations until now, but I'll say this, I really wanted original graphics. I don't mind the HD draws as much as I thought, but there's moments and parts that just look honestly worse in a drawn format instead of pixelated. But, for what it's worth, it's still the great games we've all enjoyed and a very solid story and gameplay loop. However, replayability is extremely low. I play the original game every like year to 2 years, and I still remember the story beat for beat, and the evidence I need for the trial to the point that many cases I don't even have to wonder where to press or object, and go a full case without a single penalty. That's only true of the first game for me, but still, even so, it shows the replayability is low. Very low. Like any graphic novel really. If it's on sale, for 15$, Pick it up. It is so worth it. For 30$, I would say just wait, as it goes on sale nearly every full steam sale, and Sega does plenty of sales anyway, and 10$ per game is a little steep with no Miles Edgeworth: Investigations or Investigations 2, or Apollo Justice: Ace Attorney included in it.

This game has it all. Remarkbaly written characters and engaging cases to solve, all while being simple but oh so effective in its presentation.

The music fits the game perfectly, with just a few reoccurring themes for various story beats. The most iconic example being the "objection" theme playing after an expectant pause when you found the contradiction in a witness' testimony, which theme lulled you in while thinking hard about which piece of evidence would proof a statement wrong is in itself very memorable. It even has a faster paced allegro version to let you know when shit is about to get real.
The animation is as limited as it can get, but is so on point that it leaves nothing to be desired. It brings the characters to life with unique and expressive poses that perfectly portray the character. This acting and their design itself gives you a pretty good idea how their voices would sound. All emphasized by the screen shakes and sound effects the developers use to full potential.

This Trilogy offers a perfect set of villains, the perfect rival caracter and the most likeable protagonist I ever had the honour to play. Phoenix Wright is the guy you always root for, he is never frustrating as all what he does and says you support entirely. The cases differ in quality but are solid in general. Maybe you have to pull through the occasional weak one, but I assure you it is worth it, as the best trials are waiting at the end of each game.

Step into Phoenix Wright's shoes, defend the innocent and find the truth against all odds in the most hilarious, heartfelt and incredible turnabouts that could possibly happen in court!

Don't object to buying this game.

I was deciding if I should buy this game or not during one of the Steam sales, since a few of my friends happened to really like the Ace Attorney series, and well....

I became obsessed with it. For starters, the characters are funny, memorable, and amazing, and the soundtrack instantly became one of my favorite game soundtracks. This game creates suspension that makes you more and more invested in wanting to discover the truth and (hopefully) solve everyone's problems. It also likes to make references, jokes, and the characters enjoy making fun of each other. 

I have 608 screenshots from the first two games in this game, as well as 76 hours, which is the time of review. 

This game will probably make you interested in law.

Lots of play time, and it kept me on edge for hours at a time. It's even difficult to remember what to do in previous trials without a cheat sheet in front of you, so replay value is also pretty good.
