Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy is a compilation of the original 3 games. The games are all visual novels with minor adventure-game exploration segments and an emphasis on courtroom showdowns to reveal the culprit and cut through their lies. 

Get your lawyer’s badge ready as we push papers and wag fingers in this wacky crime visual novel. 



[h1]STORY[/h1]
Being a trilogy pack, the story follows the titular character as he begins as a rookie defense lawyer up until he becomes a seasoned veteran. Overall, the stories are all very fun and unique. In this universe, all crimes must have a verdict within 3 days. In court, both the defense and prosecution will argue their stances to the judge who will hand down the final verdict to the defendant. 

It is Phoenix’s job to get his client found not guilty. All the cases are homicides, so the game does lack variety in terms of case types. Nonetheless, each is filled with a very colorful cast of characters to entertain you on your journey. 

That being said, there certainly are a few cases and characters that are poorly written or annoying. Due to the game being linear, it is sometimes a slog to get through a particular trial or cross examination/interview as the game requires you to have a firm understanding of the events of each case in order to progress. 

When a case is well-written, it is a gripping drama. When it isn’t, it is a bit hard to want to continue. With 14 episodes to explore, there is quite a lot to see and do although I definitely dreaded having to revisit some. 

For the most part, each case is episodic, following a new cast of characters in each case. However, a common theme is that the penultimate case is usually related to the final case of the game and makes Phoenix question himself. Although Phoenix wants to become a great defense attorney, all his cases will shape him in one way or another in the end. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2326779424


[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
As a visual novel, the game is 90% reading with 9% being adventure game item hunting for case clues. The remaining 1% are simple mini-games scattered about. Each case begins with an opening cinematic to give a brief glimpse at its context. Afterwards, you interact with your case assistant and begin your case investigation for day 1. 

You are offered a choice of locales to visit, however some require a certain trigger to be met before unlocking. 

Once you are in a map, you can click the screen to have Phoenix investigate the space, usually to get a clue or receive a funny or quirky comment on it. Once you have gotten all important pieces of evidence and testimonies, you progress to court day 1.

In “Justice for All”, a new minigame is introduced called “psyche locks.” This is simply an out-of-court version of countering their lies with evidence in order to get an important clue or info. 

In court, you will have to guide the case to the truth by questioning witnesses, evaluating the legitimacy of evidence and contending with the prosecution’s harassment and subterfuges. 

First, the judge/ prosecutor gives a case overview and introduces the first witness. The witness gives their testimony to the court. Afterwards, you can “press” a witness for more info to amend a testimony to become more accurate, leading you closer to the truth. 

Once you find an inconsistency in their testimony, you open your evidence list and “present” the relevant evidence. This typically leads the witness to realize their mistake (whether intentional or not) and the case progresses. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2326786232
Sometimes the prosecutor or judge will ask you to elaborate on the evidence and you are presented with a simple multiple-choice question to see if your line of though is correct. In this trilogy, if you are incorrect in either your presented evidence or the contended testimony or choice, you will lose health/ “confidence” from your bar. 

You have 10 pips in total and penalties have varying amounts of damage. Wrong evidence usually costs 1 pip but there are dire moments where the wrong answer leads to an instant game over. 

On that note, the variable writing quality comes up again as evidence and logic hinges entirely on the quality of the case. There are some questions or testimonies that are rather obtuse about what is wrong and trial-and-error spamming of evidence is not uncommon. 

Similarly, some investigation scenes are annoying as the next progression step is unclear. This is usually resolved by showing someone every single thing in your inventory, but there are some scenes where you will have to pixel hunt for a separate interaction prompt in order to get a new clue.  

Cases typically run into the final 3rd day with Phoenix having to re-interview witnesses or look around for new clues. Otherwise, the gameplay loop is the same: find a contradictory testimony, present refuting evidence, answer the prosecution, and reach a non-guilty verdict. This isn’t a terribly exciting or innovative gameplay loop; however, it is the writing and characters that carry the series. 



[h1]VISUALS[/h1]
This trilogy eschews the pixel graphics of the original GBA and DS versions for smoother and more hi-res character portraits/ busts. Overall, everyone looks great although I do miss the nostalgic feel of everything being pixilated. The same can be said about the backgrounds/ locales which received a facelift. Everything definitely feels clearer and smoother now. 

The game also scales properly at 2k resolution which is very welcome.

The game retains all the interesting and wacky character designs from the originals. It is definitely a trip to see some of the more outlandish ones and have to interrogate them in a court of law.   
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2326777839 


[h1]AUDIO[/h1]
The trilogy retains the same music of the original as well with its GBA soundfont. It was definitely nostalgic to hear the “Objection” and “Pursuit” themes again in the first game. Sound effects are overall pretty good, each fitting the attached action well.   



[h1]PERFORMANCE[/h1]
Overall, I had no issue whatsoever with the game. As expected of a visual novel, the overall level of system, graphical and other options is quite sparse. However, none of this affected my ability to enjoy the game. 



[h1]AS A COLLECTION/ RE-RELEASE[/h1]
The games use a new font which is much clearer and cleaner than the handheld's. 16:9 resolution also works as intended.  

One option I wish was included was a chapter select menu. Sometimes I just wanted to replay a particular investigation day or trial day. However, you can only select the overall chapter once you clear it- you have to start over form the very beginning each time. 

Likewise, you only get 10 save slots total. While way more than the handheld versions, I couldn't make a save point for every chapter for easy access for a later time. 

However, I am overall very happy to have all 3 games in 1 convenient package and this is a great purchase for new and returning players. 



[h1]OVERALL[/h1]
Phoenix Wright was my first introduction to visual novels. Having replayed some of it, it definitely still stands up (barring the more annoying cases). This is a series about friendship, truth, determination and much more. He may have fallen to immeasurable depths of despair before, but he has risen anew like his namesake and fights to protect others. Gameplay is very simple, but engaging nonetheless. 

At the end of the day, the game is really about trying your hardest despite all of life’s complications. That, or you shouldn’t become an anime lawyer. 



[h1][b]8/10
SOLID RECOMMENDATION[/b][/h1]

Come on. The game is a classic. If you like puzzles, cartoonish legal drama, and incredibly homo erotic dialog between the main character and his rival, then you've found your game.
Well-written stories. Totally immersed myself in it.

The story is surprisingly very interesting. It really shines when you're in the courtroom and you're exposing all the contradictions in the witness's testimonies, but there are some boring parts during the investigation part of the game. There are guides out there to get through those parts quickly if you don't like them.

Honestly, as someone who never got to play the original games, I understand why this series is so beloved by many. I have few gripes about the game. The characters and writing are fun and memorable, though perhaps leaning into the cheesy at times. My only notable gripe is the lack of diverse investigation technique. Only Case 5 of the first game introduces something new to the table. Aside from that, I always enjoyed how cathartically a case would resolve, revealing the whole truth. 
Personally, my favorite case in terms of trial and investigation is Case 5 of game 1. It has a great cast of characters, alongside my favorite villain to hate. The evidence used in that case was challenging and engaging. For me, Case 5 is the pinnacle of the Ace Attorney. It alone sold me on my purchase.

This game is good, with the caveat that sometimes the leaps of logic it wants you to make are so comical that it almost requires that you look up the answers to some problems. Similarly, it can be extremely difficult to find the end to investigation segments due to the large number of locations you sometimes have to visit, in addition to often difficult to access nested dialogue and evidence. So be prepared to brute force some answers through save scumming or just looking things up. These instances are relatively few and far between, however, and the cases with fewer annoyances truly make the experience all worth it. Do try to stick through to the end, as the completion % of this game is depressingly low, and the last case is phenomenal.

You play a defense attorney who regularly flouts judicial norms by convicting witnesses and cross-examining his own defendants. He went into the biz as a way of sublimating his gay tension with a frilly prosecutor, and got stuck watering someone else's plant. Also once ate a key piece of evidence.

Great game! Can recommend if you like mysteries, long character arcs, complicated relationships, over-the-top humor and controller vibration. You will learn where the "Objection!" and "Updated autopsy report" memes come from (and where the "You are not a clown" meme does [i]not[/i] come from). You will also learn the two rules of evidence law, only so you can break them over and over again.

I loved these games on the DS and I'm enjoying them all over again now on PC. The characters are charming and the dialogue is really funny in places. As with the DS versions, there are times when the answer to a particular matter is obscure or conditional on something non-obvious but in general the gameplay - investigation and courtroom drama - is a lot of fun.

Good classic set of games.

Main gameplay was fun for me. Talk to characters, collect evidence, and use your thinker to apply them.
I found some parts a bit weird in terms of its logic, but maybe I just have peanut brain. This rarely happened though and most  of the time it feels very satisfying to apply the evidence you collect to contradict the witness and prosecutor.

The highlight of this game is easily the character. Over the course of the three games you meet a wide variety of wacky fellows and each one is memorable and entertaining. The character design is top notch and filled with creativity. One small gripe I have is that some character appear a bit too often and they can wear on you a little bit. I very much preferred meeting new character over revisiting the old.

The stories in these games are very entertaining. Each one has a very simple formula of a seemingly clear cut case slowly unraveling to find a more unexpected truth. Despite this repeated formula, each time always plays out in fun and unexpected ways. Every story move in creative directions that keep you on your toes and I found the stories in all the games enjoyable and fun. In some cases the stories can provide a bit of emotion.

Music in this game is also great and makes the courtroom scenes feel hype.

Very great games. I would say each game is better than the last in the trilogy.

Before buying this during the summer sale, I had never played an Ace Attorney game. But this trilogy is well worth the price. I'm not too big on point and click visual novels - I think they're boring and generic - but Ace Attorney, or at the very least these three games are filled with charming and lovable characters that most of the time are incredibly funny, but can also have their emotional moments. Even if there are a few awful cases in these three games that can, at times, make you not want to finish the game at all, the best moments, such as the final case of JFA and the second case in T&T, always find a way to subvert your expectations, and are all cleverly written. I'm really glad I bought this game without any prior knowledge or interest in the series, as I went in completely blind, and was incredibly surprised with what I received. My only real advice is that if you want to go for all the achievements in this game (which is really easy to do), you basically NEED to follow a guide otherwise you'll miss out on plenty of them, and have to restart cases from the very start. Otherwise, this is a straightforward, problem solving game. I'm a fan.

[h1] The Ace Attorney Trilogy are some of the best games I have ever played[/h1]

It's likely that even outside of gaming circles, you've heard of Ace Attorney before. The games are absolute classics that have made their mark on the world and influenced pop culture to there and back again to the point where you can find references to them everywhere. Ace Attorney is iconic.

But is it really that good? Simply put, yes! Absolutely.

Playing as a young man named Phoenix Wright, you navigate your way through your career as a defense attorney, tearing apart the smallest contradictions in testimonies to prove your clients' innocence and find the real killer, investigating crime scenes and running into a colorful cast of recurring characters along the way.

The writing is very smart. The cases are all put together wonderfully, the pacing is perfect, the jokes are all hilarious (seriously, these are some of the funniest games I've ever played), and the characters and incredibly likable and human.

I think the characters are easily the best part of this series. We came to solve fun mysteries, and stayed for the characters and their relationships with one another. Of course we enjoy finding out who the real killer is and how they did it, but what we really want to know is if Phoenix and Edgeworth are going to rekindle their friendship or what's going to happen to the Fey clan next. What happens to these characters will move you and make you feel deeply to the point where you're on the edge of your seat praying for their safety.

I found myself liking pretty much every character except Godot, but aside from myself, fans seem to love every single character except the villains, who we're supposed to hate so that checks out. The characters all feel uniquely human and real, and they'll worm their way into your hearts so you'll never forget them and will be pleasantly surprised when they show up in later installments.

The gameplay is something special. It's rather simplistic, you have a few buttons you can press to make a few decisions but most of the time you're just reading text. Despite that though, it's still incredibly engaging and you'll be biting your nails trying to figure out the right choices. And once you do make the right choices? Man, does it feel [i]powerful.[/i] When the iconic "objection" rings out, Phoenix slams his hands down on the desk, and the music cuts out, you know things are going down, and you feel proud of yourself that you were able to figure it out.

And of course, while it's not the top feature, the cases are wonderful too. There's nothing like a good murder mystery, and when [i]you're[/i] the one who's responsibility it is to solve it, you can get really into it. They're all engaging and creative mysteries with a unique cast that will keep you on your toes trying to figure it out.

The Ace Attorney games are iconic cornerstones in gaming history filled with great mysteries, fun gameplay, and compelling characters (all of which you can pick up for an excellent price) that deserve all of the hype they get. If you're interested, or even if you aren't I [i]implore[i] you to pick up the trilogy.

I don't usually leave reviews for most games; hell, I don't usually leave reviews for most things. I'm that much of a lazy a-hole. Well, most of the time, at least. But man, I gotta be honest, I haven't had this much fun in a game (series) for a very long time now - and that's saying something, considering how diverse and expansive my personal library of games is these days. Despite how relatively "dated" the original trilogy of Ace Attorney games are (and I shall forever be upset with myself that I never bothered to play the original games when I had the chance years ago) in comparison to their later counterparts, and indeed, other games of a similar design/approach, there's just something about the first three titles of the Ace Attorney series that makes them downright impossible to dislike - impossible to not enjoy. Perhaps it's the way the cases are structured; perhaps it's the very anime nature of the characters themselves; or, perhaps it's the otherwise crazed design of the setting itself, being an odd mis-mash of America and Japan. It's probably all of it, and more. However, I do know one thing for certain: I absolutely do not regret getting this trilogy, and hope that with the overwhelmingly positive reception its still receiving, Capcom will take notice and port the rest of the series to Steam. I'd certainly buy them in a heartbeat.

Phoenix Wright is a classic for a good reason. For anyon who hasn't played, here's the gist;

You're an attorney, and your goal is to help clients who have no hope. The gameplay comes in two different flavors: a point-and-click style investigation stage, complete with characters to talk to and environments to explore, and a dialogue-based trial stage, where you piece everything from the investigations together. 

There are some weird quirks about the logic and court proceedings of this game, but I feel like it's easy to get a handle on what they expect from you, for the most part. I do, however, think that some of the conclusions you're meant to come to are kind of a stretch, and I feel like this game is best played with a hints guide to help you along. (I've certainly needed it, be it that I'm drawing a complete blank or that I feel as though my solution won't work when, indeed, it will.) 

Anyways, if you could tell, I do think it's pretty difficult in a lot of places (sometimes to the point of being completely unfair...), though they also nail some things so far into your head... Like teaching you that pepper makes people sneeze by making not one, not two, but THREE people sneeze when presented with pepper... Along with an explanation about how pepper makes people sneeze. Thanks....

I also thought some plotpoints were ridiculous and cheesy at first (like the final case of the 2nd game, which I've currently just finished), but the resolutions have generally been really satisfying to make up for it, in my opinion. 

(Also, can we not make an 8-year-old channel the spirit of an adult who turns the body of whoever she's possessing into her own? It's a little wacky bro. And also can we not have a 16-yo be proposed to by one 21-year-old man and a puppet controlled by a 30-year-old man? :') )

This is a trilogy of visual novel/point and click games about a defense attorney and his group of friends defending wacky clients where you NEED to think. Amazing story with highly likeable characters, great writing full of plot twists and satisfying moments. Great soundtrack that really adds to the investigation and courtroom atmosphere, the point and click gameplay consist mostly about finding and presenting evidence, reading funny dialogue and most of all thinking well on the correct answer. The game really uses minimal animation focused on poses that really emphasizes the personality of each character with plenty of shaking and sound effects that gives the game more "umph" to the situations and atmosphere. Love that!

Although, I got really impressed with the quality of the cases that the 3 games offers, I have some critisism. For example, there are various instances where you get stuck in the investigations parts, maybe because you forgot certain clue or didn't presented certain evidence to "x" character so there is some backtracking when it comes to his linear progress. Also can happen in court, that lets say, you know where is the contradiction but you haven't pressed enough to present another line of testimony or you get lost on what line should you present the evidence to continue and not lose health. Oh I haven't told you about the health bar, you can save and load whenever you want so the health bar wasn't a thing to be stressed about. Also in the last case of the first game, somehow the story of that case has some plot holes that you might find. Might be because that last case didn't exist in the original game, but they added that one on the release on the Nintendo DS so idk. BUT DO NOT LET THESE THINGS STOP YOU

 but i had a lot of fun, haven't found any bugs and I was really inmersed in the world. So of course i will keep playing the rest of the games. My mind got blown away.

All the characters feel alive and part of the world which makes the game feel like a great overarching epic rather than being slammed with different cases and random faces that wont matter which end of the gavel they finish on. The investigations and sense of urgency aren't as good as Danganronpa but I think that can be attributed to it's pursuit of realism. Danganronpa just has wild things that wouldn't make sense in a modern day world aiming for realistic representation. As trials go on, the majority of the evidence gets produced after the trial is near the halfway point, in which you have to go back and investigate the crime scenes again, which limits the player from being able to place suspicion. This creates an effect of just expecting to be spoon fed the real answer later on, which in my opinion makes a lot of parts of the trials feel pointless. When you are able to be in the action figuring out the real truth, it does deliver and does quite well. 

In the end tho its a gr8 experience

I decided I wanted to write an actual review and not be lazy about it. Phoenix Wright is a crime solving game in which you play a defense attorney. You go to different locations to find clues about the crime, and then present your evidence in a court battle against the prosecutors. All cases in this game mostly have a connection to the whole overarching story. There's an absolutely lovable cast of characters in the game. This trilogy is pretty awesome (no surprise there) I feel like no one really checks these sections for reviews of whether they should buy the game or not, but if you are here, hi. now, if you do not like reading, this game is definitely not for you, the whole game is just reading and pointing out how people are lying, there is no action and in the first game the only episode that changes things up is the last one, which was actually made for the DS. Oh yeah, and what you'll get is, 3 games with the first one having 5 episodes (including that extra episode made for the DS release) the second game has 4 episodes and finally the third game giving you 5 episodes, leaving you with 14 episodes, now the tutorial episodes wont take you too long but boy how the ending of the first game took me a little bit haha, honestly though all of these games are great unless you don't like reading, but if you do then this is definitely the game for you, the completionist made a great video on this game too if you want to check it out, but when you mess up something you will feel the stress but when you hit the opponent with that objection, it feels amazing and the music just adds to the experience. Now I would like to finish off with little advice, breathe, don't rush the game, you aren't on a time limit so just think before you act, also don't feel too bad if you need to look up a guide on the last ones, no one will judge you, and also, in the last case of the first game, make sure you line up things perfectly, since it was made for the DS with a stylus, it can be a little picky whether it's right or wrong, even if you've put something together perfectly, the game might just screw you over because you didn't do it perfectly, but hey, that's okay, just take you're time and you'll do great! So what are you doing here? buy the game already, I'll see you in court!

I can't say that I've ever really been that interested in visual novels. I spent about half an hour attempting to come up with an excuse for why, but I just can’t think of any. I guess I just don't like reading... However, there's one series that I've always wanted to try and that's 'Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney'. After playing the first case at a friend's house, I bit the bullet and gave the trilogy a shot. Now that I've donned the blue suit and stepped into the courtroom, does this game deserve the heaps of praise it gets? Yeah, kinda. 

For those who don't know, in 'Ace Attorney' you play as Pheonix Wright, the Ace Attorney (and also detective I guess). Your clients have been accused of that most heinous of crimes: murder. It's up to you to defend these poor saps in court while also gathering enough clues to figure out who the true culprit is. I’ll start by saying that I really like this dynamic because even though you're an "attorney" you also get to play the role of the prosecutor when you find the [i]real[/i] bad-guy and attempt to indict them instead. You start each case on the backfoot and slowly shift from defense to offense. It keeps things fresh. 

I guess now’s a good time to mention that if you're looking for a realistic judicial/mock trial experience you ain't gonna find it here. 'Ace Attorney' is pretty over the top and silly, but honestly I wouldn't have it any other way. Each case has its own unique twists and mysteries to unravel. Things are rarely ever as they seem, and oftentimes, the most implausible explanation for something is what actually happened. It’s like all the criminals in this universe bought the Dick Dastardly book on villainy. 

The obvious draw of this game lies with its characters, and I’m not just talking about how they’re written. The character sprites in 'Ace Attorney' are amazing, full stop. I never got tired of watching Victor Kudo smack his bulbous nose or Oldbag shoot her toy ray gun. The animators did such a great job with each and every character. Excitement, anger, stress, defeat; these emotions are communicated beautifully through just a few simple frames of animation. The best animations happen when Phoenix proves who the real culprit is. Once they realize they’ve lost, the villains always have this amazing breakdown that acts as a massive emotional release at the end of each case. It’s brilliant. 

The individual cases are (generally) really engaging nuggets of storytelling, but what’s really impressive is how ‘Phoenix Wright’ weaves a narrative thread throughout the entire trilogy. This thread is largely constructed by the prosecutors that you square off with. Miles, Franziska, and Godot are superbly written and provide some of the best back and forths in the entire trilogy. This game is packed with genuinely emotional moments. Even when the story veers into the absurd the sentiment still felt convincing, kind of like a Broadway play. There were times when I really felt for both the defendants and the culprits. I even got a little watery during the third game’s final act. 

Most cases aren’t airtight, and this rule also applies to videogames. I do have a few issues with ‘Ace Attorney’ that I’ll briefly go through now. For starters, it seems like the same level of care that was given to the character animations was [i]not[/i] applied to the backgrounds. Other than the iconic courtroom scene, most of the other settings in the game are kinda bland looking. Though I guess this is alright, as it makes it easier to spot important pieces of evidence. The soundtrack is also pretty hit or miss. Sometimes the music is exquisite, like in the iconic track ‘Cornered’ or in ‘The Fragrance of Dark Coffee’. Other times the music is loud and grating, like in the first game’s ‘Moderato 2001’ or in ‘Happy People’ (god, I fucking [i]hate[/i] that song). 

Lastly, I think the player should have the option to load to the beginning of a given trial day. This is because I managed to soft-lock my game after saving in a bad spot. I couldn’t just restart the day’s trial, so I had to start the [i]entire[/i] case over again. This was particularly grating because it was the longest case in the trilogy… There is nothing I hate more than being forced to repeat a large chunk of a game that I’ve already done. This incident almost soured me on the whole experience. 

[i]almost[/i]

However, even I couldn’t deny that ‘Phoenix Wright’ had me in the palm of his hand. I was too invested to quit, so I slogged through that entire case all over again (which was worth it). Honestly, the whole trilogy is worth it; I just had to see it all through to the bitter end. If you’re in the market for a deductive visual novel with charming characters and a gripping story, you really can’t go wrong with ‘Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney’. I must say, it feels good to have fulfilled my reading quota for the decade. See you in ten years.

Great story! Great characters! Very intellectually challenging. The games get harder as you proceed, with Trials and Tribulations being the hardest. Very accessible, since you can play with either mouse or keyboard (or both). You can also save and load at pretty much any point in the game, just like the DS originals. Has multiple language options, which also change the few bits of spoken language in the game, as well as all text.

The graphics have been enhanced to feature the actual artwork and it supports various resolutions. This game is however stuck at 16:9 aspect ratio, due to the nature of this being a 2D drawn visual novel. Altough, I remember the DS versions having you pan across the entire screen to see the full drawing. Regardless, seeing the full artwork all at once makes the gameplay experience way more smooth.

Other than changing the resolution, you can also set 3 transparency levels for text boxes (None, low and high).

Sound is great. Powerful sound effects. HOLD IT! You can also adjust the sound levels of both music and SFX.
